fields.headline: Farewell, Home Sweet Home
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: It's the sort of work that grows on you, but you could be forgiven for thinking that, well, it doesn't grow quickly enough
fields.body:
Farewell, Home Sweet Home is an elusive and enigmatic film from the Georgian director Otar Ioseliani; it is the story of Nicolas, the son of a wealthy but chaotic household, in which the father, played by Ioseliani himself, is a hopeless philandering drunk, and the mother (Lely Lavina) is a ruthless businesswoman. The original title, Adieu, Plancher des Vaches, or "Farewell to the cow floor" is evidently a cheerful old sailor's phrase traditionally uttered on putting to sea, and this is Ioseliani's informing theme: Nicolas sets out to rid himself of his family's wealthy trappings; he sallies forth from the mansion and mixes with the city's homeless - getting a menial job washing up in a cafe, and having various thwarted adventures.

These narrative strands take a lot of unpicking from the disjointed and deadpan way they are presented, though, and even the most attentive will find it difficult to work out just what is going on. There is something very opaque and a little unrewarding about the film as a whole, although the scenes in the family home have an agreeably bizarre quality, with something of Buñuel in the giant stork that quietly and surreally pads around the place. It's the sort of work that grows on you, but you could be forgiven for thinking that, well, it doesn't grow quickly enough.

fields.headline: Rules of Engagement
fields.standfirst: Peter Bradshaw   despairs at William Friedkin's grotesque, lazy war movie Rules of Engagement
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This shrill, belligerent, reactionary nonsense is lazily plotted, grotesquely dishonest, and dripping with a creepy strain of Islamophobia
fields.body:
There could not possibly be a more terrible film on release now than Rules of Engagement, the big new action movie from no less a director than William Friedkin. This shrill, belligerent, reactionary nonsense is lazily plotted, grotesquely dishonest, and dripping with a creepy strain of Islamophobia. The film is about one of Uncle Sam's uniformed heroes accused of bending the rules in the heat of battle and - but of course - let down by the pointy-headed PC politicos in Washington. Samuel L Jackson plays Colonel Terry Childers, a Marine Corps veteran who leads a mission to rescue the US ambassador from the Yemen embassy. The ambassador is a nervous, cowardly, duplicitous liar, and therefore played by a British actor, Ben Kingsley. When a local anti-American demo turns ugly a catastrophe ensues.

Shot at from somewhere outside the embassy compound, Childers orders his men to fire into the crowd - having to repeat his order to a terrified subordinate who can see no justification for this - and causes scores of civilian deaths.

The consequent political row leads to a court-martial, and Childers asks to be defended by his old buddy Colonel Hodges (Tommy Lee Jones), a desk-bound army lawyer whose life he saved in Vietnam 30 years before. Hays is a mediocre lawyer and semi-reformed drinker liable to fall off the wagon at any time. But never mind that: he's a Marine, and he knows what it's like to risk death under fire, and so only he has the kind of moral Übermensch status necessary to tackle this crisis. He's the only guy Terry can trust .

In Humphrey Bogart's immortal phrase, it stinks up the screen. Jackson and Jones are less than convincing as soldiers of any sort, and by seeking to endow the Marines with both triumphal glamour and victim status, the film strikes more false notes than a platoon of pissed Banffshire pipers. Rules of Engagement turns on the very simple issue of whether there were armed terrorists concealed in the apparently unarmed demo crowd. If there were, Childers would obviously have some justification for his action. But through a tiresome sleight of hand, this information is withheld from us until the very end, thus maintaining a bogus narrative and moral tension.

There is, we learn, a videotape recovered from one of the embassy's CCTV cameras, which could exonerate Terry. A sinister national security aide conceals it - naturally setting up our expectation of its eventual discovery at the 11th hour. But later, the evil aide burns it. Oh no! Our hero's only material evidence up in smoke! Will a copy be found? Er, no. Hays mutters some thing at the trial about a missing video but finally manages to persuade the khaki-clad jury to acquit his man with nothing more concrete than a heart-rending, choked-up speech about how as army folk they should not leave a Marine "out to dry". Over the closing credits, almost as an afterthought, we are perfunctorily informed that the corrupt video-hiding-and-burning aide has been busted.

So the video muddle shows Stephen Gaghan's screenplay needed a few rewrites. But that is not the real insult to the intelligence. To garner evidence for the defence, Colonel Hodges goes out to Yemen and sees for himself the terrible civilian casualties, including a heartbreaking little girl with one leg, hobbling around on a crutch. This is the cue for one of the shortest dark nights of the soul on record. Hays gets drunk on the plane back and gets involved in a fist-fight with Jackson - which is quickly resolved by the two of them guffawing and slapping each other on the back. The issue of civilian casualties is just the pretext for some male bonding.

The full queasy significance of this sugary pseudo-resolution does not, however, emerge until William Friedkin finally favours us with what Jackson actually saw before he opened fire: a lot of sinister dusky Ay-rabs with guns, hiding among the women and children in the demo - and the heartbreaking little girl was actually toting a weapon herself! You can't trust these towel-heads when they whinge about civilian deaths, you see... The sheer effrontery of that moment made me gasp. But it was nothing to what Friedkin produces at the finish: a North Vietnamese combat veteran wheeled out as a prosecution witness to testify to the nature of Terry's brutality to unarmed PoWs in 'Nam. Miraculously shedding his semi-drunken incompetence, Hays forces him in cross-examination to admit that he would do the same thing himself. And on the courtroom steps, over a rich violin swell, the greying Vietcong guy actually salutes the victorious Terry.

It was at this moment that I moaned from the stalls: "Oh for Christ's sake !" We're used to self-pitying tough guys in uniform shouting at us that we can't handle the truth. But Rob Reiner's A Few Good Men at least had good performances and a sharp script. And David O Russell's Three Kings showed us that it is possible to make a modern war movie which is politically savvy, yet sympathetic to the choices faced by soldiers in battle.

But all Friedkin serves up is a naive macho romp - with a little contemporary twist. As the bullets fly in Yemen, we see a photo on the wall of the ambassador's office of Bill Clinton, and another of Al Gore. In a later scene, the Clinton photo has for some reason disappeared. But Gore is still there - this year's little-fancied Democratic hopeful, presiding over this political betrayal of America's fighting man. Is Rules of Engagement the kind of Hollywood war film we can expect to see from now on? Compassionate nouveau Rambo for the George Bush Jr generation?

webTitle: Food: Tomás Graves on bread and olive oil, the subject of his book

fields.headline: Our daily bread
fields.standfirst: In Majorca, the traditional peasant fare of pa amb oli - bread drizzled with olive oil - is enjoying a revival. Here Tomás Graves, son of the poet Robert Graves, celebrates a deceptively simple dish
fields.trailText: In Majorca, the traditional peasant fare of pa amb oli - bread drizzled with olive oil - is enjoying a revival. Here Tomás Graves, son of the poet Robert Graves, celebrates a deceptively simple dish
fields.body:
I have no Majorcan blood and if I consider myself a local lad it's not so much for having been born in Guillem Massot street in Palma or attending the village school, as for having suckled from the same breast as the majority of islanders: the setrill, the olive oil cruet.

If children who share the same wet nurse are known as "brothers in milk", then consider me your "brother in oil". At the age of four, I came down with measles. The first sign of recovery, after a few days in bed, was this plea: "Mother, I want a pa amb oli." At home, we have always taken the question of olive oil fairly seriously. We have more than 50 olive trees, and any casual visitor who drops by the house between October and February is likely to be handed an olive-picking basket.

One year, a group of US students spent a winter in our village on a creative writing course and my father would lecture them while they picked olives for him. While I was studying typographic design at the London College of Printing, on one of those cold February days when not even a squirrel can be seen in Battersea Park, I came down with a case of that homesickness which all of us who have been born on sa roqueta (the little rock) have felt at some time or another, so I decided to perk myself up with a good plate of bread and oil.

No sooner said than done: I popped into the local Sainsbury's to buy bread (sliced), tomatoes (from a greenhouse) and olive oil (with as much colour and character as sewing machine oil). The insipid, colourless result was no more than a plastic parody of the original. It immediately dawned on me that a pa amb oli, like experience itself, is not transferable. That is to say, as a concept, it doesn't "travel well" because its identity depends totally upon having the authentic ingredients at hand.

The term pa amb oli means exactly that: bread and olive oil. It usually includes salt and scrubbed garlic, or sugar instead of salt for kids, if the oil is too strong or rancid. For the majority of today's islanders, the term includes tomato (in slices or scrubbed on to the bread) but most of the older generation still make a distinction: when I was a child, I would ask my mother for a slice of pa amb oli, and she would give it me plain.

If I wanted it with tomato, I'd have to ask for it specially. The tomato, like the potato, is of course a relative newcomer - a question of centuries, not millennia - and neither has yet been granted full citizenship. The Majorcan haute cuisine, or cuina de senyor, served at the tables of the landed gentry, has received a big push lately at the expense of the authentic peasant fare, because today we're all senyors, more interested in satisfying our curiosity and palate than our body and soul. There are plenty of books on sale with full-page, four-colour glossies of Majorcan dishes, each more recherché, sophisticated and aesthetically presented than the last, none of which was ever tasted by 99% of the population. Yet the reader will be lucky to find four lines dedicated to the basis of the diet: bread and oil. Shouldn't we be ashamed of ourselves?

People say to me, incredulously: "You mean to say you're writing a whole book about bread and oil?" as if the subject warranted no more than a paragraph. Yet for centuries it was the pillar of the Balearic survival diet. It was the only thing left between hunger and starvation, feeding generation upon generation of islanders, and without it many would not be here today: it deserves full recognition.

Perhaps this dish has been edited out of the cookery books because it appears too simple and thus unworthy of occupying space reserved for fancier recipes. The way I see it, preparing a plate of bread and oil is like playing good rock 'n' roll; it's so simple that few people can do it properly.

The perfect pa amb oli has two secret ingredients: honesty and appetite. Neither of which is easy to find in the Balearics since we've become a society of abundance, indifference and cynicism, treating our islands as a tourist destination rather than the place in which we live.

Much of today's urban youth in Majorca has grown up outside the domestic bread-and-oil tradition and has only now discovered, through the ever increasing network of pa amb oli cafes, a new way of eating healthily while out on the town.

Most fast-food restaurants are conceptually based upon a battery-hen farm. Everything is thought out - decor, lighting, music, production lines, fodder that can be swallowed without chewing - to stuff the maximum amount of gizzards as fast, cheaply, hygienically and artificially as possible.

The atmosphere is attractive when seen from the street (to capture the customer) but once inside, it is sterile and alienating (so that the customer has no desire to stay once he has finished his food, leaving the seat vacant for the next sucker).

A pa amb oli cafe tends to be conceptually the opposite: relaxed, civilized and cosily welcoming, although not much to look at from the outside. It is decorated on a low budget with natural (or at least unpretentious) materials and discreet lighting; your order is served with proper cutlery, crockery and glassware, and nothing comes in a plastic container. The food is unprocessed and full of vitality, inciting the customer to get to grips with it: not just finger-lickin' good, but palm-wiping delicious.

The youth of any nation, to become true citizens of the world, have to transcend their own culture; but to get to that point they first have to assimilate their own, not only intellectually but with all five senses: their music and language, smells, colours, tastes and textures. Bread and oil gives any young Majorcan a solid sense of his roots: island-dwelling, maritime, Mediterranean roots.

The raw materials for a pa amb oli are, in proportion, immensely more expensive than those used in a pizza or hamburger (as most ethically produced things usually are) but the final price is similar to a fast-food meal.

Several reasons can explain this: there's no expensive trademark one-upmanship, no high-rent prominent locations, and anyone running a pa amb oli cafe is obviously not aiming to get rich quick. The pa amb oli itself, being uncooked, is less open to manipulation in the kitchen (no deep-frying, microwaving, etc) while the ingredients, preserved using traditional techniques, contain few if any E additives: they usually are what they appear to be.

"At today's prices, a pizza will cost you more, but the ingredients for a pa amb oli have to be seen to be of better quality because they aren't disguised beneath a coat of melted cheese," says Xisco Cortes, who runs the Amano Bar. "With this dish, which anyone can make at home, you can't cut corners by buying cheap ingredients; you have to serve a ham or cheese of a higher quality than the customer would usually buy at the supermarket, so that he really enjoys his meal."

Most pa amb oli joints open only in the evenings, combining the social function of a pub or wine bar, the cultural function of a theatre-cafe (music, theatre, debates, poetry), and the practical one of a restaurant. S'Hostal, in Monuiri, began to make spectacular pa amb olis 30 years ago, but, one of the owners points out, "It's only been over the last decade that the partying doesn't stop until well into the wee hours."

This reflects the island's recent trend in decentralisation of night life from the city to the villages, as more young people move back to the rural areas. The bread and oil option allows cafes to offer more than just drinks (and avoid the problem of clients getting drunk on an empty stomach) without having to invest in costly kitchen equipment and space.

"The health authorities don't find much cause for concern when they inspect pa amb oli cafes, as long as the kitchen area is clean, because it's a dish which is bought, prepared and served; they don't need to poke about because you can't camouflage anything, it's all up front," says Xisco Cortes.

"If the bread-and-oil movement goes from strength to strength it's not just on the merits of the food, but because it's served in a very pleasant atmosphere, very much our own. Places like these all have Majorcan character, they offer good company, a good feeling and reasonable prices. I have two regular customers, a five-year-old and an eight-year-old, who prefer to come here than to go out and eat a hamburger."

In the area around the Santa Catalina market, bread and oil is king, especially on a Friday night when it's almost impossible to find a table in any of the dozens of specialised cafes. "A few years ago, this neighbourhood was on the decline," Xisco continues. "It was a demeaning situation that the people who have always lived here didn't deserve. I really put my weight behind this project; others came along, thank God, and stood beside me. What we've achieved is that this area now has a solid future as a centre for bread and oil. This dish is the basis of my business."

I think the time has come to vindicate and exalt this bread-and-oil culture because it sums up the best of our insular and Mediterranean selves. On the one hand, it reflects a simplicity, frugality, honesty and respect for tradition while on the other, the capacity to open up and adapt to outside influences without losing one's own identity. Partaking of a pa amb oli can be a solitary ritual conducive to introspection and withdrawal; but, if shared, it can lead beyond participation, into conversation and even end up as a party.

This article is extracted from Bread & Oil, Majorcan Culture's Last Stand, published by Prospect Books, price £12 (including post and packaging). Telephone Tom Jaine on 01803 712269 for a copy.

fields.headline: More awful repeats
fields.standfirst: Astrid Garage, London
fields.trailText: Astrid Garage, London
fields.body:
The (mostly male) crowd were barking for more at the end of Astrid's show, but I'd be pushed to give a reason why. Astrid are, in essence, an indie boyband and they adhere absolutely to the rules of their genre: basic verse-chorus structures, guitars that rock in a jangly, unadventurous way, lyrics about girls, films, sunshine. If the Scottish quintet have an idiosyncrasy, it's a penchant for repetition, a stylistic shortcoming that is all the more offensive because their lyrics are insipid in the extreme.

They reach their nadir with the chorus to Horror Movie: "I love horror movies/Monsters and ghouls are just so groovy". Even if it were ironic, it would be awful. In a weak attempt to instill some character into their bouncing pop rock, they make ample use of the theremin button on the keyboard; the result is about as eerie as a plastic toy mummy, and just as spineless. Astrid relentlessly demonstrate their belief that a song isn't complete unless the chorus has been sung eight times without once acknowledging that simplicity and reiteration don't automatically breed memorable songs.

Their final attempt at a tune fleetingly hints that they might, finally, redeem themselves: it opens with the words, "Are you a boy or are you a girl? Even when you rock my world", and you think, ah, an essay on the intricacies of transvestite life! Musings on bisexuality! But no: they just repeat those two lines again and again until there is nothing to read between them.

fields.headline: Motion to mesmerise
fields.standfirst: Anjali Dance Company, Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.trailText: Anjali Dance Company, Royal Festival Hall, London
fields.body:
August is the month for the free dance festival Blitz - renamed Blazing 2000 - on London's South Bank, with its workshops, exhibitions and daily performances. The star attraction this year is Anjali Dance Company who, after a three-day residency, performed Prosperous Beach, an evocative "mood" piece created with choreographer and performer Matthew Hawkins. An ex-Royal Ballet dancer, Hawkins's style combines camp eccentricity with a classical preoccupation with detail, line and form.

Anjali is unusual in the respect that its performers have learning disabilities. The company challenges the existing stereotype in dance - one that is obsessed with "perfect" bodies and virtuosic technique - by presenting us with differently abled bodies who excel in honesty, humour and sensuality. It seduces its audience by presenting work that doesn't so much show off the dancers' extraordinary grasp of technique but rather their personalities and their committed interpretation of the choreography.

Dressed in elegant black costumes that parody Ancient Greek style and have a cheeky, camp aesthetic, the dancers inhabit the performance space in a series of dignified friezes. They weave through small movements and intricate gestures with a mysterious sense of purpose while the music of Richard Strauss and Mendelssohn lends an air of demure authority to their intimate actions. The aesthetics of balance and harmony, which Hawkins is so good at creating, appear no less with these dancers, who are mesmerising.

Anjali promotes an exciting new precedent for disabled dance, one that is about visibility, confidence and glamour. The company asks us to challenge our preconceptions about what dance is and how we look at it.

 Anjali will be appearing at the Clore Studio, Royal Opera House, September 19-24. Box office: 020-7304 4000. Blaze 2000 information is on 020-7960 4242.

webTitle: Jazz review: On the edge of your seat

fields.headline: On the edge of your seat
fields.standfirst: Jazz Jamaica, Ronnie Scott's Club, London
fields.trailText: Jazz Jamaica, Ronnie Scott's Club, London
fields.body:
Jazz Jamaica playing the theme from Exodus might sound like a Caribbean version of Herb Alpert and the Tijuana Brass playing A Taste of Honey (all the usual emotional resonances are cheerfully stood on their head), but as with old Herb, the effect can make it hard to keep the feet of even the sniffiest jazz audiences still.

Jazz Jamaica is the ensemble run by bass-playing former Jazz Warrior Gary Crosby as a vehicle for classic grooves - calypso, ska and mento - to run under jazz solos. The beat is everything in a band like this, and Jazz Jamaica has an irresistible rhythm section, dominated by the effortlessly propulsive Kenrick Rowe on drums.

During the opening ska pieces at their Wednesday show, the band coasted over the groove initially, the soloists sounding as if they were filling in gaps. But as it gathered in confidence, Jazz Jamaica began to develop the fluidity and interplay between the pulse and the improvising. The mento piece revealed the Latin influences in Jamaican music and brought a characteristic trumpet solo of wild trills and rasping runs played like ripping fabric from Eddie ("Tan Tan") Thornton. Exodus was taken with a reggae bounce, the solos by now weaving seamlessly through it, and a Caribbean blues brought a rugged tenor solo from Michael Bami Rose.

Also at Ronnie Scott's this week is the superb trio led by pianist (and sometime drummer) Gary Husband, with some scalding drumming from Gene Calderazzo and the powerful, sinewy counter-melody of bassist Mick Hutton. Husband's broad grasp of contemporary jazz takes in the spacy electronics of 80s Miles Davis, and driving uptempo acoustic postbop that puts you on the edge of your seat, if you can find one.

 Both until tomorrow. Box office: 020-7439 0747.

fields.headline: Pieces of America
fields.standfirst: London Sinfonietta/ Knussen, Royal Albert Hall, London
fields.trailText: London Sinfonietta/ Knussen, Royal Albert Hall, London
fields.body:
Aaron Copland is one of the featured composers of this season's Proms, and the London Sinfonietta and Oliver Knussen celebrated his achievement in a late-night concert that focused on rarities from his output, with startling results.

Copland encapsulated the vastness of America and drew on its folk heritage. But we tend to forget that he trained in Paris, and the Prom brought home the realisation of how French some of his music sounds. The opening of his Clarinet Concerto has been compared with Appalachian Spring, but its limpid melody over a deep, pulsing accompaniment disconcertingly recalls Satie's Gymnopedies. Jazz influences enter the piece later as the pace gathers. It's as if the work describes a States-wards journey out of Europe, culminating in the dazzle of New York. It requires a virtuoso soloist and in Michael Collins it finds perhaps its ideal interpreter.

Music For The Theatre was seen as quintessentially American when first performed in 1925, though its tangy sonorities and brassy sleaze conjure up the work of Parisian dives. Stravinsky-style rhythmic propulsion lurks behind the so-called Short Symphony (in reality, the Second) of 1933 - deemed unplayable in its day. Knussen and the Sinfonietta flung it out with buoyancy.

I was less happy with Lukas Foss's Time Cycle. Berlin-born Foss's music was admired by Bernstein in the 60s. Time Cycle, for soprano and orchestra, peers back from America towards Europe. Rosemary Hardy voiced the songs with voluptuous ease, but neither she nor Knussen could quite disguise the derivative quality.

fields.headline: Banks and brass necks
fields.standfirst:
Where Barclays goes, others may follow
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: It would be easy to say that the attempt by Barclays to take over Woolwich, the former building society, should be left to market forces to decide. After all, traditional banks are facing threats from new telephone banks (like the Co-op) and internet-only ones (like Egg) which offer cheaper mortgages and higher interest rates on deposits
fields.body:
It would be easy to say that the attempt by Barclays to take over Woolwich, the former building society, should be left to market forces to decide. After all, traditional banks are facing threats from new telephone banks (like the Co-op) and internet-only ones (like Egg) which offer cheaper mortgages and higher interest rates on deposits. Part of their competitive advantage derives from the lower cost of electronic transactions and the fact that they do not have to bear the heavy fixed costs of branch networks. Since these circumstances make branch closures inevitable in the long term, the obvious course is to allow existing banks to merge so they can implement the rationalisation in a cost-effective way.

Obvious, but wrong. There are two good reasons why rationalisation is too important to be left to the banks . First, they find it all too easy to abuse their collective market power. It was only pressure of public opinion that forced them to abandon their scheme last month to charge customers excessive amounts for using cash machines. Some of the banks were planning to charge £1 a time for ordinary withdrawals, plus a 'disloyalty fee' of up to £1.50, despite the fact that Don Cruickshank, the special investigator, had said that the real cost of a transaction was between 15p and 30p. Second, the high street banks have proved much tardier in responding to the public interest than they do to the interest of shareholders. They have been very lukewarm in their response to the government's request to collaborate with the Post Office to set up a bank for poorer people, particularly in rural areas suffering from bank closures.

Until the banks show a more public-spirited approach, they cannot expect to to be allowed to merge with whom they like, when they like. Barclays' proposed merger with Woolwich is at least a 'friendly' one. But if it succeeds, it will trigger a new round of mergers not just of small former building societies like Alliance & Leicester and Northern Rock, but giants like Halifax and Abbey National as well. Last week, while parliament was in recess, the government rejected a recommendation from the Cruickshank inquiry to refer all banking mergers automatically to the authorities. That must not stop the government from referring this one, if it goes ahead. An inquiry is needed to establish the conditions for allowing future mergers - especially as there could be a flood of them.

fields.headline: Wall Street attacks disclosure rule
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: US regulators yesterday outlawed the selective disclosure of financial information to analysts or institutional shareholders, a move hailed as a victory for individual investors.
fields.body:
US regulators yesterday outlawed the selective disclosure of financial information to analysts or institutional shareholders, a move hailed as a victory for individual investors. Arthur Levitt, chairman of the securities and exchange commission, said the new Regulation FD (fair disclosure) would "bring all investors, regardless of the size of their holdings, into the information loop - where they belong".

"If investors see a stock's price change dramatically but are given access to critical market-moving information only much later, we risk nothing less than the public's faith and confidence in America's capital markets," he added.

Senior company officials will be forced to publicise any material information given to investors or analysts in a private meeting. Wall Street condemned the new rule, which comes into effect in 60 days' time.

The Securities Industry Association argued that it would deter companies from saying anything for fear of breaching the rule. Stuart Kaswell, general counsel for the association, said: "This regulation is well-intentioned but will actually hurt rather than help the investing public. Analysts should be allowed to ferret out information on behalf of investors."

The association also criticised modifications allowing executives to talk to the media, ratings agencies and suppliers. Mr Levitt criticised the relationship between corporate America and Wall Street: "As analysts play an increasingly visible role in recommending stocks, some in corporate management treat material information as a commodity - a way to gain and maintain favour with particular analysts."

fields.headline: Barclays ties up merger
fields.standfirst:
Top-tier shake-up to accompany Woolwich deal
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Matt Barrett, chief executive of Barclays, is expected to use today's confirmation of his £5.5bn acquisition of Woolwich to shake out his top management team. The takeover announcement is also expected to be accompanied by acknowledgement that some Woolwich branches face closure as a result.
fields.body:
Matt Barrett, chief executive of Barclays, is expected to use today's confirmation of his £5.5bn acquisition of Woolwich to shake out his top management team. The takeover announcement is also expected to be accompanied by acknowledgement that some Woolwich branches face closure as a result.

Mindful of the furore surrounding its own branch closure earlier this year, Barclays is expected to say that only branches on the same high streets around the country will close. Woolwich customers will be able to use Barclays branches and vice-versa. The bank is also expected to assure staff that any redundancy programme will be kept to a minimum.

John Stewart, Woolwich's chief executive who is expected to be named deputy chief executive of the combined organisation, has already taken out a layer of the former building society's middle management. Barclays already has its own job reduction programme in train. As well as naming Mr Stewart to the bank's main board, Mr Barrett, who took the helm of Barclays in October, is expected to use the acquisition as a way to "invigorate" his management structure.

Speculation about the long-term future of John Varley, chief executive of the retail financial services arm, and Chris Lendrum, chief executive of the corporate banking business, was mounting last night. The value of the offer by Barclays, which is paying 164p in cash and 0.1175 of its own shares for each Woolwich share, fell yesterday as its shares continued to slide. Just before sketchy details of the negotiations were released earlier this week, the offer valued each Woolwich share at 362p but by last night the value of the offer had fallen to 349p, against the Woolwich closing price of 337.5p.

The failure of the Woolwich shares to break through the value of Barclays bid was regarded as indication that investors did not expect another bank to produce a higher offer. Other banks, notably Alliance & Leicester and Northern Rock, are, however, regarded as potential takeover targets.

As the finishing touches were being put to the Woolwich takeover, another former building society, Abbey National, announced a deal with the National Union of Students to offer an interest-free overdraft during the years of study.

webTitle: Brierley opens campaign against iX marriage

fields.headline: Brierley opens campaign against iX marriage
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Stockbroking company Guinness Peat last night launched a high-profile "vote no" campaign against the stock exchange's plans to merge with its Frankfurt rival, claiming that its shareholders were getting a worse deal than their German counterparts.
fields.body:
Stockbroking company Guinness Peat last night launched a high-profile "vote no" campaign against the stock exchange's plans to merge with its Frankfurt rival, claiming that its shareholders were getting a worse deal than their German counterparts.

In a strongly worded letter to the stock exchange chairman, Don Cruickshank, Guinness Peat's chairman, Sir Ron Brierley, described the London bourse's attempts to explain the proposed link as "dross, notable for significant omissions and deficiencies". Sir Ron, who has had a tempestuous relationship with the stock exchange over many years, said he would be "actively urging other shareholders" to follow his firm's lead next month and vote against the plans to merge London and Frankfurt to create iX.

His call comes at a delicate time in the attempts by the exchange's management to win backing for the plan, which has been dogged by controversy over details. Most of the criticisms have come from smaller stockbrokers anxious about the cost of the deal and plans to move the market for smaller stocks to Frankfurt, leaving London with the so-called blue-chip market. It also follows anxieties raised by the Fund Management Association regarding possible distortions to share prices which might be generated as a result of the proposed structure of iX.

Sir Ron's attack on the London exchange is based on his belief that it is "beyond comprehension" that the creation of the iX market could be described as a "merger of equals". Concerned that shareholders in the London exchange - of which Guinness Peat owns 1% - were getting a raw deal, Sir Ron urged the stock exchange to pay out a dividend of £10 per share to rectify the inconsistency. A more logical preparation for a deal with the German exchange would be for the London exchange to complete a full listing on the stock market, he said. Guinness Peat received 100,000 shares when the stock exchange completed its demutualisation last month and bought another 150,000 shares from rivals to boost its bargaining power. The firm believes the shares are undervalued, blaming the exchange for failing to give a clear indication of future policy if the planned marriage with the German market fails. Mr Cruickshank, who is newly installed at the London exchange, retorted last night that Sir Ron was raising nothing new. "His analysis fails to to take into account the prospects of the different business components - in particular that Deutsche Borse has a successful derivatives business and highly marketable technology services business." Old Mutual, the South African-owned company that has most votes at the exchange, insisted last night that it not decided in which direction to exercise that vote.

webTitle: Users log on less to iii

fields.headline: Users log on less to iii
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Shares in Interactive Investor (iii) plunged 12% yesterday after analysts warned that the company faced an uncertain financial future following publication of the internet site's third-quarter results.
fields.body:
Shares in Interactive Investor (iii) plunged 12% yesterday after analysts warned that the company faced an uncertain financial future following publication of the internet site's third-quarter results.

Despite the online personal finance site announcing that it had over 1m accounts - making it Britain's biggest financial services site - many analysts doubted that the company could break even before 2004. "The future is very uncertain and our recommendation is to avoid the stock like the plague.

They have a lot of cash but they are going to eat through it quite rapidly and get really no return for their investment", said one analyst who refused to be named. The analyst put the uncertainty down to a volatile market and the lack of people interested in buying financial products online. The shares fell 6.5p to 46p.

However the company remained bullish. Results for the last three months ended June 30 showed revenues of £1.8m, exactly the same as the second quarter, but up from £721,000 in the same period a year ago. Tomas Carruthers, chief executive, said the results were in line with expectations and he was confident about the future. He said: "We have the largest customer franchise in the UK and we are able to build our services."

Average monthly page impressions, which had been falling 10% a month, were at 45.5m, while transaction related revenues fell £250,000 from the last quarter to £430,000.

Tomas Carruthers, chief executive, said the results were in line with expectations and he was confident about the future. He said: "We have the largest customer franchise in the UK and we are able to build our services." Average monthly page impressions, which had been falling 10% a month, were at 45.5m, while transaction related revenues fell £250,000 from the last quarter to £430,000.

fields.headline: Woolwich bosses back Barclays bid
fields.standfirst: 1,000 jobs lost
fields.trailText: 1,000 jobs lost
fields.body:
Barclays bank today made a recommended offer for Woolwich, valuing the former building society at £5.4bn.

The announcement comes two days after the banks revealed they were in talks which could lead to a takeover.

Barclay's bid, which will be unanimously recommended by Woolwich's board, values each Woolwich share at 352p. Yesterday they closed at 337.5p.

Sir Brian Jenkins, Woolwich chairman, said: "This is a great deal for both Barclays and Woolwich shareholders.

"From the Woolwich we bring our popular brand, innovation and highly successful management team to join in this exciting venture.

"Combined with Barclays' strengths, we can all go forward changing the nature of retail banking in the United Kingdom."

Sir Peter Middleton, chairman of Barclays, said: "The acquisition of Woolwich is a key step for Barclays in developing its UK retail financial services business with a commercial fit which is highly complementary."

However, the deal will impact on jobs and branch numbers, as Barclays aims to make cost savings of at least £150m a year by the end of the third year following the takeover.

Part of the savings will be achieved by closing 100 branches from the combined group over the next three years, slimming branch numbers to 2,000.

About 1,000 staff will also be cut from the enlarged group.

The bank said the cut would be achieved through natural wastage and voluntary redundancy, wherever possible.

Woolwich has more than 6,000 staff in the UK, operating from more than 400 branches, while Barclays employs more than 50,000 UK staff in 1,700 branches.

Barclays aims to make head office cost savings by integrating the two bank's human resources and finance functions.

It will keep Woolwich's base at Bexleyheath, Kent, following the deal, which it said would be a "significant centre of employment".

Other cost savings would be achieved by integrating overseas operations, making savings from call centres, from IT systems and from the combination of mortgage processing and general insurance operations.

Both bank brands, including separate Barclays and Woolwich branches, will be kept following the deal, and Woolwich will become the group's mortgage brand.

fields.headline: Villa say Southgate was tapped
fields.trailText: John Gregory has accused Chelsea of making an illegal approach for Gareth Southgate.
fields.body:
John Gregory has accused Chelsea of making an illegal approach for Gareth Southgate.

"Without any shadow of doubt he has been tapped," the Aston Villa manager said yesterday. "They have had a word in his ear and now it's difficult to focus on the job in hand."

Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchinson denies the allegation. "It's not our style to tap players," he said yesterday.

In any event Southgate appears unlikely to leave, partly because Villa are not willing to let him go for the kind of money Chelsea are offering and partly because he cannot play another game in European competition this season after appearing for Villa in the Intertoto Cup semi-final second leg against Celta Vigo.

Chelsea have made three bids for the England defender. The £5m they offered, Gregory said, would "probably buy his right leg". The bid was raised to £6m before the Celta game.

"It was impossible to have a dialogue with them about it," Hutchinson said. "They won't put a price on him and the situation is at a stalemate."

"They should pay the right amount," Gregory said, "or just leave the kid alone."

Chelsea will hold on to Gianfranco Zola, in whom Napoli have expressed an interest, and will not make a move for Steve McManaman, who has been told he is surplus to requirements at Real Madrid.

"Although he is a great player," Hutchinson said, "there is no way that we could fit him in to play in his preferred role at the present time."

Aston Villa have been given one of the byes into the third round of the Worthington Cup, along with the six Premiership clubs who have qualified for European competition.

Leicester City have told Celtic to raise their bid for Neil Lennon from £6.5m to £8m. Yet they remain confident that they can hold on to the Northern Ireland midfielder.

Lennon has indicated that he will make up his mind this week. "It's a difficult time for Neil," the Leicester manager Peter Taylor said yesterday. "But I am still quietly confident that Neil Lennon will line up against Aston Villa in the first game of the season."

Sir Alex Ferguson appears unsympathetic to Mark Bosnich's decision to stay and fight for his first-team place at Manchester United.

"I think Fabien Barthez is the best goalkeeper in the world," Ferguson said. "He has personality and character and he has been absolutely outstanding since he joined us, so obviously I'm going to play him."

webTitle: Rangers take bite out of Danish

fields.headline: Rangers take bite out of Danish
fields.standfirst: Albertz 28, Wallace 31, Amoruso 60
fields.trailText:
Herfoelge 0 - 3 Rangers
Rangers look almost certain to be competing in the all-important first group stage of the Champions League after a convincing victory in Denmark yesterday made the second leg, to be played in Glagow in two weeks, a virtual formality.
fields.body:
Rangers look almost certain to be competing in the all-important first group stage of the Champions League after a convincing victory in Denmark yesterday made the second leg, to be played in Glagow in two weeks, a virtual formality.

Last season the Scottish champions had to beat the expensively assembled Italian side Parma at the same stage. Herfoelge, coached by the former Arsenal midfielder John Jensen, were surprising winners of the Danish title last season but rarely posed a credible threat as they made their Champions League debut.

Indeed, while Rangers took a 2-0 lead into the break, their hosts took until the second half to have a shot on goal. Even that, a 20-yard effort from Jesper Falck, barely troubled Stefan Klos, the Rangers goalkeeper.

After a nervous opening, Jakup Mikkelsen in the home goal became increasingly besieged, saving notably from Billy Dodds and watching Jörg Albertz, Rod Wallace and Lorenzo Amoruso send efforts narrowly wide. He was eventually beaten when Albertz struck a vicious, swerving shot from distance which he seemed to misjudge.

A minute later Dodds met Wallace's cross but sent his effort wide. Wallace proved less profligate when he met a Giovanni van Bronckhorst centre from similar range after half an hour

Rangers started the second half determined to build on their lead, and Amoruso duly scored their third goal with a powerful drive from Albertz's short free-kick on 59 minutes.

But there were some nervous moments to come before the game's end, as Klos was twice called into action in the final minutes, palming over Tommy Schram's shot and then producing a magnificent one-handed save to keep out Jesper Jakobsen's header.

But in truth Rangers outclassed their opponents, something they will find a great deal harder to do as the competition enters its next phase.

Herfoelge: Mikkelsen; Lustu, Jacobsen, Lykke, K Jensen, Hoyer, Falck, Hermansen, Schramm, Kastrup, Thomsen. Substitutes: Udengaard, J Jensen, Jakobsen, Henriksen, Heyde, Abel, Knudsen.

Rangers: Klos; Porrini, Konterman, Amoruso, Reyna, Ferguson, McCann, Van Bronckhorst, Albertz, Dodds, Wallace. Substitutes: Brown, Tugay, Kanchelskis, Ricksen, Johnston, Miller, Vidmar.

Referee: Lubomir Pucek (Poland).

fields.headline: Nimes rage over Arsenal 'abduction'
fields.trailText: Arsenal have once again been heavily criticised for signing another French youngster in controversial circumstances.
fields.body:
Arsenal have once again been heavily criticised for signing another French youngster in controversial circumstances.

This week Arsenal's manager Arsène Wenger clinched the transfer of Guy Demel, a midfielder who had been with Nimes. When the time recently came for the 19-year-old to turn professional he opted to move to Highbury rather than sign for the club who had invested time and money in his development.

Arsenal took advantage of French regulations that allow trainees to skip the obligatory first contract with their club of origin if they move abroad.

Nmes's director of football, Pierre Mosca, blamed Arsenal for enticing the player. "I find it revolting that a so-called big club such as Arsenal uses such procedures to attract young players," he said. "This is not a transfer deal - it is an abduction. If Demel goes on to play first-team football in the next two seasons I will have a fit."

He said that Nimes's future depended on developing and selling players like Demel, who is likened to Patrick Vieira in terms of physique and style of play and whom Nimes signed from an amateur club in Marseille a year ago. "We need to sell a player every year in order to survive, which is why three of our best youngsters have recently left us. But we won't get a centime for Demel."

This is not the first time that Arsenal have been criticised for signing French youngsters. Three years ago Paris St-Germain were upset with the London club for signing Nicolas Anelka, then 17, for £500,000 and made £23m profit when they sold him two years later. PSG have since paid a similar amount to bring him back.

In January 1999 Wenger almost caused a diplomatic incident when he signed the 15-year-old France Under-17 striker Jérémie Aliadière on a £1.3m, seven-year contract. At that point he had not completed his time at France's national academy, and the authorities threatened to take the case to the European Parliament.

However, though Arsenal's tactics may be questionable, they do not break any rules. Indeed the Nimes coach Bernard Boissier, who oversaw Demel's development, blamed his club for losing the player.

"Guy is right to right to try his luck with Arsenal," he said. "They are a prestigious club. We knew what the rules are but we just didn't have the sense to keep him. We were too slack - he would have stayed with us had we given him more first-team opportunities."

Crystal Palace have signed the Arsenal goalkeeper Stuart Taylor on a month's loan. The 19-year-old was on loan at Bristol Rovers last season.

Paulo Wanchope, 24, has completed his move to Manchester City, who paid a club record £3.65m to West Ham. The Costa Rican striker signed a five-year contract.

The Maine Road club, whose reserve striker Lee Peacock has agreed terms with Bristol City for a £600,000 move, have confirmed that they have withdrawn from the bidding for Ugo Ehiogu after Aston Villa rejected a £7.5m offer.

fields.headline: European  round-up
fields.trailText: Two goals from Mario Jardel gave the Uefa Cup holders Galatasaray a 2-1 win over the Swiss champions St Gallen in the first leg of their Champions League third qualifying round match.
fields.body:
Two goals from Mario Jardel gave the Uefa Cup holders Galatasaray a 2-1 win over the Swiss champions St Gallen in the first leg of their Champions League third qualifying round match.

St Gallen took the lead in the 14th minute when Charles Amoah caught the Galatasaray keeper Claudio Taffarel off his line. The Ghanaian striker came close again 20 minutes later.

But the unmarked Brazilian striker Jardel headed the Turkish side's equaliser in the 39th minute. The unfancied Swiss side had most of the chances in the second half but Jardel gave Galatasaray the lead after 78 minutes, sliding the ball through the Swiss defence.

St Gallen finished with 10 men after Giuseppe Mazzarelli was sent off for a second bookable offence in the closing minutes.

In the run-up to the match Swiss police had searched Galatasaray's hotel following an anonymous bomb threat. They found nothing.

Dynamo Kiev and Yugoslavia's Red Star Belgrade drew 0-0 last night in a Champions League qualifier that the Ukrainians dominated. However, Red Star came close to snatching victory in the 88th minute when Valentin Belkevich hit the bar.

Also in Ukraine, Tomas Dosek grabbed a late goal to give the Czech runners-up Slavia Prague a 1-0 away victory over Shakhtar Donetsk in their Champions League qualifier.

Authorities in Milan arrested nine Croatian fans yesterday and held another 60 for questioning after they pelted passers-by and police with bottles and chairs before a Champions League qualifier between Dinamo Zagreb and Milan, won 3-1 by Milan. Police said at least four people were injured.

The Sturm Graz striker Gerald Strafner was shown a red card yesterday - a day after he should have received it for two bookings in Tuesday's Champions League qualifier against Feyenoord.

Uefa's disciplinary commission had issued the red card after the Norwegian referee Terje Hauge admitted having forgotten to send Strafner off in the first leg of the third qualifying round match which Sturm won 2-1. The mistake came four minutes into injury-time.

fields.headline: Bradford bet on Carbone
fields.standfirst: City demand goals as Italian signs for £6m over four years
fields.trailText: Bradford City demand goals as Benito Carbone signs for £6m over four years.
fields.body:
In a move that smacked as much of desperation as ambition Bradford City unveiled Benito Carbone yesterday amid scenes of near-hysteria at Valley Parade.

As if to provide moral support against a cynical media, the City chairman Geoffrey Richmond invited fans to the press conference to welcome the highest-paid player in Bradford's history. Around 200 duly crammed into the Bantams Lounge of City's Carlsberg stand, chanting the player's name and hailing what is, only nine days before the start of the season, the bravest transfer gamble of the summer.

Carbone, formerly of Internazionale, Sheffield Wednesday and Aston Villa, signed a £6m four-year contract, incorporating a £2m signing-on fee. He put pen to paper after a night of deliberations among the chairman, the player and his agent.

"Although this is my last contract, money isn't the most important thing," the Italian forward insisted. "What is important is that the club want and trust me. That is what they made clear last night. That's why I came here."

"We had some options in the Premiership, not just one," said Giovanni Branchini, the player's agent. "There was also the possibility to wait a bit longer and try to go back to Italy, which was Benito's original idea. But the task force from Bradford that came to Italy was very effective and touched the right strings."

Presumably he was not referring to purse strings. For Richmond, who had already lost out on signing Paulo Wanchope from West Ham and had left City fans on tenterhooks when he claimed on Monday that he was on the verge of making "the most exciting signing in the history of the club", the completion of the deal clearly came as a relief.

After a night of u-turns befitting the Italian's tetchy reputation, and with speculation rife that Coventry were poised to pip Bradford City at the post, a telephone call in the early hours from Branchini persuaded Richmond to cancel his 7.30am flight home.

"It was the longest night," he said. "At around two in the morning I thought the deal was dead. But we got the call at 4am and, by 9am, Benito had slept on it and decided to commit his future to Bradford.

"We've had to look at the total financial package. Benito was available on a Bosman free, so we have worked out the total cost of the deal over four years without a transfer fee. We sit comfortably with the package we've negotiated."

Carbone's ability to command such a wage is all the more surprising given his reputation off the pitch and inconsistency on it since he joined Sheffield Wednesday from Internazionale for £3m in 1996. He left Wednesday under a cloud last season having fallen out with the manager Danny Wilson.

A protracted loan spell at Aston Villa followed. It featured the odd spectacular goal - he scored only three in the Premiership and eight in all - the occasional tantrum and the acrimonious rejection of a £25,000-a-week deal to remain in the west midlands.

"What happened at Villa wasn't my fault," Carbone insisted. "I wanted to stay there but they did not contact either me or my agents over the summer."

Though there were tentative approaches from Perugia and his former club Napoli, Italian interest was lukewarm. But the Bradford City chairman was not put off by Carbone's chequered past. "We didn't need persuading to sign Benito," he added. "We were desperately anxious to sign him. He's come here for all the right reasons. He's going to be a hero and a superstar here."

Though Carbone has scored only 35 goals in his four seasons in England, the City manager Chris Hutchings is convinced that he has solved his side's goalscoring problem. "I think he's a 20-goal striker," he said. "We've got a fantastic player who can score unbelievable goals. That has to be exciting."

Earlier in the day the Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson unveiled his own prospective goalscoring hero in the £2.5m Croatian international Alen Boksic.

Robson was quick to deny that the 30-year-old striker had moved to Teesside purely for financial reasons. "Finance has not played a major part in this," he said. "I tried to sign him a few years ago but he was not ready to leave Rome then.

"He knew that I wanted him here and that was the main factor. He wants the challenge now. He knows of our reputation, which is growing in Europe. This signing helps that process."

Robson denied that the Croatian would earn almost £63,000 a week at the Riverside but it is likely the striker will still pick up a weekly wage of nearly £40,000 - that for a player who has only once scored 10 goals in a Serie A season and has struggled with knee problems.

"It is less tactical here than in Italy," Boksic said. "There is far more space and my speed will be a big advantage."

Transfer timetable

Monday Bradford's chairman Geoffrey Richmond announces that the club are set to make the "the most exciting signing" in their history.

Tuesday 10am: Carbone fails to arrive at Leeds/Bradford airport despite having agreed in principal to sign a four-year deal. Bradford City representatives fly to Milan to continue talks.

Evening: Coventry City emerge as the favourites to sign Carbone as a replacement for Robbie Keane.

Yesterday 2am: Carbone rejects Bradford's £30,000-a-week offer.

4am: His agent Giovanni Branchini calls Richmond and arranges fresh talks at 9am.

5pm: Carbone is unveiled at Valley Parade having signed a four-year deal worth around £6m.

It featured the odd spectacular goal - he scored only three in the Premiership and eight in all - the occasional tantrum and the acrimonious rejection of a £25,000-a-week deal to remain in the west midlands. "What happened at Villa wasn't my fault," Carbone insisted. "I wanted to stay there but they did not contact either me or my agents over the summer." Though there were tentative approaches from Perugia and his former club Napoli, Italian interest was lukewarm. But the Bradford City chairman was not put off by Carbone's chequered past. "We didn't need persuading to sign Benito," he added. "We were desperately anxious to sign him. He's come here for all the right reasons. He's going to be a hero and a superstar here." Though Carbone has scored only 35 goals in his four seasons in England, the City manager Chris Hutchings is convinced that he has solved his side's goalscoring problem. "I think he's a 20-goal striker," he said. "We've got a fantastic player who can score unbelievable goals. That has to be exciting." Earlier in the day the Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson unveiled his own prospective goalscoring hero in the £2.5m Croatian international Alen Boksic. Robson was quick to deny that the 30-year-old striker had moved to Teesside purely for financial reasons. "Finance has not played a major part in this," he said. "I tried to sign him a few years ago but he was not ready to leave Rome then. "He knew that I wanted him here and that was the main factor. He wants the challenge now. He knows of our reputation, which is growing in Europe. This signing helps that process." Robson denied that the Croatian would earn almost £63,000 a week at the Riverside but it is likely the striker will still pick up a weekly wage of nearly £40,000 - that for a player who has only once scored 10 goals in a Serie A season and has struggled with knee problems. "It is less tactical here than in Italy," Boksic said. "There is far more space and my speed will be a big advantage." Transfer timetable Monday Bradford's chairman Geoffrey Richmond announces that the club are set to make the "the most exciting signing" in their history. Tuesday 10am: Carbone fails to arrive at Leeds/Bradford airport despite having agreed in principal to sign a four-year deal. Bradford City representatives fly to Milan to continue talks. Evening: Coventry City emerge as the favourites to sign Carbone as a replacement for Robbie Keane. Yesterday 2am: Carbone rejects Bradford's £30,000-a-week offer. 4am: His agent Giovanni Branchini calls Richmond and arranges fresh talks at 9am. 5pm: Carbone is unveiled at Valley Parade having signed a four-year deal worth around £6m.

webTitle: Trescothick weighs in before rush of run-outs

fields.headline: Trescothick weighs in before rush of run-outs
fields.standfirst: Somerset Sabres 223 v Gloucestershire Gladiators
fields.trailText: Somerset Sabres 223 v Gloucestershire Gladiators
fields.body:
Courtney Walsh or Michael Cawdron, they all come the same to Marcus Trescothick. England's man of the moment returned to his county and made a 59-ball half-century studded with eight cleanly struck boundaries, forcing Cawdron out of the attack with chastening figures of 6-0-40-0.

It was hard to see how Gloucestershire would dismiss Trescothick but they did not have to as Somerset effectively did it for them. There looked to be two when Trescothick pushed Martyn Ball firmly to deep mid-wicket but his captain Jamie Cox did not think so and left his partner stranded halfway down the pitch.

Cox later ran himself out, wandering down the wicket after surviving a leg-before appeal from Tim Hancock as Somerset did their best to squander the start provided by Trescothick and Mark Lathwell. They had put on 79 in the first 15 overs but Gloucestershire's captain Mark Alleyne then brought himself on to good effect.

Alleyne has not been bowling much because of a back problem but he had Lathwell lbw for a sprightly 37 in his second over. Ian Blackwell was promoted to No3 but edged Alleyne's next ball, with Jack Russell diving in front of Ball at slip to take a one-handed catch. Cox averted the hat-trick but Alleyne had Peter Bowler caught behind in a second spell for figures of three for 36.

Somerset's other England returnee, Andy Caddick, was a third run-out victim as wickets fell regularly, and unintelligently, through the second- half of their innings. He hesitated over a second run to long off and was beaten by Hancock's direct hit.

Cawdron bowled a much better second spell and, with James Averis providing the usual mixed bag, this was a typically efficient Gloucestershire performance in the field, clawing back an unpromising situation and giving the home supporters in a crowd of around 6,000 something other than free Scrumpy Jack to take their minds off the drizzle.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Neil Killeen struck two vital blows for Durham on the first dayof their crucial championship First Division relegation battle against Kent at Chester-le-Street.
fields.body:
Neil Killeen struck two vital blows for Durham on the first dayof their crucial championship First Division relegation battle against Kent at Chester-le-Street.

The fast bowler was quick to make up for lost time - rain had prevented any play until 4pm and there was another short break for bad light - trapping the Indian Test opener Rahul Dravid lbw for seven and then having the opener David Fulton caught at second slip for 27 as Kent struggled to 71 for three off 32 overs at the close.

Kent had been put in after their captain Matthew Fleming had lost the toss for the seventh successive championship game.

The visitors were in trouble from the start with Fulton edging Simon Brown's first ball just short of second slip. Robert Key was not so lucky 12 balls later. Fulton drove straight at Brown and the ball deflected off the bowler's boot into the stumps at the non-striker's end with Key out of his ground.

Bad light then halted proceedings and four overs into the resumption Dravid fell and Killeen's movement off the seam then claimed Fulton.

Ed Smith and Matthew Walker steadied the innings although both survived difficult chances during an unbroken stand of 20.

Lancashire were skittled out for 68 in the roses match in the National League First Division day-night at Headingley and Yorkshire cruised to a nine-wicket victory.

The Australian Test player Darren Lehmann, who was acting captain in the absence of the injured David Byas, steered his side home with an unbeaten 54, Yorkshire reaching 72 for one in 13.5 overs.

Earlier Matthew Hoggard had given the England selectors a nudge with a fine spell that yielded three for 15 while Craig White maintained his form from the third Test with four for 14. Lancashire's total would have been lower but for Andy Flintoff, who hit their top score of 28.

Graham Thorpe hit 62 as the Second Division leaders Surrey defeated Warwickshire by 103 runs at Whitgift in Croydon, south London. Thorpe then featured in stands of more than 40 with Alistair Brown (16) and Hollioake (21) to put the home side in command.

Surrey's total of 211 proved well beyond Warwickshire and they were all out for 108 with Alex Tudor and Saqulain Mushtaq each taking two wickets.

South Africa have given themselves an outside chance of achieving a series winning victory in the third Test against Sri Lanka in Colombo, although much will depend on Lance Klusener who is 27 not out.

They ended a rain-affected fourth day leading by 178 runs with five second innings wickets remaining. They had started the day slowly on 27 and had moved to 157 for five from 77 overs, with Jonty Rhodes making 54, before rain wiped out the final session.

Muthiah Muralitharan kept Sri Lanka in the contest, taking the wickets of Kirsten (40), Daryll Cullinan (three) and Rhodes to finish with figures of three for 41.

fields.headline: Lung cancer deaths halved
fields.standfirst: Britain sets example to the world, say researchers
fields.trailText: Britain has had the world's largest fall in premature deaths from lung cancer thanks to the drive to help smokers give up, according to a study reported in the British Medical Journal.
fields.body:
Britain has had the world's largest fall in premature deaths from lung cancer thanks to the drive to help smokers give up, according to a study in the British Medical Journal.

Lung cancer deaths have halved since 1965, mainly due to a reduction in the number of people who smoke. The findings come when, looking worldwide, deaths from tobacco related illnesses are increasing.

Researchers said that Britain should be held up as an example, although they stressed that smoking was still the biggest cause of premature death; half of all smokers would eventually be killed by their habit.

However, smokers who stopped, even in middle age, reduced significantly the risk of premature death; and those who stopped before middle age were at little higher risk than non-smokers.

The report was written by Sir Richard Doll, a professor emeritus of medicine at Oxford University, who 50 years ago was one of the first to link lung cancer with smoking, and by Sir Richard Peto of the Imperial Cancer Research Fund's Oxford unit, who is also an Oxford professor.

Prof Doll said: "Our 1950 study showed that smoking was a cause of most of the lung cancer in Britain at that time, and our new study shows that widespread cessation of smoking has halved the number of lung cancer deaths that would otherwise be occurring in Britain in 2000."

Annual tobacco sales in real terms fell from £150bn in 1965 to £80bn in 1995 in the UK, the researchers found. By 1998 the death rate for men aged 35-54 had more than halved to 17.4.

But smoking was still the biggest cause of premature death in Britain, with 6m tobacco-related deaths over the past 50 years. And worldwide it is predicted that in the 21st century 1bn will die from smoking.

Prof Peto said: "There are still 10m smokers in Britain, and about 5m will be killed by tobacco if they don't stop.

"Tobacco deaths over the next 50 years will be affected much more by the number of adults who manage to stop than by the number of adolescents who start smoking."

Clive Bates, the director of the anti-smoking charity Action on Smoking and Health, said: "The message from this is that no one should ever think it is too late to quit."

 Philip Morris, the world's largest cigarette company, admitted last week that it had paid scientists to attend World Health Organisation meetings but said it had done nothing improper to influence the United Nations body.

The admission came after a report by the WHO accused tobacco companies of trying to subvert international attempts to control smoking over the past two decades through an "elaborate, well financed, sophisticated and usually invisible" campaign.

webTitle: Memories of the Invincibles and six sixes

fields.headline: Memories of the Invincibles and six sixes
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: My Dad's earliest memory of cricket was peering over a wall in Edinburgh to see the Australians playing in 1948 (a very long time ago). Can you tell me any more about that game? asks Ben
fields.body:
My Dad's earliest memory of cricket was peering over a wall in Edinburgh to see the Australians playing in 1948 (a very long time ago). Can you tell me any more about that game? asks Ben

This match was played on September 13-14, 1948, and was the penultimate match of the "Invincible" Australians' unbeaten tour. The Australians made 236: Arthur Morris scored 112, and Don Bradman a comparatively modest 27. Scotland were bowled out for 85 (Bill Johnston 6-15) and 111 (Morris 5-10) as the tourists won by an innings and 40 runs. The last game of the tour, also against Scotland, was played at Aberdeen: the Australians won by an innings again, and Bradman marked his final appearance on British soil with 123 not out.

Many years ago, when I was living in Swansea, I met Malcolm Nash, the bowler hit for six sixes in an over by Garry Sobers. When was that match? And has the feat been duplicated since? asks Bruce Bradley from Wisconsin, USA

That famous match took place at Swansea in 1968. Sobers was playing for Nottinghamshire, and Nash for Glamorgan. Nash, usually a left-arm fast bowler, was experimenting with slower spinners at the time. Sobers was looking for quick runs before a declaration, and was hitting out. He was nearly out off the fifth ball, but the long-off fielder, Roger Davis, fell over the boundary after catching the ball and it was given as a six.

Nash nearly suffered a repeat performance at Swansea nine years later, when Lancashire's Frank Hayes hit him for 34 in an over (the second ball went for four, the other five for sixes). Sobers's feat wasn't matched in first-class cricket until 1984-85, when Bombay's Ravi Shastri, the Indian Test allrounder, hit Tilak Raj of Baroda for six sixes in an over during a Ranji Trophy match at Bombay.

Using one home umpire in Tests is harming cricket's image - he makes his presence felt in every series. When will ICC start appointing two third-country umpires? asks Shahid from Pakistan

I agree that they should do it now, but the problem is one of cost. Until recently the international umpires' panel was sponsored (by the British electricity company National Grid), but that contract has finished and ICC are looking for new sponsors. Let's hope that the new one will cough up enough money to send two umpires to each Test match Ð or that ICC, which has just sold the broadcasting rights to the next two World Cups for a reported $US500million, will stump up themselves.

I started following the recent European Cricket Championship in the newspapers, then the details mysteriously stopped appearing. Who won? asks RJ Gibbs

This tournament was held in Scotland between July 21 and 27. Twelve countries took part, in two divisions. Holland were the eventual champions - they won all five of their matches. What turned out to be the vital game was Holland's match against the ECB XI - the England amateur side - which the Dutch won by six wickets. Gibraltar won the second division title, with Germany second.

What's the worst injury anyone has ever sustained in a cricket match? asks Kashaf Ali

I suppose the worst that could happen would be that someone is killed by the ball. Fortunately this doesn't happen very often. The most recent case involving a prominent player was in February 1998, when Raman Lamba, the former Indian Test batsman, was hit on the head while fielding in a club match in Bangladesh, and died shortly afterwards.

The most macabre scorecard entry in a first-class match came in Pakistan's Quaid-e-Azam Trophy final in 1958-59. The week after he'd been at the other end when Hanif Mohammad was run out for 499 in the semi-final, Karachi's wicketkeeper Abdul Aziz was hit on the chest by an innocuous-looking ball from Combined Services offspinner Dildar Awan. He collapsed at the crease and died on the way to hospital (he turned out to have a weak heart). He's recorded as 'retired hurt 0' in the first innings and 'absent dead' in the second.

I'm trying to finish a crossword, and am stuck on a cricket clue: who took nine wickets for Pakistan against England at Lahore in 1987-88? asks Barry Michaels

It was Abdul Qadir, Pakistan's fiery legspinner, in the first Test of what turned into a contentious series (Mike Gatting, the England captain, had a famous spat with the umpire Shakoor Rana in the second Test). On an underprepared pitch Qadir was soon into the attack, and England were bowled out on the first day for 175. Qadir sent down 37 overs and, helped by some undistinguished umpiring, took 9 for 56. He took four more wickets in the second innings as Pakistan won by an innings: it was the only result of the series.

How can you order the Wisden Almanack Millennium Edition from the United States? asks Dr Roger Pulwarty

The 2000 edition of Wisden Cricketers' Almanack (with the free paperback, 'A Century Of Wisden') can be bought by mail order in the USA from Penguin Putnam consumer sales dept., telephone 800 788 6262, quoting the ISBN reference 094776657X.

In the UK it can be bought by mail order (quoting the same ISBN reference) from Penguin Direct, telephone 020 8757 4036. Penguin Direct will accept overseas orders, but will charge an extra £6.75 for airmail postage.

Look out for our guide on how to buy cricket books on the internet in the September issue of Wisden Cricket Monthly, on sale in some newsagents in the UK and Ireland on Friday 18th August, and in all of them on Monday 21st.

webTitle: Nasty Nick investigated over secret phone claim

fields.headline: Nasty Nick investigated over secret phone claim
fields.standfirst: Big Brother
fields.trailText: Producers of Channel 4's Big Brother series today launched an investigation into allegations that stockbroker Nicholas may have smuggled a tiny phone into the camera-filled house - giving him a link to the outside world.
fields.body:
Producers of Channel 4's Big Brother series today launched an investigation into allegations that stockbroker Nicholas may have smuggled a tiny phone into the camera-filled house - giving him a link to the outside world.

On joining the hit TV and internet experiment, all 10 original housemates were rigorously searched to ensure they had no means of contacting friends or viewers.

But now the surveillance show's makers are investigating a newspaper report that one contestant, Nicholas Bateman, 32, may have sneaked in a tiny Motorola mobile phone at the start.

According to today's Sun, an "associate" of Nick rang in to allege the City trader was receiving daily reports from a friend about his fellow contestants' views and the way he is perceived by the viewing public. Nicholas allegedly switches the phone, which he keeps inside his wash bag, on to vibrate alert at 4am each day while lying beneath his bed covers. When it goes off, he then listens intently to the latest report without speaking.

A spokeswoman for the show today confirmed producers were launching an initial investigation to identify the source of the rumours about Nicholas.

"We have so many rumours to contend with, because this is a big show, and we can't investigate every one," she said. "With this, we are looking into the source of the rumour first off, because we can't just jump straight into the house and start searching.

"It's unlikely that any of the contestants would have been able to smuggle anything in. They were searched thoroughly before they went in. They had their bags searched and individually photographed."

She added that no further action would be taken unless there was thought to be some substance to the allegations once their source had been contacted.

Since Big Brother went on air four weeks ago, Nicholas has become something of a cult TV villain in the eyes of many viewers, earning himself the nickname "Nasty Nick".

Thanks to 24-hour internet coverage of goings-on in the Big Brother house and weekday television highlights slots, addicts of the programme have seen him frequently playing his housemates off against each other. But despite his growing unpopularity among the public at large, Nicholas has yet to be nominated for one of the weekly evictions by any of his fellow contestants.

Earlier this week, Nicholas was seen confessing that he had lied to his housemates when he claimed early on in the nine-week experiment that his wife had been killed in a car crash.

Another member of the house, Craig Phillips, said before the contest if he wins he will donate the £70,000 prize money to a Downs Syndrome teenage girl from Shrewsbury who needs to travel to America for a life-saving operation.

Ladbrokes, the official bookmakers of the TV programme, said that the odds on Craig to be the last left in the house were 17/1. Only Nichola - at 26/1 - has longer odds for winning the two-month competition.

A spokesman for the company said: "Craig has been pretty unpopular with gamblers up to this point with most people backing Anna or Darren as the likely winners.

Sight and Sound magazine compiled a list of the 360 all-time classic films from around the world, from 1914 to 1981. The list was compiled by David Meeker, keeper of films at the National Film and Television Archive. Initially he drew up a list of 100 films, the aim being to build up a library of new show-prints for screening at the Museum of the Moving Image. But things got a little out of hand. Meeker says there is now a film for every day of the year - which there almost is, there being 362 films on the list. It is also a reference to the 360 degrees in a full circle (which it almost is, too). Why does the list end in 1981? Because, Meeker says, we need the distance of time to assess whether a film is a classic - and going to 1981 allowed him to include Mad Max 2
