webTitle: Belgrade: Diplomats permitted to see spy suspects

fields.headline: Diplomats permitted to see spy suspects
fields.trailText: British and Canadian diplomats in Belgrade gained access for the first time today to four of their citizens held by the Yugoslav army for more than a week in Montenegro.
fields.body:
British and Canadian diplomats in Belgrade gained access for the first time today to four of their citizens held by the Yugoslav army for more than a week in Montenegro.

Bob Gordon of Great Britain and Craig Bale of Canada, accompanied by lawyers, visited the detainees - two Britons and two Canadians - at the Belgrade military court, where the detainees have been under preliminary investigation for charges of attempted terrorism.

"They are healthy, they've been well treated and we were able to discuss their detention with them," Mr Bale said. "We are hopeful  that they will be released as soon as possible."

The Yugoslav army detained the four last week in Montenegro, near the border with Kosovo, after finding explosives-related material in their car. They have not yet been charged by the Belgrade military court, which is conducting a preliminary investigation to determine whether to formally indict them.

During a court hearing yesterday, the two Britons, Adrian Prangnell and John Yore, and the Canadians, Shaun Going, and his nephew, Liam Hall, denied any wrongdoing.

UN officials in Kosovo, where the four worked, have maintained they were returning from a brief holiday when they were captured. Serb officials, however, disagree.

Vojislav Seselj, the Serbian deputy prime minister and head of the ultra-nationalist Radical party, said there was no doubt the four were spies. "They are obviously spies and saboteurs. They had sabotage equipment with them and an investigation will determine what their aim was," he said.

"Whether they came here to carry out a sabotage with explosives, to kill or abduct someone or if their aim was to reach Radovan Karadzic and kidnap him."

Mr Karadzic is wanted by The Hague's ongoing war-crimes tribunal for war crimes during the Bosnian war.

Mr Bale said evidence presented so far at the military court proves that there is no ground for any charges. He added, however, the investigative procedure is continuing "in accordance with the Yugoslav law".

Djordje Djurisic, the lawyer for the two jailed Britons, has said that it would be at least a week or two before the military prosecutor decides whether to lay charges, but he said he remained optimistic.

"Then the matter will be sent to the military prosecutor. Based on the evidence now, we are hopeful for a successful and positive outcome," Mr Djurisic said.

Mr Gordon said the two Britons were "fine and in good health, and are looking forward to receiving some reading material". Mr Gordon said they had given him messages to relay to their families. If convicted, the four could face up to 15 years in prison.

Commenting on the detentions, Nikola Sainovic, a high-ranking Socialist party official and close aide to the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, said the matter was "very serious indeed."

"We take the matter as seriously as any other country would when it discovers foreign nationals - and members of a foreign military - with mine explosive devices to which they admit ownership," he said.

fields.headline: Stealing, Dealing and Appealing
fields.trailText: STEAL CITY
fields.body:
STEAL CITY

It is only a couple of years since Aston Villa could routinely saunter into the dressing room of any other Midlands club and make off with whichever player they fancied. Julian Joachim? We'll have it. Dion Dublin? Stuff that in this large bag. Steve Stone? Hmm... well, we may as well, there's enough room in the back of the van. But how times change! Villa have spent all summer trying to yank Neil Lennon away from Leicester, but to no avail: the midfielder today signed a new four-year contract at Filbert Street, leaving a masked John Gregory abjectly gripping his empty sack.

"I am looking forward to our first game against Aston Villa even more," chortled a smug Peter Taylor, who for some reason seemed to find the whole thing very amusing. "I am delighted that Neil has agreed to sign a new contract. He is one of the most important players at the club and I am delighted to have him on board," he continued as Gregory sped off in a getaway car, shaking his fist and swearing exotically.

It's certainly a coup for the Leicester boss, because his much-respected predecessor Martin O'Neill was also hoping to prise Lennon away to Celtic. Taylor talked the player round, however, and the offer of a £10,000-a-week pay rise can't have hindered his argument. "I felt very humble that they have made such a good offer to me," Lennon said today. "Now I simply want to get my head down and complete my preparations for what promises to be an interesting time in the Premiership and Uefa Cup," he announced, before a local security firm came in and fitted a burglar alarm onto his face.

FREE WITH MONDAY'S GUARDIAN - THE SEASON

It's a small book you'll want to keep all year round (but will sadly be rendered unreadable before the season even begins after you carelessly spill lager all over it). It's The Season, an 84-page colour magazine which comes free on Monday August 14 with The Guardian. It's overflowing with facts, analysis, fixture lists and previews, it mentions all the up-coming European action, and... er... it's not available in Scotland. Sorry about that.

ROD, JANE AND ASHLEY

Hello Zippy! Hello Bungle! It's Bradford's Geoffrey Richmond here again, and if I don't sound like George out of Rainbow I'll give you all a big squeeze. Ooh, you liked that didn't you! Now back in May, when I said, "Maybe in a year or two we could even win the Worthington or FA Cup and I feel we could soon be challenging for a European place," you all laughed didn't you? Well yesterday I made the "most exciting signing in the club's history" and today I've been busy finding a partner for young Benito. Oh, Geoffrey!

And soon to be flying high above the streets and houses in Bradford is Blackburn's Ashley Ward, a big strapping mount of a lad who I've just agreed a fee of £1.5m with Blackburn for. But don't worry Mr Bank Manager - I'm about to offload Lee Mills to Portsmouth for £1m, with a further £175,000 to be added depending on appearances. Ooh, I'm so excited I want to break into song!

But I won't call in Rod, Jane and Freddy just yet, because the deal isn't completed. "We have agreed the fee with Blackburn for Ashley, but he still has one or two details to iron out with his club before we can proceed with talks," I told the world's media earlier today. But don't worry Bantams fans - I don't mind flying to Lancashire at the last minute or paying over-the-top wages to get my man! And as for Lee Mills? Well, he's "due to have talks over personal terms with Portsmouth shortly, and he and his agent will be flying down this afternoon to start the ball rolling." And Bradford's ball will soon be rolling too, my lovelies - all the way to the top of the table! Now can somebody get me out of this window?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We had a great relationship and still have. Everything was always great between us and between him and his team-mates. They loved him to death. Our coaching staff loved him, the crowd loved him and the ladies at the training ground loved him. He got on great with everybody" - So why was Benito Carbone offloaded by John Gregory (who has now officially taken Quote of the Day residence)?

THE KIDS AREN'T UNITED - THEY'RE ARSENAL

Arsene's Arsenal Wenger has been called many things in his illustrious career. As a player with Mutzig, Mulhouse and Strasbourg he was called Le Prof. With Grampus Eight in Japan he was known as Arsene-san. And now he laughs along as amusing English colleagues tease him with the first four letters of his name. But our research has shown he has never been called The Kidnapper... until now.

You'll recall that defenceless child Guy Demel - "a young Patrick Vieira" - moved from Nimes to Highbury the other day. "It's not a transfer, it's a kidnapping," Pierre Mosca, the football director at Nimes, ranted. "I find it revolting that so-called big clubs use such methods to attract young talent." And before Mosca totally blew his top, there was just time to seethe: "If Arsenal needs Demel, Arsenal needs help."

Step forward The Kidnapper. He patted the blubbering child (er, 19-year-old French ace) on the head, handed him a Calippo and bridled: "I am not happy at all with what [Mosca] has said. It harms our reputation. They had him on a one-year contract and did not offer him another one. We did everything right." So poor Mosca can have no retort. He has already acknowledged that, "legally, Arsenal is in the right, but not ethically". Even if the Arsenal boss did lead Demel to north London with promises of sweets and first-team football - stop singing that song, Spurs fans - Mosca will just have to bite his lip and call Wenger what everyone else at Arsenal does.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Chelsea are reported to be close to signing Italy defender Christian Panucci from Internazionale. Panucci seems keen on the deal: "Chelsea is a good solution, and the Premiership is an important championship. I hope my agent agrees a deal with Chelsea."

Dundee's Scotland Under-21 international defender Lee Wilkie is poised to join Leeds on trial with a view to a £2m move.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Liverpool are confident the Anfield Road stand will be fully open for the visit of Bradford on the first day of the new Premiership season. They today instructed engineers to stiffen the upper terrace, which started moving during Ronnie Moran's recent testimonial against Celtic.

David O'Leary could lose Harry Kewell and Mark Viduka for the whole of March if plans to alter next year's fixture calendar are given the go ahead. Australia were looking to play all of their World Cup qualifying matches in June, but Fifa now look set to hold the Confederation Cup that month, forcing the Socceroos to seek alternative dates.

Manchester City midfielder Jamie Pollock is poised to join Crystal Palace after the two clubs agreed a fee of £600,000 for the player.

Jaap Stam has been cleared by the Dutch FA to play in Manchester United's Premiership opener against Newcastle. United boss Sir Alex Ferguson had feared Stam would miss the Old Trafford clash on August 20 because of international duty.

Former Blackburn and Leicester striker Graham Fenton, 26, has joined Stoke on a month's contract.

Crystal Palace have signed Middlesbrough left-back Craig Harrison, 22, and Arsenal goalkeeper Stuart Taylor, 19, on loan.

Rochdale manager Steve Parkin has signed a new three-year contract at Spotland.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Fifa TV (6.30, 10.15pm)

Sepp's show is now so popular Sky are now showing it twice in one night. Why isn't ITV doing the same with Burnside?

Sky Sports 3: Football (8pm)

And a three hour Sky-a-thon about the first Premiership season isn't going to placate us either. We want more Burnside.

Eurosport: Football - Live (9pm)

FC Boavista v Barry Town. Watch the second half live. After Burnside.

Channel 5: Football (12.10am)

Liverpool v Valerenga. Do you think Gerald Houllier looks a bit Christopher Ellison, the man who plays TV's Burnside?

Argentinian Football (1.50am)

We'll have to go to bed after this finishes. If only there was a repeat of Burnside.

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Coca Cola
fields.body:
Cyber pocket money

Fancy taking on the England five-a-side football team in your back garden or having your face on the Coca Cola sign in Piccadilly Circus? Coca Cola is offering customers the opportunity to do so, at an online auction site where the only acceptable currency is "Coke credits". Auctions at www.cokeauction.co.uk will start at the end of the month, allowing web-savvy teens - who can't shop on the net because they don't have credit cards - to bid for anything from CDs and games software to "money-can't-buy experiences". By registering at the site you receive 500 free credits. To increase your credits you need to collect the special ringpulls and labels that started appearing on cans and bottles at the beginning of this month (10 ringpulls or labels convert to 1,000 credits).

Coke credits are not the first virtual currency to get generation Y shopping on the web. www.Y-creds.co.uk is an e-payment system that lets youngsters shop at partner sites. Anyone can buy Y-creds for an account holder provided they have the holder's email address. Teenagers can use the credits to shop at online shops including Lush and teen girls site Wicked Colors.

www.rools.com, the virtual payment site whose fortunes are chronicled in this paper, is aiming to "soft launch" in mid-to late September. It will operate a cash-based system that teenagers will be able to use to shop at online retail partners. Looks like it's all over for the piggy bank.

webTitle: Consumer: How much can you pay for...a bedspread

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst: ... a bedspread
fields.trailText: ... a bedspread
fields.body:
Barely will you have recovered from the shock of how much it costs, than you'll be struck by the horror of what it's made from. Let's face it, no fool, no matter how rich, is going to spend the equivalent of a Kensington bedsit on a cotton-polyester bedspread. We're talking chinchilla here, a king-size creation designed by the master of luxury Avi Rossini at the breathtaking price of £150,000.

Improbable as it is that you'll be planning to remortgage the flat and sell the car, kids, whatever you can lay your hands on, to purchase said object, you might want to take a moment to browse the Rossini brochure. In addition to designing the collection - men's tailoring and accessories, luggage and furnishings - Rossini demonstrates how it should be worn by treating customers to a few carefully posed pictures.

Just in case you were in any doubt that you've got what it takes to be a Rossini customer, Rossini's "10 commandments" for life, listed at the back of the brochure, include "power", "ego", "money" and "perfection". So have you got it? Let's hope not.

Avi Rossini: 020 7499 5076

fields.headline: Spanish protest against Eta violence
fields.trailText: Protesters took to the streets throughout the northern Basque region of Spain today, after this week's upsurge in violence by Basque separatists Eta.
fields.body:
Protesters took to the streets throughout the northern Basque region of Spain today, after this week's upsurge in violence by Basque separatists Eta.

Crowds outside the town hall in Pamplona hurled abuse at politicians from Euskal Herritarrok - widely considered to be Eta's political wing - as they walked across the square at the start of a five-minute silence to mark yesterday's shooting of an army officer in the city.

When police asked to see their identity papers, a scuffle broke out and Juan Kruz Aldasoro, a member of the party's executive committee, was wrestled to the ground and detained.

Police would not confirm what, if any, charges Mr Aldasoro would face.

Since noon on Tuesday, two car bombs and a shooting have left two people dead and 11 injured. Since ending a 14-month cease-fire in December, Eta has been blamed for nine deaths in around 20 attacks.

The Interior Ministry office for the Navarra region, the capital of which is Pamplona, said that Mr Aldasoro and other EH officials had requested permission to hold a demonstration in the area today, but that had been turned down.

News agency Efe said that the rally would have been in memory of four suspected Eta members who blew themselves up Monday night as they drove through Bilbao in a car full of explosives.

Spanish police said that they were on their way to stage an attack.

While the Pamplona protest was taking place, other silent anti-Eta vigils were held in the Basque capital Vitoria and San Sebastian.

At the same time, the Spanish met opposition leaders to discuss the upsurge in violence.

All officials refused to make any comment as they left the meeting, but it seems likely that politicians will present a united front against the violence.

Before this week's violence, Eta had staged nearly a dozen attacks over the previous month, including two political assassinations in July.

The group has killed around 800 people since 1968, when it launched its campaign of violence for a Basque state in northern Spain and south west France.

Eta maintained a ceasefire for 14 months until last, blaming the government for refusing to discuss its demands for self-rule.

webTitle: Native speakers are failing online English test

fields.headline: Native speakers are failing online English test
fields.standfirst: It is an English invention that conquered the world. It drives the internet. By 2050 more than half the world's population will use it every day. But Britain is forgetting what to do with it.
fields.trailText: It is an English invention that conquered the world. It drives the internet. By 2050 more than half the world's population will use it every day. But Britain is forgetting what to do with it.
fields.body:
It is an English invention that conquered the world. It drives the internet. By 2050 more than half the world's population will use it every day. But Britain is forgetting what to do with it.

The rapid rise of e-business and email has exposed a national embarrassment: English may be the international online language, but British firms are less adept at using it than their foreign competitors.

Workers at some of Britain's biggest firms are so bad at penning simple email messages or dealing with customers on the internet that managers are hiring teachers to explain secondary-school-standard grammar, spelling and punctuation. Retailers such as Marks & Spencer, Tesco and Waterstone's are spending hundreds of thousands of pounds on teaching staff how to write.

Unilever, which sells everything from margarine to washing powder, is enrolling staff in a "writing programme" and has hired poets and dramatists to help raise standards. The Royal Mail has issued guidelines to its staff on how to communicate.

Alastair Creamer, who set up Unilever's Project Catalyst literacy programme last year, says: "Businesses do more and more work online, but they are finding they cannot get their message over in words as well as they used to face-to-face or on the telephone.

"In some areas email is a complete joke, with no grammar, no capital letters, and words in the wrong place."

Sending staff back to language school will also have commercial benefits, says Creamer. "A well-crafted letter or email can turn one person on to a brand and they will then perhaps tell 10 of their friends. Write a bad email and they will tell their friends not to buy that company's products again."

Martin Lee, of the London-based marketing consultancy Fourth Room, who helped Waterstone's set up its literacy scheme, says Britain is falling behind because businesses assume that English is the international language and they do not work as hard as foreign firms to ensure high standards.

Britons also see email as an informal means of communication in which mistakes do not matter. Supporters of a return to traditional teaching methods will see British businesses' initiatives as confirmation that Britain's education system is in a worse state than ever. If nothing is done, they say, England will disappear into a linguistic cyber ghetto.

"A well-crafted letter or email can turn one person on to a brand and they will then perhaps tell 10 of their friends. Write a bad email and they will tell their friends not to buy that company's products again." Martin Lee, of the London-based marketing consultancy Fourth Room, who helped Waterstone's set up its literacy scheme, says Britain is falling behind because businesses assume that English is the international language and they do not work as hard as foreign firms to ensure high standards. Britons also see email as an informal means of communication in which mistakes do not matter. Supporters of a return to traditional teaching methods will see British businesses' initiatives as confirmation that Britain's education system is in a worse state than ever. If nothing is done, they say, England will disappear into a linguistic cyber ghetto.

webTitle: Asylum seekers left out of class

fields.headline: Asylum seekers left out of class
fields.standfirst: Sue Stewart on the struggle to meet the ELT needs of Britain's refugee community
fields.trailText: Sue Stewart on the struggle to meet the ELT needs of Britain's refugee community
fields.body:
Straight into the college foyer on Monday morning, and I see the first asylum seeker of the week at the reception desk, looking Middle Eastern and tired. "I need English. English class where?" Reluctantly I declare myself. "I teach English. Can I help you?"

The answer is that I can't. We have no more spaces in any of our classes for English as a second language (ESOL) in Newcastle. We have a file bulging with names and addresses of desperate refugees. We are no longer enrolling students, and I should tell him to come back in three months' time when our next sessions start.

But I can't face the disappointment in his eyes. So we go upstairs and I ask him to write down his name and address and promise to get in touch if there are any spaces. "But please you give me class soon," he begs. "I come back again tomorrow."

"No, not tomorrow. Wait until we write to you," and I mimic the act of writing with an imaginary pencil in the air.

"I at home all day," he says. "Do nothing. Need English. Need class."

He starts to follow me into the staff-room to plead his case, and colleagues look up wearily. I manage to get rid of him at last, after marking his name with an asterisk and the words "very keen".

We date all entries and try to offer places on a first-come, first-served basis, but many names have special pleas for clemency attached, and when we trawl the files we try to take these into account. We also have to work out whether to offer several classes to a few students, thereby enabling them to learn English more quickly, or one class a week to many students. We eventually decide to send notes round to all the ESOL staff again, asking them to look at their class lists and see if they can squeeze in a few extras.

The week continues in the same pattern, the normal demands of teaching and administration being punctuated by the extra requests of the new arrivals in the corridors.

We started our classes and filled them in last September, but huge numbers of asylum seekers began to arrive without warning in the middle of winter. We have laid on as many extra classes as we can without notice, but we are stretched to breaking point, as are other nearby colleges and ESOL centres.

We have taken on new staff, thus increasing the overcrowding in our squalid staffroom. We are even busing students twice a day to a nearby campus where new IT facilities are proving a boon to the new refugee students. (Many with a smattering of English and an interest in computing have enrolled on a Start IT course while awaiting the holy grail of ESOL.)

Meanwhile our role in the college extends far beyond that of mere teaching. We are worried about the students' living conditions. Some came to us from a hostel where there was no hot water for a week. They smelt so bad that teachers on enrolment duty were gagging as they filled in the forms. Others are suffering from the bad diets forced on them in these hostels, or from the fact that they have been housed out of town, but are not being given their bus fare to attend college.

We find ourselves phoning social services to plead for students to be rehoused, as they have been placed in unsuitable accommodation without local consultation. Other teachers are phoning the churches to find out about second-hand clothing and furniture for our students. We have to deal with mental health problems too. Many asylum seekers are traumatised and deeply unhappy. A few are aggressive.

We have always taken pride in our ESOL department, seeing ourselves as a happy and successful part of the college, efficiently led by a section leader who is professional and compassionate, and with classes of satisfied and hard-working students.

Now we find ourselves exhausted, demoralised and embarrassed at having to turn so many people away. We are haunted by the corridor people, their faces pressed against the glass of our staffroom door. It feels as though we are in a kind of corridor, too, a halfway place between compassion and frustration, and Britain seems to be in a large corridor of its own, not sure whether it is helping asylum seekers or punishing them.

One thing seems certain - if we continue to move vast numbers of people around the country to areas of high unemployment without any support systems for them, we are storing up trouble that will explode in a way that lowly further education teachers cannot control.

I recently set a class the mundane homework task of designing an information leaflet for public library users. A Kurdish refugee wrote: "You have to be careful when you choose the book because from those books which you will read, the Iraqi security service will know how do you think. You can find these books are against the Iraqi government but you cannot read them. If you read them, you will go to the prison as soon as possible."

In a country where we have the luxury of reading the books of our choice, could we not also offer a little more practical help to people from countries where this is not possible?

 Sue Stewart is an ESOL lecturer at Newcastle College, England

webTitle: British backpacker raped and murdered in Thailand

fields.headline: British backpacker raped and murdered in Thailand
fields.trailText:
A British backpacker has been raped and strangled in a guesthouse in a popular Thai hill resort today, police said. 
Kirsty Sara Jones, 24, who is thought to originate from Wales, had checked in alone at the Aree guesthouse in Chiang Mai,
422 miles north of Bangkok, a few days ago.
fields.body:
A British backpacker has been raped and strangled in a guesthouse in a popular Thai hill resort today, police said. Kirsty Sara Jones, 24, who is thought to originate from Wales, had checked in alone at the Aree guesthouse in Chiang Mai, 422 miles north of Bangkok, a few days ago.

A fellow Briton Sarah Wiggett, from Cambridgeshire, who spent the evening with Kirsty before she died, said: "We were out on the town last night. I'm staying at a different guesthouse to Kirsty so we parted ways at the end of the night.

"The first thing I knew about this was at 6.30 tonight.

"I only met her last week. I think she'd just finished university and she was working around the Liverpool area to get some money together.

"I don't know if I'm going to stay out here now after this."

Police Lieutenant Colonel Suvit Khunprasert said the body had been found by other guests and the guesthouse owner, who became suspicious when Ms Jones did not come out of her room today.

They let themselves in to find her laying face down, partly naked with a piece of cloth tightly wrapped around her neck. The previous night guests had heard sounds of a struggle and a scream from Ms Jones's room, but ignored the fracas, thinking it was no more than a lovers' quarrel, Lieut Khunprasert said.

Police suspect there was only one attacker. The body was sent to a hospital for forensic examination and British diplomats had been informed of the death, police said.

webTitle: Win tickets to The Jolly Boys' Last Stand

fields.headline: Win tickets to The Jolly Boys' Last Stand
fields.standfirst: Win one of ten pairs of tickets to this new British comedy starring Sacha Baron Cohen
fields.trailText: Win one of ten pairs of tickets to this new British comedy starring Sacha Baron Cohen
fields.body:
For years now, Anthony (Andy Serkis) - better known to his mates as Spider - has been a steadfast member, and 'El Presidente', of a select but none too sophisticated group of friends who live only for their regular meetings down the pub and an endless succession of silly japes. But time's moving on, and Anthony's attention shifts to thoughts of promotion at work and marriage to the middle-class, considerably more sensible Rebecca. She, understandably, is wary when he invites the eternally adolescent Des to be his best man, especially when Des decides to make a documentary about the forthcoming wedding on his camcorder. The video's supposed to be a celebratory souvenir, but Des has plans of his own...

Christopher Payne's first feature makes a virtue of its low budget and having been shot on Digibeta video; structured along the lines of a home-movie, complete with 'fly-on-the-wall' footage and interviews, it's cleverly reminiscent of those embarrassing wedding videos we've all had to suffer. As it follows the ups and downs of the Jolly Boys, desperately trying to stay together even as their leader hesitantly considers calling it a day, the film is both very funny and an insightful critique of the kind of laddish behaviour that refuses to confront the responsibilities of adulthood and emotional commitment. With engagingly naturalistic performances all round and a lively but credible script, Payne's modest but very entertaining comedy proves that talent and imagination are far more important than a big budget, and introduces a talent to watch. It also features a certain Sacha Baron Cohen (better known as Ali G) in the role of Vinnie.

The Jolly Boys' Last Stand opens at London's National Film Theatre on Friday 18 August and plays throughout the subsequent week. On its opening night, the 6.20pm screening will be introduced by the director, Christopher Payne. Members of the cast and crew will also be present.

We have 10 pairs of tickets to give away to this screening, available to the first 10 Film Unlimited users to call the NFT box office on 020 7928 3232 quoting 'Film Unlimited Jolly Boys offer'. The box office is open 11.30am - 8.30pm daily. Winners will be required to collect their tickets from the NFT box office half an hour before the screening.

webTitle: Pacific Century CyberWorks bolstered by mystery sale

fields.headline: Mystery sale bolsters Hong Kong hi-tech
fields.standfirst:
£320m trade gives Pacific Century CyberWorks blue chip status
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Pacific Century CyberWorks, the internet company founded by Richard Li, traded for the first day as a blue chip in the wake of a mystery sale of 1% of its shares.
fields.body:
Pacific Century CyberWorks, the internet company founded by Richard Li, traded for the first day as a blue chip in the wake of a mystery sale of 1% of its shares.

The deal, concluded after Tuesday's market close, was a block trade by the parent Pacific Century Group to an unnamed security house. The trade was for 240m. CyberWorks shares worth HK$3.79bn (£320m).

"The timing is interesting," said a market analyst yesterday. "In the last 30 minutes of trading, CyberWorks and Cable & Wireless HKT [with whom CyberWorks is set to merge on August 17] were falling like a rock, and people were very puzzled."

"There is a lot of speculation that it might be the [Hong Kong government's] tracker fund - it has to track the Hang Seng index and it would not be perfectly matching otherwise."

Mr Li, son of Hong Kong real estate tycoon Li Ka-shing, created the company to wire up Asia to the internet and controls nearly 70% of the group. Chip-maker Intel owns 15%.

The company yesterday insisted that it would now retain the rest of its holdings. In its first day of trading on the Hang Seng, CyberWorks gained 2.45% to close at HK$16.70. This was interpreted as a natural rebound after it had done less well than expected on Tuesday.

Shareholders of C&W HKT have five more trading days to choose between CyberWorks's alternative offers of all shares and cash and shares. It is generally believed that unless CyberWorks can trade up to about HK$18.60, shareholders will plump for cash and shares.

Analysts say that the Li family factor is still powerful enough to sway the market in spite of recent setbacks.

Last week the much-hyped internet vehicle Tom.com, which belongs to the flagship company of Richard Li's even more famous father, Li Ka-shing, announced losses of HK$193.89m (£16.6m) in its first six months.

Recently the internet company laid off 80 staff to cut costs and terminated contracts for another 30 temporary employees.

However, the company has been judged more likely to weather the storm than many companies in Hong Kong and in mainland China thanks to the Li family's influence and cash.

webTitle: Bomb blasts hole in Kashmir peace hopes

fields.headline: Bomb blasts hole in Kashmir peace hopes
fields.standfirst: As militants target Kashmir again, former India correspondent Derek Brown assesses the damage it has done to the provinces's hopes for peace
fields.trailText: August 10, Analysis: As militants target Kashmir again, former India correspondent Derek Brown assesses the damage it has done to the province's hopes for peace.
fields.body:
A bomb explosion, cynically planned to inflict maximum casualties, has killed at least 10 people in Srinagar, the capital of the Indian-controlled Kashmir Valley.

The powerful car bomb exploded minutes after an earlier, smaller blast had drawn a crowd of security forces and journalists to the scene.

As yet, none of Kashmir's gaggle of guerrilla groups has claimed responsibility. Government sources have already discounted early speculation that the bomb was planted by the Hizbul Mujahiden, which is the biggest of the militant groups.

The Hizbul fighters had called off a ceasefire on Tuesday, accusing the Indian government of failing to show good faith by involving Pakistan in peace talks.

Since the ceasefire was declared on July 24, senior Indian officials, including former prime minister Inder Kumar Gujral, have been involved in frantic talks with Hizbul leaders and intermediaries.

But other militant groups, apparently determined to sabotage the rickety peace process and outflank their Hizbul rivals, made sure that Kashmir remained bathed in blood.

At the beginning of this month, more than 100 Hindus were massacred in Kashmir. Most were on religious pilgrimage to the mountains overlooking Srinagar.

Now, it seems that the slender thread of hope offered by the Hizbul ceasefire has been snapped.

The chaotic guerrilla campaign has claimed tens of thousands of lives since it erupted in the late 1980s.

India has regularly accused Pakistan of arming and training the insurgents, especially Hizbul, and the two countries' armies have frequently exchanged artillery fire along the 1948 ceasefire line that separates them.

At the dawn of independence, Kashmir became part of India on the whim of its Hindu maharajah, and to the dismay of its overwhelmingly Muslim people.

Pakistan's forces invaded, but were restricted to the mountainous western third of the state.

Many Kashmiris long for independence from both India and Pakistan. Neither country is prepared to countenance that option.

webTitle: G2: Only 13 to go Oliver Burkeman tackles William Hague's Rotherham pub crawl

fields.headline: Cheers!
fields.standfirst: William Hague says he often used to down 14 pints a day, knocking one back in every pub his delivery van stopped at. But can this really be possible?  Oliver Burkeman  visited some of the Tory leader's Rotherham haunts to take up his challenge
fields.trailText: William Hague says he often used to down 14 pints a day, knocking one back in every pub his delivery van stopped at. But can this really be possible?  Oliver Burkeman  visited some of the Tory leader's Rotherham haunts to take up his challenge
fields.body:
The bitter in Rotherham flows thick and smooth from a thousand taps in tens of pubs. And its journey thereafter is usually simple enough - taking in the stomachs of a few bar-propping heavyweights of advancing years and ending up as often as not in the porcelain urinals of the same establishments. But for several years in the late 1970s, if the current edition of GQ magazine is to be believed, an improbable proportion of it took an unlikely detour via the guts of a blond and baby-faced soft-drink delivery boy of rightwing sympathies called William Hague. At every pub where his father's delivery van stopped, Hague told the magazine, he'd have a pint: "You worked so hard you didn't feel you'd drunk 10 pints by four o'clock. But then you had to lift all the empties off the lorry. It's probably horrifying, but we used to do that, then go home for tea, then go out in the evening to the pub." Totalling 14 pints a day? "I think when you're a teenager you can do that," said the author of the common sense revolution.

Hague's claims have prompted much mean-spirited scepticism from those eager to detect the signs of another ill-conceived publicity stunt. There is, however, only one true way to test the feasibility of a 14-pint afternoon pub crawl around the centre of Rotherham, and that is a 14-pint afternoon pub crawl around the centre of Rotherham.

The Mason's Arms, Wellgate

They remember Hague's Drinks, the Tory leader's family business, at the gloomy and near-silent bar of the Mason's Arms, where I sink an initial pint of Stones bitter and hear, to my astonishment, the landlord Neil Wheeler and his friend Joseph Bamsorth tell me they have no difficulty at all in believing that the schoolboy Tory might have imbibed 14 pints of the same. "All the draymen doing the deliveries stopped for one in every pub," says Neil. "And, of course, the beer was stronger then, so it was even more impressive. But I'm sure if he says he did it, then he did it."

"Yes, but this is William Hague we're talking about," I point out.

"Yes, but this is Rotherham," Joseph says. This is the end of the discussion.

The Hare and Hound, Wellgate

"Of course he did," says Jess, propping up the bar at the Hare and Hound in a way that suggests he may have been written into the architectural plans of the building. "He's a Yorkshireman, and you've got to remember that God created Yorkshire first and then just chucked everything else around it." I order a second pint of Stones.

"I could do 24, 25 pints in my time," Jeff adds, a little menacingly. "Where are you from?"

I down my drink hurriedly and leave, narrowly avoiding tripping on the step.

The Mailcoach, Wellgate

I am beginning to feel a little tipsy and decide to start pacing myself, so I downgrade from bitter to Carling Black Label, which has the advantage of being completely undrinkable anyway. It is here, in the smoky cosiness of the Mailcoach, that I encounter the first murmurings of scepticism towards Hague's hard-drinking reminiscences. Actually, it's more than a murmur.

"It's absolute crap. It's the biggest fallacy going," says Philip, a rosy-cheeked regular of many years' standing. "Fourteen pints of sarsaparilla maybe. Or 14 pints of shandy perhaps. He wants to be one of the lads, but I'm telling you, he'll never be one of the lads. We were miners, steelworkers here. There's a gentleman in Barnsley who can make 36 pints a day." We're interrupted by another red-faced regular who says he heard all this Hague business and doesn't buy it either. "I am a correspondent with the international Reuters news service," he adds, apropos of nothing. "Michael Parkinson is a very good friend of mine. Can I buy you a drink?"

Through what is rapidly becoming a drunken haze, I listen to Philip's considered assessment of the political fallout from Beergate. "Hague's certainly got everyone talking about him in Rotherham. But, you know, he's a very good man for the area. Put it this way: if he came round my house I'd certainly give him tea if he wanted some." He pauses for reflection. "But if he wanted coffee, tough shit."

The Red Lion, Red Lion Yard

Four pubs in, and the putative leader of the opposition would presumably have been discovering the finer points of Hayekian economic philosophy and wondering when somebody was going to start serving some real alcohol. I resort to a half, which is, as the barmaid points out, a ladies' drink, and so it is with a group of ladies in the corner that I next raise the explosive combination of the words "William Hague" and "hard drinking" in the same breath.

"He was in my class at Wath Comprehensive and he was a prat even then," says Sharon, when the incredulous laughter finally subsides. "A prat. The first week of school, he stood in front of the class - nobody else did this - and his mum was standing beside him, and he said, 'I would like to introduce myself. My name is William Hague and I'm looking forward to being at school with you all.' I never slept with him," she adds, as if it would have been only natural to have wondered.

"He's trying to be a Rotherham man," says Liz, "and all Rotherham men drink a lot." It is becoming increasingly clear that I'm never going to pass for a Rotherham man.

"I tell you," says Sharon, "I said then, I looked at him and I said to my best friend, 'Look at that William Hague. I swear to God he's going to be prime minister one day. I said it all those years ago."

She takes a sip of her beer. "He isn't of course."

The Angel, Bridgegate

I feel sick. "This is one of the oldest pubs in town and not one of the old boys here can ever remember him even having half a lager," says the Angel's deputy manager, Terry Glossop. "Look - he was Billy the Fizz. That's what we all called him. There's no way he ever drank 14 pints." I am comforted by the news and order a lager shandy.

The barman looks at me strangely, although not unsympathetically.

The County Borough, Bridgegate

At this point the sober visitor to Rotherham may wish to pause to admire the beauty of the 15th-century Chapel of Our Lady on Rotherham bridge. But it doesn't register particularly strongly with me as I stumble into the County Borough Hotel, a spit-and-sawdust kind of an establishment, and not at all the kind of place to order a Coke. I order a Coke.

"He's the laughing stock of Rotherham," says the manager Nick Sleight, regarding my drink with suspicion. "Most of the women here could drink him under the table."

"Tell him," says Gareth Mouseley, lurching towards me while clutching his pint. "Tell him that if he wants to come down here the County Borough boys will see what he's made of. We'll see if he can drink 14 pints." Mouseley tells me proudly that he spent £120 on beer alone yesterday. "And tell him I'm paying."

It is a challenge that most politicians would avoid like the plague, since it could only lead to an entirely humiliating attempt at a publicity stunt that would be much mocked by the press, which means, presumably, that a pre-election Hague-Mouseley drinking match is a near inevitability.

The Effingham Arms

I don't remember the Effingham Arms.

A churchyard, central Rotherham

I'm not quite sure where I am. The sky seems to be spinning. I still don't know how it feels to be William "14 pints" Hague, iron-stomached delivery boy and scourge of Tory wets and Rotherham lightweights. I am, however, beginning to empathise with Euan Blair.

fields.headline: Vigilantes suspend anti-paedophile protest
fields.trailText: Anti-paedophile protests on a Portsmouth housing estate were today suspended after a fifth family was driven out by the violence.
fields.body:
Anti-paedophile protests on a Portsmouth housing estate were today suspended after a fifth family was driven out by the violence.

The vigilante group - which had until today threatened to keep the protest up until all alleged paedophiles were driven off the Paulsgrove estate and the government agreed to tag all sex offenders - said it would suspend the demonstrations to take part in talks with Portsmouth city council.

Up to 300 people took to the streets last night, targeting the homes of three alleged paedophiles in what was the seventh night of vigilante protests on the estate.

A spokesman for Portsmouth city council today confirmed that a fifth family had been moved into temporary accommodation but would not confirm if they had been targeted by last night's protest or had asked to move because of the demonstrations.

A five-point "peace plan" has already been put into action in a bid to reduce tension on the estate, the spokesman said.

Police revealed yesterday that four innocent families had been forced to leave the estate in the wake of gossip that falsely accused them of harbouring paedophiles.

Protest leaders maintain their aim is not to intimidate innocent people but to rid the area of sex offenders. They claim their campaign has succeeded in driving out some of the 20 paedophiles they believe are living on the estate. Portsmouth North MP Syd Rapson said today that many residents had been terrified by the night-time marches through the streets. "I think the protesters themselves are starting to get exhausted and if they can stop the marches then that will be seen as a sign of good faith.

"They have put fear into people and risk driving paedophiles underground and I think residents would be very glad if the protests can be stopped," he added.

Home Office minister Barbara Roche called for calm in the wake of the protests. "We have said we are having a review of the register. We will meet with everybody concerned, of course we want to meet with the Payne family," she said.


 Outside Portsmouth an 82-year-old Dunkirk veteran who indecently assaulted a nine-year-old girl has been forced to leave his lifelong home because of the "current climate" regarding paedophiles, a court heard today.

The former soldier admitted putting his hand inside the young girl's trousers while she was at his home in the Northumberland coastal village of Embleton earlier this year.

Charles Edward Varnham admitted one count of indecent assault when he appeared before Alnwick magistrates earlier this year and today appeared at Newcastle crown court for sentencing. Penny Moreland, prosecuting, told the court that since the incident, in May, the girl began wetting the bed and crying, and had become afraid of older men. Stuart Graham, defending, told the court: "He will not be returning to his home town, for obvious reasons, and his house will be sold."

Judge David Wood imposed a two-year probation order and told Varnham: "The girl may not recover from this for a long time, if at all, and usually people go to prison for this offending.

"You will be 83 this Sunday and have never been in trouble before. You have lost your home because you will not be permitted to go back to Embleton and will have to find a new life somewhere else and that seems punishment itself."

fields.headline: Work mates dismiss Hague's boast
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: It was less Billy Fizz and more Billy Liar yesterday as William Hague's reputation as a drinking heavyweight was left hanging by a thread after former colleagues dismissed his boast of downing 14 pints a day.
fields.body:
It was less Billy Fizz and more Billy Liar yesterday as William Hague's reputation as a drinking heavyweight was left hanging by a thread after former colleagues dismissed his boast of downing 14 pints a day.

The Conservative party leader's claims of heavy drinking during a summer job hauling crates of drinks into pubs across South Yorkshire were met with disbelief by some who had worked with him.

One former colleague admitted he would never have dared to allow the boss's son to drink to such excess, while another recounted one episode which suggests Mr Hague may have been seeing double when he made his recent claims.

Neil Baker, a former driver for the Hague family's soft drinks company, who spent three summers with the Mr Hague, described how on one occasion, the young student was barely standing after just six pints.

He recalled in the Sun newspaper how the pair had stopped for a drink after a delivery run, but after six pints of beer Mr Hague was "sozzled".

He said: "It was ever so funny. He could not walk straight and his legs were all over the place. His words were coming out in a jumble, and when we walked back to the lorry he couldn't find the door. He kept reaching out for the handle and missing."

Mr Baker, 48, described Mr Hague as a smashing lad and paid tribute to his capacity for hard work. But he seemed less impressed with his ability to down pints: "He was not the boozer he'd have us believe".

Terry Glossop, assistant manager of The Angel, one of Rotherham's oldest pubs, was equally sceptical about Mr Hague's drinking prowess, but invited him to come and prove everybody wrong.

Speaking in the Mirror, he said: "He is very welcome to come in here and have 14 pints of bitter on the house - as long as he drinks the lot."

fields.headline: Reforming Perot's alternative into oblivion
fields.standfirst: Forget stage-managed party conventions. As Duncan Campbell discovered in Los Angeles, the Reform Party is offering Americans far better entertainment value this week, if not a genuine political alternative
fields.trailText: Thursday, 11.30am: As Duncan Campbell discovered in Los Angeles, the Reform Party is offering Americans plenty of entertainment, if not a political alternative.
fields.body:
When eccentric billionaire Ross Perot founded it in 1992, the Reform Party pledged itself to reform the American political system.

But following a bizarre rumpus between party members gathering for their convention in Long Beach, it seems that what is in the greatest need of reform is the party itself.

What was intended as a rallying point for the party's presidential bid has turned into high farce with the possibility that, by the end of the week, there will be two Reform Parties, two Reform Party candidates and one big, fat law suit.

On one side of the row are supporters of Pat Buchanan - the gung-ho, right-wing former Republican who only joined the party last autumn.

In the opposite corner are those who accuse him and his supporters of hijacking the party and turning it from a libertarian crusade into a conservative pressure group that will do nothing to capture the electorate's imagination.

The row came to a head on Tuesday afternoon when the national committee split into factions, with each side claiming to represent the party and local police being called to restore order.

The Buchanan brigaders claimed victory but the opposition dispute the claim and say they will nominate their own candidate, Iowa physicist John Hagelin, who is also the Natural Law Party's candidate.

Buchanan himself was missing from the early fracas although his doughty sister Bay Buchanan was battling on his behalf.

When he arrived in Long Beach on Wednesday afternoon he ridiculed his opponents, laughed at their claims that his supporters were "storm troopers" and claimed "we built a party where it didn't exist."

Over the next few days, the two factions will each be running separate operations to validate the credentials of delegates and each will be claiming to be the true voice of the party.

The anti-Buchanan camp claim that his supporters have filed false ballot papers and committed electoral fraud. The party secretary Jim Mangia, who opposes Buchanan, said on local radio: "I think Pat Buchanan is corrupt and his campaign is corrupt."

It was over such feuding that the party lost the support of its most famous elected official, Minnesota governor and wrestler, Jesse Ventura

Now the party is in danger of becoming a laughing stock with the anti-Buchananites asking the media in to watch what was happening, while the pro-Buchananites wanted their meeting held in secret.

As the temperature outside the convention centre climbed towards the nineties, the heat also rose inside the two hotels where the separate camps were meeting to plan their next moves.

Yesterday, bemused delegates arriving from across the country were puzzled by the chaos that confronted them, although some clearly found it refreshing after last week's heavily stage-managed and unspontaneous Republican Convention in Philadelphia.

The row will be overshadowed when the Democrats start gathering at the weekend for their own convention in Los Angeles, but it may have dealt the Reform Party a blow from which it will be difficult to recover.

Polls already polls suggest that, if voters are leaning towards a third party, it will be the Green Party. Its candidate, Ralph Nader, is now achieving 10 per cent ratings in some states and could benefit from libertarian, anti-government voters who may have been put off by this week's unseemly brawling in Long Beach.

fields.headline: This ghoulish cull
fields.standfirst: Michael Ellison in New York on the political death of mentally retarded Oliver Cruz
fields.trailText: Michael Ellison in New York on the political death of mentally retarded Oliver Cruz.
fields.body:
Al Gore and George W Bush were out on the stump talking up their respective running mates in the presidential campaign.

Gore's prospective vice-president, Joe Lieberman was lauding the redemptive powers of miracles; and Bush's, Dick Cheney, was meeting a Christian organisation. Elsewhere in the United States, Hillary Clinton was helping to hand out Congressional medals to 15 well-deserving cases such as Jesse Jackson, allegedly dangerous car tyres were being recalled, and Elizabeth Taylor was being treated for mild pneumonia.

And far away in Huntsville, Texas, early today, a 33-year-old man with the mind of a child of 12 was receiving a lethal injection. Oliver Cruz, who had spent 12 years on death row, said he was sorry for raping and killing a 24-year-old woman and blamed drink and drugs rather than his IQ, which had been tested as low as 63, making him mentally retarded.

"I want to apologise to the family of Kelly Donovan (his victim)," said the killer who could barely read or write, speaking from the death chamber. "I'm sorry for what I did to her. I wish they could forgive me for what I did."

The Huntsville death chamber is the busiest in the United States and has had 227 clients since capital punishment returned to Texas in 1982, 140 of them in the five years since Mr Bush became governor.

Thirteen of the 38 states where the death penalty can be imposed do not execute the mentally retarded. Mr Bush's brother Jeb, governor of Florida, will not sign death warrants on such people and an attempt to save the mentally retarded from lethal injections in Texas failed last year in the state legislature.

The measure is thought likely to have more chance of passing next year when it comes up again for consideration. "That's the tragedy of this case," said Jeff Pokorak, Cruz's lawyer. The law is going to prevent the execution of people like Cruz in six to eight months so he would be the last retarded person to die under the old law."

But it would be a mistake to imagine that the streets are teeming with people objecting to this ghoulish cull. Cruz's case would barely have been noticed, if at all, were it not for his mental state. Certainly, the name of 36-year-old Brian Roberson, who stabbed to death an elderly couple in 1986, would not have rated a mention had he not been executed in the same death chamber an hour before Cruz.

True, support for the death penalty has ebbed, down to a 19-year low of 66 per cent at the last count. But the subject was just not an issue at last week's Republican Party convention; no-one expects to hear a word about it when the Democrats have theirs in a few days.

Both candidates for president are supporters, as are their running mates. President Clinton famously broke off from the campaign trail in 1992 to return to Arkansas, where he was governor, to sign the death warrant on a mentally-impaired man.

And Hillary Clinton, who is running for the Senate from New York, might be the only person running for elected office in the western world who is described by her opponents as an extreme left winger and by herself as a supporter of the death penalty.

fields.headline: Gibraltar
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the Rock, and why it's no longer quite as safe as   the old saying makes it out to be
fields.trailText:
All you need to know about the Rock, and why it's no longer quite as safe as 
the old saying makes it out to be
fields.body:
1. The Royal Navy nuclear submarine HMS Tireless is berthed in Gibraltar. In spite of their centuries of military links, the Gibraltarians are not best pleased.

2. The Tireless made for Gibraltar in May, breaking off a patrol when radioactive coolant leaked from her reactor.

3. The Navy wants to repair the stricken boat in Gibraltar. Local people believe that the sub is much too close for comfort, and want it towed back to the UK.

4. The officers and ratings from the Tireless have been put up at local hotels since May at a cost thought to run well into six figures.

5. This is a handsome boost to the local tourist industry, though by now the submariners may be tiring of the slightly limited dining, sightseeing, and entertainment offered on Gibraltar.

6. If they hang on another month, they will be able to divert themselves at the powerboat races.

7. Gibraltar was captured from Spain by an Anglo-Dutch expeditionary force in 1704. It has been British far longer than it was ever Spanish. But before that, it was held by the Moors for even longer.

8. Up to the second world war, Gibraltar was a priceless strategic asset. In more recent times, the military connection has been superseded by its importance as a financial centre.

9. The Rock (pop c.30,000) has also grown up politically, and is now self-governing. But the Royal Navy still doesn't have to ask permission to repair its leaky submarines there.

10. Nor are the British forces on Gibraltar any longer obliged to feed the Barbary apes.

webTitle: Analysis: Software will increasingly respond to our preferences

fields.headline: Second sight
fields.standfirst: Intelligent tills that check you out along with your goods are now part of our daily life
fields.trailText: Intelligent tills that check you out along with your goods are now part of our daily life, says Kevin Carey
fields.body:
Have you ever wondered what the real motive is behind supermarket loyalty cards? They are a front for tying you up with the things that you buy. Till records are no longer lists of anonymous purchases, but preferences attached to real, reachable people.

One day you will turn on your internet terminal, log onto your customary grocery supplier and will be greeted with a personalised message such as: "Special offer on Chateau Neuf du Pape." The system will have noted your love of red wine at around £7 a bottle and will try to nudge your spending up a notch.

When you have negotiated this temptation, you will check your regular, default list and make some amendments as Auntie, who is staying for the weekend, likes that revolting tinned salmon and, as the cat has just been run over, you cancel its food. Otherwise, it's the order as usual.

This model, of a supply being tempered by our own behaviour, is already part of some email systems. If you regularly answer email from Jack before anybody else, the system can put Jack at the top of your list every morning. But if a deal falls through with Jack, he will slip down the running order.

Soon the same kind of system will help to regulate our viewing behaviour. In a world of multi-channel, pay per view, unscheduled television, every minute you faff about with your remote control is a minute of unsold entertainment.

So entertainment sellers will log what we watch and when; football on Monday, cartoons with the kids on Tuesday; pornography when the wife's out at her needlework class on Wednesday; documentaries when the husband is out at darts on Thursday, and so on. You will be reminded of the special two-hour episode of your soap opera to be released at midnight at a special price.

These examples of intelligent agents are the simple part of information delivery based on "data mining" and behavioural analysis. We have much more to look forward to when probability software based on the theories of Thomas Bayes, an 18th century clergyman, will analyse huge quantities of data to produce manageable search reports.

Type in "Lions" without the prefix "British" and the system will guess that, as you watch a great deal of rugby but never wildlife programmes, you probably want the latest news of the tour.

These developments will save us all a lot of bother. But the usual reaction is that we don't need all this help. So many of us are speeding into the future with our back to the engine, analysing where we are going in terms of where we have been, that we are not ready for broadband technology and what it will do.

Soon your internet terminal will be an interactive, digital television, a telephone and a search engine but it will undergo a massive qualitative and quantitative shift once freed from conventional telephones. This is when we will need default grocery lists, narrowcasting and supersmart searching software.

Conventional supermarkets are limited in what they stock by their space and your trolley pushing patience. But their online services will be virtually unlimited.

We will soon forget the constraints of terrestrial television, no longer united by watching the same things at the same time. But no average human being will be able to navigate all the world's available digital entertainment.

Even with the conventional tools for building boring web sites, the amount of data on the web is doubling annually.

Soon we will be out of the messy experimentation and the gentle academic internet of the 1980s and 1990s into serious business and commerce. Instead of the annoyance of the "Illegal operation", we will not be allowed to fail. The combination of ruthless retail, intelligent systems and unlimited capacity has the potential to overwhelm us.

On the other hand, we will be able to buy intelligent systems that work for us against the salesmen.

The crunch will come when the dot.coms can survive only on the sale of advertising. What will happen when our privately purchased software automatically cleans out the stuff we don't want, even while we sleep?

fields.headline: Blast kills 10 in Kashmir
fields.trailText: At least 10 people were killed and 20 injured today after two bombs were detonated outside a government bank in Srinagar, the summer capital of Indian-administered Kashmir.
fields.body:
At least 10 people were killed and 20 injured today after two bombs were detonated outside a government bank in Srinagar, the summer capital of Indian-administered Kashmir.

Several journalists filming a car damaged in the decoy explosion were among those wounded when the second, larger, blast occurred in the city's crowded Lal Chowk district.

"I have removed seven bodies. They were all in uniform," said Manohar Singh, a paramilitary soldier, who said that most of the dead were policemen. "One body had no arm. One had his face ripped off."

Caps obelonging to the dead policemen were strewn on the road as shops shut down and terrified people scurried for cover.

Pradeep Bhatia, a photographer for The Hindustan Times,also died in the blast, said an assistant to the editor.

No one immediately claimed responsibility for the blasts, which come two days after Kashmir's main guerrilla group Hezb-ul-Mujahideen called off a 15-day ceasefire and ended talks with the Indian government.

Kashmir has been wracked by a separatist movement since 1989, during which guerrilla groups have fought with security forces, leaving 25,000 people dead.

Guerrillas massacred 102 people on August 1 and 2 in nine attacks in towns and villages in southern Kashmir.

The militants want Kashmir to break away from India and become independent or merge with Pakistan.

Hezb-ul Mujahedeen announced a ceasefire on July 24, angering other militant groups opposed to talks that did not involve them or Pakistan.

They called off the ceasefire on Tuesday, saying that Indian Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee had refused to involve Pakistan in the dialogue.

fields.headline: Paedophile protests
fields.standfirst: As vigilantes continue to target suspected paedophiles, Simon Jeffery, Jeevan Vasagar and Julian Glove explain what has triggered the violence
fields.trailText: As vigilantes continue to target suspected paedophiles, we explain what has triggered the violence.
fields.body:
Why are vigilante groups haranguing suspected paedophiles?
Just under two weeks ago, the News of the World published the names and photographs of 49 people it said were child sex offenders living in towns and cities across Britain. Vigilante groups, composed mainly of parents who now believe they have convicted paedophiles living in their area, have taken to noisy protests outside the suspected sex offenders' houses demanding they leave. A protest in Portsmouth has carried on unabated for the last six nights.

And what have they achieved?
Two men accused of child sex offences have committed suicide and four innocent families have fled their homes in Portsmouth after gossip and rumour wrongly identified them as harbouring paedophiles. Violence has flared in Plymouth and Whitely, Berkshire, as gangs mob suspected sex offenders. Innocent men mistaken for paedophiles who have been "named and shamed" by the News of the World have been targeted in London and Manchester.

What do the police and others say?
Police say that the attacks will put more children at risk as they struggle to supervise convicted paedophiles driven underground for fear of their lives. Clergy and politicians, sensing a witch hunt, have called for the vigilante action to stop. Robin Corbett, chair of the Commons home affairs select committee, says he is asking the Home Office to prosecute the News of the World for incitement to public order offences.

So what was the News of the World thinking of?
The murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne focused national attention on the threat to children posed by sex offenders, which is where the current saga began. The paper called its campaign For Sarah and claimed that her murder proved that police monitoring of paedophiles was not enough. Every parent had a right to know who the child sex offenders were, it said, and has since dropped the campaign in favour of "Sarah's Law," a version of "Megan's Law" in the US, that would give parents access to information about paedophiles on the sex offenders register.

What is the sex offenders register?
There are 12,000 people on the sex offenders register, which came into force in 1997. Anyone convicted of any sexual crime must register their names and addresses with the police, and inform them within 14 days if they move. Any offender failing to register can be jailed for up to six months and fined. In addition, police can apply for a community protection order, which lasts for a minimum of five years and can bar an individual from areas frequented by children.

Who gets told about the movements of sex offenders?
Head teachers, doctors, youth leaders, sports club managers and others, including landlords, are notified on a confidential basis of the existence of a local sex offender.

Is it likely that this information would be freely available in Britain?
In a recent legal ruling, it was declared that it was in society's interests for the offenders to be allowed to live normal, lawful lives. The past week's vigilante action makes it increasingly unlikely the Home Office would support a law that would give life to mob rule. The police maintain that the supervision of sex offenders is designed around public protection. "If you damage our supervision you damage public protection," George Barrow, spokesman for the Association of Chief Officers of Probation, said yesterday.

What do Sarah Payne's parents think?
They say "life should mean life" for sex offenders and have endorsed the News of the World's actions every step of the way. The girl's mother, Sara, said: "We think anyone who causes harm to a child in this way must be taken out of the community for life."

webTitle: CJD: the news improves, but the mystery remains

fields.headline: CJD: the news improves, but the mystery remains
fields.standfirst: The latest research reveals how little we really know about Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), writes science editor Tim Radford
fields.trailText: Thursday, 2.15pm: The latest research reveals how little we really know about Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), writes science editor Tim Radford.
fields.body:
The air is full of good news about the dreadful new disease, variant CJD (vCJD). There are now likely to be no more than 136,000 deaths in a worse-case scenario, down from the 500,000 previously estimated by a European committee set up to study its causes, and there could be a good deal fewer.

It all depends on the "mean incubation period" for the disease, according to the Wellcome Trust Centre for Epidemiology of Infectious Diseases at Oxford University in a letter to Nature magazine.

However, this statement exposes how little we know about CJD. Would the "incubation period" be less than 20 years for most people? If so, the number of deaths will be dramatically fewer than even the new estimate.

Or is it on average 60 years or more, the period on which the revised estimate is based? If so, we can expect it to claim more victims, although perhaps not as many as were thought a year ago.

The original version of disease itself is for the most part a riddle: roughly one in a million cases, anywhere in the world, vegetarians or meat eaters. It was, however, a disease of that appeared to be restricted to the elderly.

The new variant - the one linked with Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE) and thought to be contracted by eating part of an animal contaminated with BSE, or "mad cow" disease - is however, so far a disease of the young.

That too, raises a number of questions: How is it contracted? Is it something to do with being young? Or is it contacted from what the young eat? How indeed, did British cows get it?

The cows may have consumed baked and rendered infected animal carcasses. But if the disease is spread by eating, then its agent has to survive cooking, digestion, and then travel from the stomach to the brain.

How does it do that? How much infected beef needs to be consumed to contract the disease? And how many infected cattle have entered the food chain since the disease began? Which parts of the beast are the most infectious? When controls were first imposed, how well were they observed?

BSE first appeared in about 1986: for a while, British government ministers tried to pretend it posed no threat. Indeed, pet-food manufacturers were the first to act, banning the use of the cattle's eyes, brains, spleens, tonsils and so on in their products a year before the government banned them in food earmarked for human consumption, in 1990.

Zoo animals such as kudu, oryx, ocelot and elk which that fed infected food began to contract BSE, but the government still protested that the disease could not cross a species barrier to harm humans.

Only in 1996, with the first horrifying evidence of a new kind of CJD very like the bovine version, did the government act. But by then, an epidemic was inevitable.

The statisticians at Oxford are doing what they can: They look at the pattern of events, construct possible scenarios and categorise them by in order of probability. Next year they will know a bit more, and with each ensuing year they will have clearer projections of what lies ahead.

With luck, each year the expected toll will fall. But that still won't be good news: There is no cure, no vaccine and no way for consumers to protect against its contraction. It is a wretched way to die.

But however many cases are to come, vCJD will always seem like the disease that need never have happened.

fields.headline: Chelsea
fields.trailText: This time last year, half of Fleet Street was predicting swinging Chelsea for the Premiership. Yet twelve months later Gianluca Vialli's team are strangely out of fashion, replaced in the affections of the press and public by younger, sexier teams, like Liverpool and Leeds.
fields.body:
This time last year, half of Fleet Street was predicting swinging Chelsea for the Premiership. Yet twelve months later Gianluca Vialli's team are strangely out of fashion, replaced in the affections of the press and public by younger, sexier teams, like Liverpool and Leeds.

Chelsea, it seems, are yesterday's news. But why? If anything they have stronger squad than last year.

Crucially, Vialli has addressed his side's most obvious problem: the lack of a natural goalscorer. Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink has never received the credit his record deserves - he's been labelled as lazy and selfish and was even left out of Holland's Euro 2000 squad - but he consistently scores 20+ goals a season, something Chelsea have been crying out for since the mid-90s.

And, cleverly, Vialli has also signed up Eidur Gudjohnsen, who is raw but powerful in a Emile Heskey kind of way. When Flo's intricate flicks aren't doing the trick, the Icelandic striker can add a bit of muscle up front.

In midfield, Chelsea are arguably better - and certainly more balanced - too. Last season Deschamps and Wise adopted almost identikit holding roles, and didn't make runs into the box. This year, a Wise and Jody Morris combination - provided the later eases back on the booze and the burgers - will not only be good for Chelsea, but it will help the youngster's England prospects too. And with Stanic on the right and Poyet on the left the midfield should ooze goals.

Then there's the defence. For the past two years Chelsea have finished up with the second best defensive record in the Premiership. And while Leboeuf's defending and De Goey confidence at coming for crosses is often rightly questioned, the fact remains that they have Desailly, who is - when he wants to be - the best defender in the world. And according to reports he'll soon be joined by Internazionale's Christian Panucci.

All this makes a strong case for Chelsea being in a great position to finally smash the hegemony of Manchester United and Arsenal. So why haven't we all tipped them for the title?

Put it down to mystery factor X: their lack of motivation. Because too often Chelsea are wonderful then woeful. They can beat the best sides in Europe one week and then get bashed up by Sunderland the next.

Maybe this season will be different. Maybe Gianluca Vialli will get his side to battle in every game, Leboeuf will be tighter in defence, and Stanic will prove he's worth £5.6m. And maybe, without the distraction of the Champions League, the foreign stars will be more focused too. But that's just too many maybes to be completely confident in backing Chelsea to go all the way. They will come close though.

In J-F Hasselbaink (A Madrid), Eidur Gudjohnsen (Bolton), Mario Stanic (Parma), Carlo Cudicini (Castel D.S.), Sebastien Kniessel (Eintracht Frankfurt).

Out Chris Sutton (Celtic), Kyle Shepphard (Bristol City), Neil Clement (West Brom), Dan Petrescu (Bradford).

Odds: 6-1

Football Unlimited writers' prediction: 3rd

Agree? Disagree? Want to beat our pundits around the head with a meat pie? Send us your opinion at the.boss@theguardian.com.

All this makes a strong case for Chelsea being in a great position to finally smash the hegemony of Manchester United and Arsenal. So why haven't we all tipped them for the title? Put it down to mystery factor X: their lack of motivation. Because too often Chelsea are wonderful then woeful. They can beat the best sides in Europe one week and then get bashed up by Sunderland the next. Maybe this season will be different. Maybe Gianluca Vialli will get his side to battle in every game, Leboeuf will be tighter in defence, and Stanic will prove he's worth £5.6m. And maybe, without the distraction of the Champions League, the foreign stars will be more focused too. But that's just too many maybes to be completely confident in backing Chelsea to go all the way. They will come close though. fields.headline: Charlton Athletic
fields.trailText: Relegation wasn't the only unpleasant experience Alan Curbishley enjoyed the last time Charlton graced the Premiership. The back-handed praise his team received that year - "my, aren't they brave?" - would have stuck in the craw of an ambitious man in charge of an ambitious club. So this year the Charlton boss will not simply want to avoid the drop - he'll also want his team to avoid attracting the same well-meaning but essentially patronising praise again.
fields.body:
Relegation wasn't the only unpleasant experience Alan Curbishley enjoyed the last time Charlton graced the Premiership. The back-handed praise his team received that year - "my, aren't they brave?" - would have stuck in the craw of an ambitious man in charge of an ambitious club. So this year the Charlton boss will not simply want to avoid the drop - he'll also want his team to avoid attracting the same well-meaning but essentially patronising praise again.

Of course, the reason Charlton spent most of the 1998-99 season being patted on the head was because they dared to play good football. Sadly - like Barnsley and Swindon before them - they didn't do it well enough to survive. Curbishley has admirably (foolishly?) decided to stick to his principles, despite seeing Bradford achieve what his team couldn't manage by scrapping and battling to the death. But this time a couple of judicious signings may make a crucial difference.

Claus Jensen, newly arrived from Bolton, will take some of the creative burden away from Mark Kinsella and John Robinson. Charlton's dependable midfield duo aren't short of a trick or two - both can put their foot on the ball and play - but the one-time Liverpool target can ping the ball around with the best of them and will add extra guile to their midfield. Jensen likes to get forward as well - Charlton will be more than happy if he matches last season's return of six league goals in 42 starts.

Mind you, goals shouldn't be too much of a problem: the unheralded signing of Jonatan Johansson from Rangers for £3.75m fee was perhaps the most astute piece of business done by any Premiership club this summer. Johansson never established himself in the first team at Ibrox, but his record of a goal every three games is more than impressive when you consider over half his appearances were as substitute.

With Graham Stuart and Martin Pringle on hand to chip in, Charlton are far from toothless. Which is just as well, because despite the addition of ball-playing Bulgarian Radostin Kishishev, their defence remains a problem - Curbishley hasn't spent all summer trying to tempt Michael Duberry to the Valley for nothing. So with the lack of a truly commanding presence at the back, Charlton fans better get used to the sight of Dean Kiely or new recruit Ben Roberts picking the ball out of the net at regular intervals.

There'll no doubt be a real thrashing or two along the way. But that's as far as the heartache will go. The rest of the team is good enough to prop up a creaking defence, so expect the Addicks to survive - even if it's just by the skin of their brave, brave teeth.

In Ben Roberts (Middlesbrough), Claus Jensen (Bolton Wanderers), Jonatan Johansson (Rangers)

Out Keith Jones (Reading), Anthony Barness (Bolton), Simon Royce (Leicester), Sam Turner (Stockport)

Odds 750-1

Football Unlimited writers' prediction 17th
