Guzman's case rests on a series of arguments that the Chilean Supreme Court has now not only accepted but reinforced. This week's decision is an important step forward in the painful process of putting Chile's legal system to rights after the systematic distortion of justice that took place under Pinochet's dictatorship. The first hurdle that Guzman had to overcome was the amnesty law that Pinochet had passed to insure himself and others against the possibility of ever facing justice. Decree law 2191, personally drafted by the then justice minister, Monica Madariaga, a relative of Pinochet's, was published on April 19 1978. It exculpates from criminal responsibility anyone who committed crimes, was an accomplice in crimes or covered up crimes between the day of the coup and March 10 1978. It is still in force. The list of crimes that the amnesty law pardons offers an illuminating glimpse of the methods employed by Pinochet's security forces: falsification and cheque swindles, for instance, are pardoned, along with all crimes committed by public employees through the exercise of their office, except for fraud. Homicide and physical injury are pardoned along with property damage, abortion, the abandonment of minors and, curiously, bigamy. Technically, the law applied to crimes committed by the regime's opponents as well as its servants and its stated purpose was to reunite a divided nation. Some 69 political prisoners were released under its provisions, but the impression of even-handedness was a fig leaf. Most of the beneficiaries were the members of the security services who had committed crimes against humanity. Such few human rights cases as had been accepted by the criminal courts were promptly handed over to the military system of justice - a network greatly expanded by Pinochet for the purpose - where the amnesty law was applied wholesale. The law was challenged, though, in 1986, when Ana Luisa Gonzalez filed a criminal suit for the premeditated abduction and homicide of her son, 17-year-old Jose Gregorio Saavedra Gonzalez. Jose had been president of his high school student body association and was in prison in Calama on October 19 1973, when General Starck's helicopter touched down. General Starck was an enthusiast for the coup - in fact, he persuaded an initially reluctant General Pinochet to lend it his support. He was an ideal man, therefore, to entrust with the Caravan of Death and had no scruples about ordering the 17-year-old to be murdered, along with 25 others. Like the families of 18 other victims of the Caravan of Death, Jose's family has never recovered his remains. Mrs Gonzalez argued in 1986 that the crime of abduction is expressly excluded from the amnesty law because, until the victim or his remains are found, the crime is ongoing. The military courts promptly claimed jurisdiction and applied the amnesty law. Mrs Gonzalez had not achieved justice, but the principle she had argued survived and has been used by Judge Guzman as a key element in his strategy. Judge Guzman's second stroke of luck was a matter of evidence. Like other mass murderers before him, Pinochet has not left a paper trail linking himself to his crimes. No written orders have come to light from Pinochet to his subordinates ordering them to carry out arbitrary detentions, torture and killings. But the events of the Caravan of Death do provide a direct link. The 72 victims who fell on each stop of General Starck's helicopter convoy were largely connected with the copper mines - trade unionists, mine workers, engineers, mine managers. Many had reported voluntarily to the military bases when they were called in after the coup to be relieved of their jobs, only to find themselves imprisoned. Chile's armed forces, it is easy to forget, were at the time seen as less prone to the overthrow of democracy than many others in Latin America. It had been a matter of some pride in Chile that democracy had deeper roots than elsewhere on the continent. It was a matter of pride, too, to many of the officers. So when General Starck arrived and ordered that prisoners be shot without trial, he occasionally encountered some resistance from constitutionally minded officers in charge of the jails. They demanded to know on whose orders such atrocities were to be committed. General Starck answered that he had the authority of the supreme commander, no less - thus supplying Judge Guzman with a vital link in the chain of evidence. Pinochet's next defence, his immunity as a self-appointed senator-for-life, was perhaps the gravest insult to Chile's still partial return to democracy, however much Chile's elected representatives might struggle to live with this stroke of realpolitik. Whatever the final outcome of Judge Guzman's case, the supreme court, by a majority of 14 to six, has restored both dignity and credibility to Chilean democracy and for that alone must be applauded. It remains to be seen how many heads of the Pinochet hydra still have life in them. It is still open for a military court to claim the case, but since the supreme court has ruled that the amnesty law does not apply, that option is neither as quick nor as convenient as it used to be. The head of the armed forces has been quick to express his support for Pinochet, but otherwise there is little the military is able - or is prepared - to do to affect the judicial process. The case will take its course. The mental health of the general must now be examined, though his family are presently refusing to permit what they term an "indignity". To that, Judge Guzman replies that nobody is above the law. Until this week in Chile, that principle was more dishonoured than respected. Today, at least it has a chance.

fields.headline: Inspector angers 'selfish' prison staff
fields.standfirst: Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: Prison warders were accused yesterday of selfishness in sidelining inmates' safety for the sake of bettering their pay and conditions, in a report by the chief inspector of prisons.
fields.body:
Prison warders were accused yesterday of selfishness in sidelining inmates' safety for the sake of bettering their pay and conditions, in a report by the chief inspector of prisons.

Sir David Ramsbotham said that vulnerable prisoners at Lindholme, in South Yorkshire, had been exposed to bullying and even the risk of suicide because of "militant" staff refusing to experiment with different rotas and increased patrols.

In a strongly-worded report, noting dismal progress in carrying out recommendations made after his visit to Lindholme four years ago, Sir David accused the Prison Officers' Association of putting its own "ease and comfort" first.

He said: "I am well aware that there are two sides to every issue, but the POA at Lindholme has only itself to blame for its attitude being questioned, because of its long record of militancy."

The attack brought an equally sharp reaction from the union. It described the criticisms as "asinine" and wholly adrift from realities at the grade C prison at a former RAF base on isolated moorland east of Doncaster.

Ron Adams, vice chairman of the POA, described the comments made by Sir David, who is reluctantly standing down from his post later this year, as "inaccurate, misleading and an affront".

Mr Adams claimed that working arrangements at Lindholme were sanctioned by the prison's management, which enjoyed a good working relationship with staff.

"The inferences made by Sir David that POA members at Lindholme would knowingly put inmates at risk are scandalous," he said. "At prisons throughout the UK, including Lindholme, POA members put their own safety at risk to protect inmates.

"His comments are designed solely to catch headlines, and are not worthy of someone in such a responsible position. It appears his use of language is chosen just to continue to inflate his already swollen ego to hitherto unprecedented proportions."

Sir David was unapologetic about the report, which detailed the POA's refusal even to increase nightly patrols in outlying parts of the prison from two a night to three.

The attack comes at a time when relations between the officers' union and the prison service agency management have reached a nadir, following the announcement of industrial action by staff over the proposed privatisation of Brixton jail.

The prisons minister at the Home Office, Paul Boateng, rounded on the union last week after a report compared industrial relations in the service to the worst days of the British car industry in the 1960s.

He said: "The prison service cannot be some sort of Jurassic Park, some sort of lost world in which dinosaurs roam, while the rest of the world moves on and passes by."

fields.headline: Belgian judge forbids naming campaign
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: An emergency injunction forbidding the publication of a list of suspected or convicted paedophiles was yesterday issued against a Luxembourg weekly paper.
fields.body:
An emergency injunction forbidding the publication of a list of suspected or convicted paedophiles was yesterday issued against a Luxembourg weekly paper.

The injunction was issued after the News of the World threatened to relaunch its own naming and shaming campaign unless the British government gave parents access to information about local paedophiles.

The Belgian judge found that publication of the list in L' investigateur would be an abuse of human rights and the presumption of innocence. Jean Nicolas, editor of L' investigateur, was warned he would face a fine of £15,000 a copy if he refused to comply with the order. But Mr Nicolas said last night the ruling had been issued too late and he was helpless to stop the names and birth dates of 102 convicted or suspected paedophiles from entering the public domain.

He said his paper, distributed via the internet and through subscription sales, was due to arrive this morning in Belgian subscribers' mail.

The debate about paedophiles is particularly sensitive in Belgium. In the country's most notorious sex crime case Marc Dutroux, a convicted child rapist, has been in custody since 1996 awaiting trial on charges of abducting, raping, torturing and murdering four young girls.

webTitle: Portillo 'failed to register public speaking fees'

fields.headline: Portillo 'failed to register public speaking fees'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Shadow Chancellor Michael Portillo is accused of failing to register all his earnings from public speaking, it was reported today.
fields.body:
Shadow Chancellor Michael Portillo is accused of failing to register all his earnings from public speaking, it was reported today.

Labour backbencher Chris Leslie has written to Parliamentary Standards Commissioner Elizabeth Filkin, asking her to look into the question of Mr Portillo's outside earnings, The Independent newspaper reported. In the Register of Members' Interests, Mr Portillo lists an unspecified income from "occasional fees for journalism, broadcasting and speaking".

MPs are required to register full details of outside earnings for services linked to their position in Parliament, lodging written employment agreements for any activities such as speaking, TV appearances or newspaper columns which are "frequent" rather than "occasional".

Mr Leslie's complaint to Ms Filkin revolves around allegations that Mr Portillo gave several after-dinner speeches to audiences of businessmen for fees of as much as £5,000 a time.

Mr Portillo could not be reached for comment last night, and a Conservative Party spokesman said that the party had no comment to make on the complaint.

It comes hot on the heels of a complaint to Ms Filkin by Mr Portillo's frontbench colleague Angela Browning about Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy's earnings from after-dinner speaking.

Ms Browning, shadow trade and industry secretary, described allegations that Mr Kennedy had not registered his earnings from this source as "a matter of grave concern".

Asked about that complaint yesterday morning, Mr Kennedy told BBC Radio 4's Today programme said that he was seeking clarification of what requirement there was to register fees for speaking.

He added: "I am very interested the Conservatives have chosen to try and make an issue of this. "One assumes therefore there is no question of any senior parliamentary Conservative accepting the occasional outside speaking engagement."

fields.headline: McManaman stirs Everton interest
fields.trailText: Steve McManaman has been offered the chance to return to his native Merseyside but in the colours of Everton rather than Liverpool.
fields.body:
Steve McManaman has been offered the chance to return to his native Merseyside but in the colours of Everton rather than Liverpool.

The Real Madrid and England midfielder's future was cast into the melting pot earlier this week when the coach of the European champions, Vicente del Bosque, announced that McManaman is now surplus to requirements.

The issue of his availability was discussed by Everton's board on Monday and the manager Walter Smith was informed that money would be made available to fund a bid, if he so wished. McManaman, however, is adamant that he still sees his future overseas.

McManaman, 28 and an Everton fan as a boy, joined Real from Liverpool on a Bosman free 12 months ago but would be available for around £7m.

fields.headline: Liverpool in limbo over 'swaying' stand
fields.trailText: Liverpool were last night contemplating closure of part of their ground for the start of the season following claims that the Anfield Road stand is unsafe.
fields.body:
Liverpool were last night contemplating closure of part of their ground for the start of the season following claims that the Anfield Road stand is unsafe.

A possible design fault has been found in the upper tier of the stand, according to today's edition of the trade paper Construction News, and the club have been ordered by Liverpool City Council to file a report as soon as possible.

The alarm was raised after Ronnie Moran's testimonial in May, when there were allegations that the stand's upper tier was swaying while occupied by boisterous Celtic fans.

Construction News suggests it may be a similar problem to the one which forced London's Millennium Bridge to be closed earlier this year a few days after opening. Liverpool's first home game is against Bradford on Saturday week.

An upper tier was added to the Anfield Road stand in 1997 to increase its capacity to 10,000 and, though Liverpool have been issued with a safety certificate for the season, they have been in talks with builders and designers all summer.

fields.headline: Black leader suspended for anti-semitic Lieberman slur
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: A senior member of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) has been suspended for making anti-semitic remarks in the wake of Al Gore's choice of Joseph Lieberman as his presidential running-mate. The remarks were condemned by the leadership of the NAACP as "anti-American"   and the suspension was swift.
fields.body:
A senior member of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) has been suspended for making anti-semitic remarks in the wake of Al Gore's choice of Joseph Lieberman as his presidential running-mate. The remarks were condemned by the leadership of the NAACP as "anti-American" and the suspension was swift.

The head of the Dallas branch of the oldest and most influential black organisation in the country, Lee Alcorn, told a Dallas radio station, KHVN: "If we get a Jew person then what I'm wondering is... what is this movement for? Does it have anything to do with the failed peace talks?"

Mr Alcorn continued: "We need to be very suspicious of any kind of partnership between the Jews at that kind of level because we know that their interest primarily has to do with money and these kind of things."

Kweisi Mfume, the national head of the NAACP, responded immediately by faxing Mr Alcorn a suspension order which will be in effect until an inquiry has been carried out. Mr Mfume said later that Mr Alcorn did not speak for either the NAACP board or any of its membership and his remarks had been both "anti-semitic and anti-American".

As the row grew, Mr Alcorn claimed that his remarks had been taken out of context and that he was not anti-semitic but only anti-Lieberman. "I don't see where he has been a champion for African-American concerns," he said.

Mr Alcorn's remarks were in contrast to those of the outspoken Rev Al Sharpton who told the political television show Hardball on Tuesday night that the appointment of Mr Lieberman was to be welcomed as a positive step.

There has been a rash of anti-semitic messages posted on the internet in the wake of Mr Lieberman's appointment and America Online has taken action to close down a number of sites.

As the news of the suspension emerged, Mr Gore and Mr Lieberman were heading for Atlanta, where they will pay a joint tribute to the work of Martin Luther King, a move which was seen as a sign to the African-American community.

fields.headline: Floundering Lancashire sunk before sundown
fields.standfirst:
Lancashire Lightning 68
Yorkshire Phoenix 72-1
Yorkshire win by nine wickets
fields.trailText:
Lancashire Lightning 68
Yorkshire Phoenix 72-1
Yorkshire win by nine wickets .
fields.body:
Defeat of any description in a Roses encounter is sufficient indignity but being bowled out for a record lowest one-day total while remaining nailed to the foot of the First Division in the National League made for much wringing of Lancashire hands at Headingley.

So abject was Lancashire's display that the game was over in 37.2 overs and before 7.30pm with the floodlights unnecessary.

"It was a slow pitch but there was nothing much wrong with it and our batting was simply terrible," said their captain John Crawley. "There are no excuses and we have got to pull ourselves together if we are to avoid relegation."

A score of 68 in only 23.3 overs represented Lancashire's lowest total in this form of cricket, three runs fewer than they made against Essex at Chelmsford in 1987.

They were destroyed in ruthless fashion by Matthew Hoggard and the England all- rounder Craig White, who took seven wickets between them. Hoggard took three for 15, his best figures in this competition, in a brilliant nine-over spell which began when he bowled Crawley for three and continued with the wickets of Sourav Ganguly and Ian Austin.

White came on as first change and ripped through to take four for 14, also his best return in the competition. White accounted for Graham Lloyd and Joe Scuderi in his first over and Lancashire contributed to their downfall by having Neil Fairbrother and Greg Chapple run out.

Lancashire's only fire came from Andrew Flintoff, who managed four boundaries in a spirited 28 from 44 balls before he was bowled aiming another big blow at White.

Austin removed the opener Vic Craven in his first over, leaving the stage to Darren Lehmann, who was leading Yorkshire in the absence of David Byas through injury.

The Australian left-hander lashed eight fours in a masterly 54 not out from 43 balls as Yorkshire reached the target in less than 14 overs.

webTitle: Swann turns it off and on for Northants

fields.headline: Brown and Swann on song
fields.standfirst:
Sussex 232
Northamptonshire 23-0
fields.trailText:
Sussex 232
Northamptonshire 23-0
fields.body:
The Second Division table resembles a grand prix grid right now. There are several poised to take advantage if those near the front slip up. Yesterday, before the start of this game between the leaders and Sussex, the team in second place, 13 points covered the top seven.

Northamptonshire are a team in form, having won three of their past four matches; and, as pitches dry out, their off-spinners Graeme Swann and Jason Brown are beginning to make an impact.

Brown in particular has been troubling the division's finest. He had taken 35 wickets in five games before winkling out another four yesterday on a surface that will keep slow bowlers interested throughout the match.

Sussex can be thankful that they won the toss and will not have to bat last. Wasim Khan, playing his first championship match of the season, ensured they at least have something to defend. Replacing Michael Bevan, who is away on international duty with Australia, he laboured 74 overs for 74. None of his colleagues reached 30.

The opening hour had the feeling of a phoney battle while the shine was taken off the new ball, although Richard Montgomerie contrived to miss a straight delivery and was leg-before to Darren Cousins.

Brown was introduced after 17 overs and six overs later he and Swann were bowling in tandem. Swann's fifth delivery turned sharply, beat Toby Peirce's outside edge and knocked out his off stump - not a bad way to impress the on-looking England selector Geoff Miller.

Chris Adams' arrival at the crease then provided the cue for the day's most intriguing passage of play.

The Sussex captain was immediately confronted by a six/three offside field which included three men on the boundary, at deep cover, long on and deep backward square, and two close catchers, at slip and silly point. Both Swann and Brown gave the ball air and persevered with a line wide of off stump.

There was no obvious outlet for a batsman who aims to be positive and relishes finding the boundary rope. His scoring was restricted to eight singles, a two and then another single before, from his 35th ball, he was bowled off the inside edge trying to defend a delivery from Swann which spun into him. It was an intelligently conceived plan and it will be fascinating to see how he copes with it in the second innings.

The new batsman, Tony Cottey, had clearly been considering his own approach while waiting in the pavilion. He was bold enough to sweep his fourth and fifth deliveries to the boundary in the final over before lunch and then to follow them with another over the head of square leg soon after the resumption.

His promising innings had a tame ending, however. He was caught behind aiming a tentative prod at a ball from Cousins, who went on to sort out the tail after Brown had accounted for the middle order.

Both Swann and Brown gave the ball air and persevered with a line wide of off stump. There was no obvious outlet for a batsman who aims to be positive and relishes finding the boundary rope. His scoring was restricted to eight singles, a two and then another single before, from his 35th ball, he was bowled off the inside edge trying to defend a delivery from Swann which spun into him. It was an intelligently conceived plan and it will be fascinating to see how he copes with it in the second innings. The new batsman, Tony Cottey, had clearly been considering his own approach while waiting in the pavilion. He was bold enough to sweep his fourth and fifth deliveries to the boundary in the final over before lunch and then to follow them with another over the head of square leg soon after the resumption. His promising innings had a tame ending, however. He was caught behind aiming a tentative prod at a ball from Cousins, who went on to sort out the tail after Brown had accounted for the middle order.

fields.headline: Aymes shames his peers
fields.standfirst:
Leicestershire 266 & 42-0
Hampshire 228
fields.trailText:
Leicestershire 266 & 42-0
Hampshire 228
fields.body:
Adrian Aymes's renown in these parts stems largely from a post-match grooming ritual that would make Yves St Laurent seem the epitome of slobbishness. There is also a growing feeling that he is the one Hampshire batsman who can be relied on to do something other than sell his wicket for a song. Conviction hardened yesterday on the second day of this First Division match.

A glance at the visitors' attack was sufficient to infuse even the most sceptical Hampshire followers with a modicum of expectation. In place of Anil Kumble, Phil DeFreitas, Chris Lewis and James Ormond, all laid low by one malady or another, loomed the combined might of Jon Dakin, Scott Boswell, Carl Crowe and Dominic Williamson, collectively responsible for 111 first-class victims at 38.90 and only 14 this summer. Given a season-long funk yielding one batting point per game, they ought to have known better.

Boswell and Dakin, who shared the new ball, would make a spiffing pair of All Black locks, and the home batsmen appeared suitably intimidated. Dakin, a fitful presence despite leading the national batting averages for much of the term, responded admirably to responsibility. Generating plenty of zip, he ejected both openers in his first four overs, inducing Giles White to chop on, then pinning Derek Kenway.

Boswell joined in the fun, hitting Will Kendall's off-stump and having Jason Laney taken at slip by the diving Vince Wells. Williamson sentenced Robin Smith to an identical fate, defeating a forward defensive that would not have been out of place in a coaching manual, provided the ball was Tippexed out.

At 72 for five, the follow-on still 44 runs distant, Hampshire appeared to be up a creek, even more so when Boswell struck Aymes a painful blow on the right hand - vexing indeed with the NatWest semi-final three days away.

At last, though, came signs of resistance. Emboldened by last week's maiden century, Dmitri Mascarenhas launched a series of audacious biffs that reflected his Asian roots as the sixth-wicket pair added 52. Regrettably, prudence eluded him as he drove over a full-length offering from Wells.

When John Stephenson skied an off-break from Crowe to extra cover, Aymes' disgust could be imagined, though the fates had been kind to him: on 29 a sharp chance in Crowe's first over escaped short leg. Shaun Udal proved an able accomplice before Boswell went round the wicket and drew an immediate edge to Neil Burns. The advent of Alex Morris, however, heralded the day's most substantial alliance.

In his first such outing since shin problems flared in May, Morris had occasionally reminded onlookers why he has been touted as a Test seamer. Now he emphasised that he is no mug with the bat.

After nearly 3 hours of grit and graft it took something special to unglue Aymes, Burns changing direction to clasp an inside edge. Aymes, who had made 71, punched his bat in frustration; that he resisted the urge to do likewise to his purported superiors says much for his self-control.

webTitle: Pollard ton points way for Hussain

fields.headline: Pollard ton points way for Hussain
fields.standfirst:
Worcestershire 302
Essex 35-1
fields.trailText:
Worcestershire 302
Essex 35-1
fields.body:
The Chester Road ground, cold and blustery with a cortege of black clouds passing every few minutes as if in mourning for the lost summer, looked the sort of place where a batsman might lose his form rather than find it.

But it is here, in this Second Division match, that the England captain Nasser Hussain has come in the hope of ending a sorry sequence that has brought him 134 runs in 12 first-class innings this season.

He is nine not out from 22 deliveries, having shuffled uneasily to the wicket at 6.09 when Essex lost the wicket of Paul Grayson in the second over. In response to Worcestershire's total of 302 Essex were 35 for one at the end of the first day.

There was swing and a little seam movement. But essentially this is a good pitch and one where Hussain could prosper today. Essex certainly hope so. Loftier issues aside, this is an important Second Division fixture.

Judging by the way Paul Pollard played here yesterday Hussain might have found the right place to rediscover his touch. When it comes to losing form Pollard has been one of the most absent-minded batsmen around. He is always putting it down somewhere and forgetting about it.

There are some at Worcester who were beginning to suspect that he forgot to pack it after Nottinghamshire released him at the end of the 1998 season. He moved to New Road last year.

Last season Pollard scored 377 at an average of 19.84, although he missed much of the season through injury. He made another disappointing start this season. But the left-hander, signed as an opening batsman, has looked the part in recent weeks when he has played down the order.

In his 14th first-class season he scored his 14th century yesterday. And it was a good one. This is not the most attractive of players, as one would expect from someone who has spent much of his professional career in tandem with Tim Robinson.

Here, though, he played some fine strokes. He came to the wicket with Worcestershire 17 for three, which must have reminded Hussain of England's recent score at Old Trafford.

They had lost Elliott Wilson, caught behind for five. And in the next over Graeme Hick, who made one, was bowled by a ball from Ronnie Irani that nipped back and which he made no attempt to play until it was too late. Then Philip Weston was lbw in the 10th over.

It was not only Pollard's runs which damaged Essex. One stroke had Paul Prichard, who was fielding at square leg, running from the field with a dislocated left thumb. The batsman hurt the spinner Peter Such's pride even more, hitting him for a straight six that went out of the ground and on to the nearby rail track.

He also hit 18 fours in his unbeaten 123 from 248 balls, reaching his century with an extra-cover drive for four off Grayson. He put on 92 with Vikram Solanki (55) and then 124 in 30 overs with David Leatherdale (52). At the end Pollard was betrayed by Worcestershire's tail. Their bowlers seemed impatient for a chance to bowl at Essex - and Hussain.

webTitle: No state, no cash, but Somalis clear Olympic hurdles

fields.headline: No state, no cash, but Somalis clear Olympic hurdles
fields.standfirst: Special report: Sydney Olympics
fields.trailText: When 203 countries take the field for the opening ceremony of the Olympics next month, one team of athletes will march somewhere near the back of the procession, carrying a blue flag embossed with a white star.
fields.body:
When 203 countries take the field for the opening ceremony of the Olympics next month, one team of athletes will march somewhere near the back of the procession, carrying a blue flag embossed with a white star.

Few will recognise the flag or know anything about the country it represents.

They will not know that it has been devastated by 10 years of civil war between clan warlords, and they will have no idea of the obstacles these seven athletes had to overcome to get there.

The country they represent is the only one in the world without a government - stateless and ungoverned since 1991 - and its athletes will compete in memory of the hundreds of thousands of their fellow countrymen who have died in the ongoing conflict.

"The world has forgotten us and our suffering," said Abdullahi Turabi, secretary general of the Somali Olympic Committee (SOC). "But by going to the Games we are asking them to remember us. To remember Somalia."

Abukar Mohammed will compete in the marathon. He says the number of family and friends he has lost is "uncountable".

"I will be thinking of them when I compete in Sydney."

Abukar, 19, already has the sinewy form of a long-distance runner. He is bursting with talent, but Somalia's ruinous state means that the SOC can offer him little more than moral support.

He took up athletics just over a year ago, when a coach spotted him training for a football match and asked him to come back the following week and take part in a race.

Abukar won the race and was selected to represent Somalia at the Pan-Arab Games in Jordan last year.

But on the day of the marathon he was given a pair of ill-fitting sprinting spikes and was injured, though he does not blame it on the shoes. Because he had no access to doctors or physiotherapists, he had to pull out of the All Africa Games two months later.

With the support of the International Olympic Committee, the SOC is able to send the athletes to the games, but that is about as far as their financial support goes.

"We have no champions, no facilities and no government to assist us financially. All we have is hope," said Mr Turabi.

Mire Omar, a member of the SOC, added: "For most countries, sport is a luxury. But here in Somalia we use it as a medicine to help us cure the disease of war."

It is not just ill-fitting shoes and the lack of the most basic facilities that the athletes must contend with. Safiya Hussein, the only female member of the team, has also had to overcome the prejudice of a male-dominated society.

"One day when I was at the stadium training, some old men came up to me and tried to chase me away. 'It is demeaning for a woman to put on trousers and run in the street,' they said. 'Why don't you stay at home and do the sweeping and cooking'."

Safiya will be running the 400 metres at Sydney, but recognises that, like the rest of the team, she has little chance of surviving beyond the first round of heats. But the team's achievement lies in getting there and flying the flag.

"Whatever they manage to achieve, to us they are the magnificent seven," Mr Turabi said proudly.

fields.headline: Paedophiles close to home
fields.trailText: When she was eight years old, like Sarah Payne, my daughter was raped, buggered, and strangled till she lost consciousness. Unlike Sarah, she survived and the man was arrested the same day, but it is just chance that she lived and Sarah died.
fields.body:
When she was eight years old, like Sarah Payne, my daughter was raped, buggered, and strangled till she lost consciousness. Unlike Sarah, she survived and the man was arrested the same day, but it is just chance that she lived and Sarah died.

The man lived over 10 miles away - he'd come on a bus - so even if there had been community notification of paedophiles, we wouldn't have known of him (Vigilante target kills himself, August 9). Even if there had been general access to a list of paedophiles we still wouldn't have known of him - he'd never done it before. He must subsequently have been placed on a list of paedophiles, but this couldn't have helped anybody: I heard he committed suicide while in prison for the offence. I'm not even convinced he was a paedophile: he was married with two children, was depressed (he had had to be talked down from a roof from which he was threatening to jump shortly before), and was very drunk at the time it happened.

Those are the facts for my family. Before further decisions are made about publishing the names, addresses and photographs of those who have murdered children who were strangers to them, or made really serious sexual assaults upon children, could we please be told the similar facts about all cases that have occurred within the last five or 10 years? Then we the public will be in a position to make an informed judgment as to whether lists should be available to all, with the risks of lynchings taking place on the guilty or by mistake on the innocent, or only to the police and to headteachers and others when they need to know.

Name and address supplied

 My friend Ted was a low-risk paedophile, not a pouncer nor a predator, but a man who, when in drink, played "touching games" with small boys, the sort of games most boys play at some time behind the bike sheds. But when sober, which was most of the time, he was a model citizen.

He served a few prison sentences and each time, when he came out, the word went round among the local boys that if Ted had had a drink, he was good for a pound or two. They knocked at his door, put inviting notes through the letterbox, and on one occasion he appealed to the police to drive them away. But inevitably the day came when he'd been drinking and they got their "pocket money".

Since imprisonment was getting nowhere, a constructive attempt was made to help him. He was found a flat where no one knew his background, a senior probation officer kept him under strict supervision, a medical specialist took him on for treatment and a group of friends kept in close touch with him personally and by telephone. He lived alone: there were often times when he needed support in his struggle to control his problem.

And he did. He lived for another six years and he never reoffended. Were he alive now, all that dedicated professional and comradely support could count for nothing. A useful experiment in a different way of handling such a man would be negated. He would certainly try to disappear. And it occurs to me that at the moment naughty boys all over the country must be making a fortune - just like the News of the World.

Margery Parker
Westleton, Suffolk

 The sole remaining shreds of moral justification were surely stripped away by the comment from the News of the World's spokesperson following the suicide of James White, who had admitted his offences and was prepared to accept whatever punishment was to be meted out to him by the proper authorities: "We did not specifically name him therefore this case has nothing whatsoever to do with the News of the World."

David Hughes
Trowbridge, Wilts

webTitle: Intelligent pebble to fathom tidal secrets

fields.headline: Intelligent pebble to fathom tidal secrets
fields.trailText: It is the thinking man's rolling stone. It will not gather moss. But it will go with the flow and gather data on the way.
fields.body:
It is the thinking man's rolling stone. It will not gather moss. But it will go with the flow and gather data on the way.

The world's first intelligent pebble is about to be tested on a beach and in two rivers by scientists from Southampton and Lancaster universities. The stone will serve as a tool to help hydraulics engineers understand how coasts erode and rivers scour their beds.

Each knock on the pebble - which is made of resin - will be recorded on a microchip inside it. Researchers will bury wires into the riverbed or beach they want to study, put smart pebbles in the water and send signals down the wires.

A receiver in the pebble will record the signals, and their relative strengths, which will vary as the pebbles move across the space between the wires. When the experiment is over, the scientists will send a signal which will set the pebble resonating - so that it will not be lost among all the other pebbles on the beach.

"Once we have found the pebble we plug the chip into a computer so we can download the data," said David Sear, of Southampton University.

"We will be able to plot when particles started to move and relate this to the wave energy, or the stream energy. Did the particles move constantly with the tide, or did they move and stop? Did they travel down the beach and back again, or did they move only in one direction? These are important questions. We hope the pebbles will allow us some answers."

webTitle: Buchanan supporters split the great right hope

fields.headline: Buchanan supporters split the great right hope
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: On the eve of their annual convention in which they hoped to present a third party alternative to American voters, the Reform party has become involved in an ugly split. In scenes of high farce, there were walkouts, scuffles and shouting matches as two rival factions accused each other of fraud and "brownshirt tactics".
fields.body:
On the eve of their annual convention in which they hoped to present a third party alternative to American voters, the Reform party has become involved in an ugly split. In scenes of high farce, there were walkouts, scuffles and shouting matches as two rival factions accused each other of fraud and "brownshirt tactics".

Opponents of Pat Buchanan, the rightwinger who is the party's likely presidential candidate, stormed out of a meeting of the national committee at a Long Beach hotel and threatened to nominate their own candidate. Security guards and police were involved in the scuffles as each side screamed insults at the other.

At the heart of the split in the party formed by billionaire Ross Perot in 1992 is a claim by some party loyalists that the self-styled "Buchanan's Brigaders" have hijacked the party which had traditionally been fiscally conservative but allowed members to make their own decisions on social matters. Mr Buchanan is a well-known social conservative and former Nixon speech writer who defected from the Republicans last year. His rival for the nomination is an Iowa physicist and former professor at the Maharishi University of Management, John Hagelin.

The row came to a head at a meeting of the 164-member national committee over who should sit as delegates at the convention which opens today. After the shouting, opponents of Mr Buchanan stormed out calling for the media to be allowed in to see what was happening as other Buchanan supporters tried to fight their way in to the meeting. They were cries of "Go, Pat go!" and "Buchanan's brownshirts!" as security guards sought to separate the factions.

The anti-Buchanan faction, about a quarter of the committee, then held its own meeting at a neighbouring hotel and both groups claimed to have the authority to nominate the candidate. Russell Verney, an opponent of Mr Buchanan and the party's first chairman, said: "We could end up with two nominees." He said that whichever side lost would go to court, which could throw their campaign into chaos.

Apart from the nomination, at stake also is the $12.5m (£8.3m) in matching federal campaign funds to which the nominee is entitled. Mr Buchanan's opponents are also claiming ballot fraud by the Buchanan supporters.

Bay Buchanan, the sister of the likely nominee and his campaign strategist, emerged from the first meeting to claim that her brother had won. "Pat has the nomination." Mr Buchanan's supporters claim that the party was moribund until he arrived to rejuvenate it. The split could help Ralph Nader's Green Party candidacy which is currently winning around 8% in the polls and could claim to the most viable third party.
fields.bodyText: On the eve of their annual convention in which they hoped to present a third party alternative to American voters, the Reform party has become involved in an ugly split. In scenes of high farce, there were walkouts, scuffles and shouting matches as two rival factions accused each other of fraud and "brownshirt tactics". Opponents of Pat Buchanan, the rightwinger who is the party's likely presidential candidate, stormed out of a meeting of the national committee at a Long Beach hotel and threatened to nominate their own candidate. Security guards and police were involved in the scuffles as each side screamed insults at the other. At the heart of the split in the party formed by billionaire Ross Perot in 1992 is a claim by some party loyalists that the self-styled "Buchanan's Brigaders" have hijacked the party which had traditionally been fiscally conservative but allowed members to make their own decisions on social matters. Mr Buchanan is a well-known social conservative and former Nixon speech writer who defected from the Republicans last year. His rival for the nomination is an Iowa physicist and former professor at the Maharishi University of Management, John Hagelin. The row came to a head at a meeting of the 164-member national committee over who should sit as delegates at the convention which opens today. After the shouting, opponents of Mr Buchanan stormed out calling for the media to be allowed in to see what was happening as other Buchanan supporters tried to fight their way in to the meeting. They were cries of "Go, Pat go!" and "Buchanan's brownshirts!" as security guards sought to separate the factions. The anti-Buchanan faction, about a quarter of the committee, then held its own meeting at a neighbouring hotel and both groups claimed to have the authority to nominate the candidate. Russell Verney, an opponent of Mr Buchanan and the party's first chairman, said: "We could end up with two nominees." He said that whichever side lost would go to court, which could throw their campaign into chaos. Apart from the nomination, at stake also is the $12.5m (£8.3m) in matching federal campaign funds to which the nominee is entitled. Mr Buchanan's opponents are also claiming ballot fraud by the Buchanan supporters. Bay Buchanan, the sister of the likely nominee and his campaign strategist, emerged from the first meeting to claim that her brother had won. "Pat has the nomination." Mr Buchanan's supporters claim that the party was moribund until he arrived to rejuvenate it. The split could help Ralph Nader's Green Party candidacy which is currently winning around 8% in the polls and could claim to the most viable third party.

fields.headline: Wifebeating guide angers Muslim women
fields.trailText: A Turkish state-funded religious foundation has courted public fury by publishing a volume that says men may beat their wives as long as they avoid the face and do not strike too hard. The Muslim's Handbook, written by a retired cleric, Kemal Guran, also says that if a man's wife is ill and he cannot afford a servant, he can take a second wife.
fields.body:
A Turkish state-funded religious foundation has courted public fury by publishing a volume that says men may beat their wives as long as they avoid the face and do not strike too hard. The Muslim's Handbook, written by a retired cleric, Kemal Guran, also says that if a man's wife is ill and he cannot afford a servant, he can take a second wife.

The book was printed under the supervision of the Pious Foundation, which is affiliated to Turkey's government-run religious affairs directorate. The directorate appoints all Muslim clerics and dictates the topics preached at mosques.

Although other religious texts have declared wifebeating permissible in the past, the Muslim's Handbook has been produced at a time when the directorate is attempting to present a modern interpretation of Islam, including greater rights for Muslim women.

"I am outraged that such a book was published with state funds - with money women paid in taxes," said Zuhal Kilic, the head of Kader, a group which promotes women in politics. And Sema Piskinsut from the Turkish parliament's committee on human rights warned that "no one has the right to hit another person".

The foundation is already in trouble with the military-dominated national security council for publishing a book which described the armed forces as "not a national army but the army of a faction [of society]". Turkey's army is staunchly secular and has led the crackdown on political Islam.

Several weeks ago a similar row erupted in Spain about another book by a Muslim cleric which included tips on wifebeating. The imam Mohamed Kamal Mostafa, based at a mosque in Fuengirola, on Spain's southern coast, also described how to hit without leaving marks in his recent book Women in Islam.

He suggested that verbal skills were the best way to bring women into line. If that did not work, a period of sexual abstinence should be tried. Failing that, beating was acceptable so long as the blow, delivered by a thin rod, was not struck in extreme anger. Sensitive parts of the body such as the face, breasts, and stomach should be avoided.

webTitle: Comment, Michael White:  William Hague can't get the personal stuff right

fields.headline: Fourteen pints of trouble
fields.standfirst:
Poor old William Hague - he just can't get the personal stuff right

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Michael White: What is it about William "14-pints-a-day" Hague's image that causes him so much trouble? Apart from the premature baldness, now resolved by his adoption of a menacing Grant Mitchell crop, his CV should be a spin doctor's dream.
fields.body:
What is it about William "14-pints-a-day" Hague's image that causes him so much trouble? Apart from the premature baldness, now resolved by his adoption of a menacing Grant Mitchell crop, his CV should be a spin doctor's dream. A "normal" middle-class family background, north of Watford too, a state school education, four As at A-level and straight into Oxford. There he both got a first and was president of the Union, a rare double. Thence into McKinsey's, the cult management consultancy which does not hire fools.

Onwards and upwards until, at 36, already an ex-cabinet minister, young William becomes the youngest Tory leader since Pitt (who got the job in 1793 when he was 24). He was a William too, come to think of it, nerdy and a bit of a boozer. As Cecil Parkinson used to say: "At every stage William's done better than Tony Blair." And yet he still seems to get the personal stuff horribly wrong. Even making allowances for the August silly season in Fleet Street, yesterday's tabloids were, surely, a nightmare.

"I was Britain's biggest boozer," thundered the Mirror. "Billy Liar," roared the Sun with its usual delicacy. The broadsheets were scarcely kinder. Even the FT managed "Billy Fizz Hague tries to sink his sober image" on page three, so that Britain's EU partners, just recovering from Euro 2000's battle of Charleroi, will be sure to see it.

In one casual exchange with GQ magazine, Mr Hague had simultaneously annoyed a vast coalition of voters: health fascists joined forces with teetotallers, prigs with sophisticated teenies who know that simply everybody nowadays does drugs (that's why it's called e-commerce) on Saturday nights. All of them combined with anyone who wants to feminise the tone of our still rather masculine public life to denounce him for laddishness, social irresponsibility and a sheer lack of cool. It could be argued that the worst offence was caused to boozers of the old school, who simply didn't believe the claim. At 15 or 55 years old, it's a lot of beer. In Rotherham they claimed to remember that the lad who helped deliver the beer barrels on behalf of his dad's company, wasn't even a half-of-lager lout.

Hence the Billy Fizz and Billy Pop jokes. They reinforce what remains the predominant public image of Hague the teenager as a nerd, who made "that speech" at the Tory conference in 1977, who read Hansard and kept byelection results, not football results, on his bedroom wall. We have been here before with Mr Hague. Back in 1997, he was photographed in a baseball cap and then drinking through a straw (beer presumably) out of a melon at the Notting Hill carnival. A young, happening-kind-of Tory leader, one who cared, had taken over, was the not-so-subliminal message.

Except it didn't work, as Tory strategists came to realise. It wasn't the real Hague and it wasn't the right message after the slaughter of May 1. Hague was already busy remoulding his party well out of public gaze. Once he'd done that and finished apologising for past Tory error, he could start to move on policy reformation.

The Hague Mk II who emerged in time for the 1999 European elections (along with the Grant Mitchell look) was harder and meaner. He focused on Tory core issues with wider resonance: the euro, law and order, asylum seekers entering Britain during the Kosovo war, enough to start getting Tony Blair rattled. No more Mr Nice Guy, and some cartoonists started to portray him in an uglier light than the short-trousered kid at Margaret Thatcher's side. Lately he has begun making speeches on education and health - he may tackle green issues soon - but Hague Mk II has been the key to the modest revival of Tory electoral fortunes. It is the Hague who will fight the coming election.

What happened on the pages of GQ this week was not another attempt to reposition the leader's image, it was an accident. The interview was given weeks ago on the grounds, familiar enough to Mr Blair's handlers, that GQ is an upmarket lads' mag, the market leader in fact, which reaches thirty-something voters with lots of disposable cash who are too busy playing squash or shopping to read much.

The interviewer was not just another hack either. Nicholas Coleridge is a media grandee, MD of the Condé Nast group which owns GQ, the Eton-and-Trinity son of a past chairman of Lloyds. It is a patsy interview; Mr Coleridge has decided Mr Hague is now the plucky underdog, but there is a distinct tone of condecension in the exchanges. This being GQ, there was a lot of detail about where Hague buys his suits (posh West End) and what colour shirts he likes (blue). His feet are size 9 and Ffion has purged his wide-lapel jackets. She buys him daft cufflinks.

Fascinating or what? But politicians have to do this nowadays, though Gordon Brown's GQ interview on fashion would be rather short. The Tory leader was given space for a brief message: GQ should vote Tory for a better business climate, national sovereignty and improved public services.

GQ played it up (hey, this is August), but the beer story is actually old. Hague has written it himself, as in the Times of November 15 1997: "When I'd finished each delivery I'd always be given a pint of John Smith's as a reward. . . at five in the evening I'd be feeling pretty light-headed."

Far more revealing for a modern populist was his inability to name the England football captain. Describing how he first moved in on Ffion Jenkins (one of his civil servants at the time) he also said that after an official dinner "we went out socially to a bar in London" - Hague-speak for "had a drink".

Yet Mr Hague is a clever man, a witty and fluent public speaker who will, I suspect, surprise us all by surviving long enough to become prime minister over Michael Portillo's acquiescent body - one day. Little horrid has been said about Hague that was not said about Ted Heath or - the dumbos - Mrs T.

Last night his aides were putting a brave face on the affair. It had helped to shift that stubbornly-held image voters have of him, as a southern public school boy and toff, they explained. A poll on Talk Radio showed 82% of callers more likely to vote for the 14-pint man than less. Sky TV's poll was running neck and neck. Just as adultery is no bar to high office in France, youthful boozing is not an impediment here.

All this may be wishful thinking, but the Tories are surely right to argue that when a wimpish media stereotype clashes with a claim to be a 14-pint man it will produce a bang. All politicians reinvent themselves a bit to become more interesting and all, including Tony Blair, get caught out.

The sad thing is that in an age of professionalised politics, when they all start so young, few have time to do or become anything interesting before they start polishing those leadership CVs.

fields.headline: Putin widens hunt for bombers
fields.standfirst:
Wrong to blame Chechens for Moscow deaths, says president

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Amid a rising tide of anti-Chechen sentiment, the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, insisted yesterday that it was too early to blame Chechen rebels for Tuesday's bomb atrocity in the centre of Moscow which killed seven and maimed dozens.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor  and Amelia Gentleman  in Moscow
fields.body:
Amid a rising tide of anti-Chechen sentiment, the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, insisted yesterday that it was too early to blame Chechen rebels for Tuesday's bomb atrocity in the centre of Moscow which killed seven and maimed dozens.

Leaders of the large Chechen community in the city and Russian Muslims voiced alarm at the incendiary statements from some senior political figures which encouraged reprisals against Chechens, while racist demonstrators paraded at the site of the tragedy declaring that the "only good Chechen is a dead Chechen".

In a statement on television, Mr Putin said that "a crime was perpetrated, either the result of a criminal feud or an act of terrorism. Discussing the terrorist version I have to state that it is not right to seek a national trace, a Chechen trace, or any other in this crime. It's not correct to brand an entire nation."

The statement was seen as an attempt to cool Muscovite tempers and a rebuke to the powerful mayor of Moscow, Yuri Luzhkov, who was quick to denounce the bomb as "100% Chechen" while his aides declared that Russia was in a state of war (with the Chechens) and that freedom of movement would need to be restricted.

It was also clear that Mr Putin's government believed that Chechen terrorists were responsible. One Chechen man and another from neighbouring Dagestan were detained for questioning though they were not suspects in the blast.

Three suspects were being sought, two of them officially described as being of "north Caucasian appearance".

Another three Chechens were arrested in the town of Saratov with bomb equipment said to be in their possession. They "might have been planning a terrorist attack similar to that in Moscow", the Interfax news agency reported.

And Nikolai Patrushev, the head of the domestic security service and close Putin associate, said 11 other bomb plots in various Russian cities were foiled last month.

While some 1,600 police launched a security sweep across Moscow, checking papers, searching vehicles, patrolling railway and subway stations, and inspecting flats, the city's Chechen leaders said they feared the kind of harassment and repression that followed last year's bomb blasts, which killed 300 in Moscow and other Russian cities.

"We can see the problems coming for Chechens all over Russia. We're extremely worried and the official statements are encouraging this," said Dzhabrail Dzhokalayev, the head of an organisation representing the Chechen diaspora in Russia.

"What happened in Moscow yesterday is happening in Chechnya every day. We're suffering more from terrorism than anyone else. It's very dangerous for Russia to defame an entire people in advance." He said Mr Putin's statement had been reassuring.

The religious leader of Russia's Muslims, Sheikh Ravil Gainutdin, said: "Politicians and public figures should be very cautious so as not to spark nationalist feuds."

The scene of the blast at Pushkin Square, a few hundred yards from the Kremlin, was yesterday thronged with people engaged in heated debate about the atrocity and who was responsible.

"This would never have happened if our security services were working better," said Tamara Ivanovna, a crockery seller working in the underpass at the time of the explosion on Tuesday evening. "They knew something like this was going to happen and they didn't stop it. This was a terrorist attack."

Passersby laid flowers and bottles of vodka and beer at two makeshift shrines to the victims in the charred ruins of the pedestrian underpass.

There was no lightning and burnt wires and piping hung from the ceiling, but thousands of Muscovites passed through, going about their normal business. Several women wept on seeing the carnage, and one young man fainted in the crush of people.

Mr Putin launched the war in Chechnya last year in response to a series of bomb attacks blamed on Chechen secessionist rebels, although the allegations have never been proven. But the measured nature of yesterday's statement suggested the president was fearful of lighting a touchpaper which could spark a bigger conflagration.

The risks of such conflict were illustrated a fortnight ago when a Russian mob went on the rampage in a Volga village in southern Russia, stoning Chechen homes and torching several flats after a disco brawl in which two Chechens killed a Russian youth.

webTitle: Why do the Blairs need 15 armoured cars?

fields.headline: Why do the Blairs need 15 armoured cars?
fields.standfirst:
Italian and German press bemused by heavy security at premier's holiday retreat and 'almost sadistic iciness' shown to British media

Those holiday snaps
Special report: Blairs' baby
fields.trailText: Tony Blair may be at ease in Europe, but the continental press did not provide much of a festive welcome yesterday.
fields.byline: Rory Carroll  in Rome, John Hooper  in Berlin, Jon Henley  in Paris and Owen Bowcott
fields.body:
Tony Blair may be at ease in Europe, but the continental press did not provide much of a festive welcome yesterday.

Newspapers in Tuscany, where the prime minister and his family are staying, labelled the security laid on as "almost sadistic". A German paper claimed he was being guarded by a police detachment of 80.

Baffled by the ritual of the Blairs' reluctant family photocall at the Villa Cusona, near San Gimignano, European papers questioned the princely cost. One pointed out that Mr Blair required 15 armour-plated cars, when his Italian counterpart, holidaying elsewhere in Tuscany, made do with one such vehicle.

Altogether, it was not a good press day for Mr Blair. La Nazione, in Tuscany, suggested Italians were lucky not to have to witness the security operation required to preserve the family's privacy, and the "almost sadistic iciness" shown to the British press pack.

Magi Cleaver, a Downing Street press officer, was mocked as an ill-humoured watchdog. Branding her "Sergeant Magi", La Nazione quoted her as saying: "Only TV operators and photographers can go in. You can only stay a few minutes, you will be 20 yards away and remain in silence. You must not disturb the sleep of little Leo. If he cries we will stop it."

Another Tuscan newspaper, Corriere divi Siena, said the photocall's three-minute stony silence, from which reporters were banned without leave to appeal, was a "dumb show" that left a bitter taste in the mouth. The event, cancelled following the Blairs' protests over publication of photographs of the christening of baby Leo, was reinstated after the intervention of the chairman of the Press Complaints Commission, Lord Wakeham.

Unlike previous years, Italy's national newspapers have in the main ignored the guests of Prince Girolamo Strozzi, owner of the 50-room renaissance villa outside San Gimignano. There have been no new accusations of Blair freeloading for having accepted the prince's hospitality.

Local newspapers also played down last week's report in a British daily that San Gimignano's mayor, Marco Lisi, was still furious at Mr Blair's failure to meet him last summer. Amends have been made, and after the two had met, Mr Lisi dripped superlatives in yesterday's La Nazione.

Italian criticism found an echo in the German daily Die Welt: "The premier's stay in Tuscany is keeping the Italian security services pretty busy. Forty officers have been quartered in a nearby farmhouse, 20 police and 20 Carabinieri. For the family, a further personal detachment of 20 has been deployed. In addition, there are two Scotland Yard officers and 12 police consultants accompanying Mr Blair."

A dog team had been brought in, along with a helicopter to watch from above, Die Welt reported. The premier and his family also had 15 armour-plated cars at their disposal, "more extravagant than his Italian counterpart, Giuliano Amato, who, on his holidays in Ansedonia [also in Tuscany] has only 10 escorts and one armour-plated car".

Last night a Downing Street spokeswoman said: "The numbers of Italian police and armour-plated cars are a matter for the Italian authorities; we have not requested any."

webTitle: Vigilantes defy calls to end paedophile protests

fields.headline: Vigilantes defy calls to end paedophile protests
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: A senior Labour backbencher last night demanded that the News of the World be prosecuted for inciting public disorder as a wave of mob violence continued after its decision to name convicted paedophiles.
fields.body:
A senior Labour backbencher last night demanded that the News of the World be prosecuted for inciting public disorder as a wave of mob violence continued after its decision to name convicted paedophiles.

Robin Corbett MP, chair of the Commons home affairs select committee, joined a chorus of concern over the attacks on sex offenders and innocent people wrongly identified by vigilantes. Yesterday police, a bishop and probation officers united in condemning the disorder that experts believe is putting children in more danger.

Mr Corbett said: "It was perfectly predictable when the News of the World started this what the outcome would be and I suspect they knew it as well. That is why I have asked the Home Office whether they will consider prosecution for incitement to public order offences."

Last night vigilantes marched through an estate in Portsmouth for the sixth night in a row. Four innocent families have been forced to flee after being wrongly identified as harbouring sex offenders.

Violence has also flared in Plymouth, a man was chased by a mob in Whitley, Berkshire, and two men accused of child sex offences have committed suicide. Police said a millionaire businessman, John Potter, arrested over child sex charges, had been found on Sunday night shot dead at his Kent home.

Peter Gammon, spokesman for the Association of Police Superintendents, said the News of the World bore part of the blame for the unabating disorder. The newspaper's naming and shaming campaign followed the abduction and murder of Sarah Payne, eight.

"What they've created is an atmosphere of fear among members of the public, among parents and among sex offenders," Mr Gammon said.

The violence was being initiated by thugs using parents' fears about paedophiles as an excuse for lawlessness. "In most cases there is a violent element infiltrating these groups and initiating the violence," he said. "The group mentality and group dynamic leads to people who are normally law abiding to join in. Violence begets violence."

Last night the Church of England entered the debate. Richard Harries, the Bishop of Oxford, condemned the "communal hysteria" triggered by the paper's campaign.

The bishop, who chairs the church's board for social responsibility, said: "The News of the World has a lot to answer for. I would say this phenomenon is deeply disturbing and we've only got to remember examples like the witches of Salem, where communities can get caught up in communal hysteria."

The bishop called for the vigilante action to stop, saying it made the problem of paedophiles worse. "These are fellow human beings, they need to live in the community again and all attempts need to be made to rehabilitate them," he said. "They can't spend the rest of their lives in prison."

George Barrow, spokesman for the Association of Chief Officers of Probation, said the monitoring of paedophiles had been made more difficult: "The supervision of sex offenders is designed around public protection, and if you damage our supervision you damage public protection.

"People on the register wrongly thought the News of the World had access to official information and therefore thought there was a disincentive to remain in contact with statutory bodies like probation and police."

Last week the News of the World backed down on its pledge to publish the names and locations of paedophiles. Its editor, Rebekah Wade, had launched the campaign three weeks previously, despite advice from police and experts that such tactics could lead to violence.

In a statement released before Mr Corbett's call for a prosecution, the paper said: "The News of the World's campaign for the introduction of Sarah's law [legislation to give parents access to information about paedophiles in their area] is designed for the protection of children. To date, the newspaper has received nearly 350,000 signed petitions in support of the campaign."

On the Paulsgrove estate in Portsmouth police were last night bracing themselves for fresh protests from vigilantes, who claim to have a list of 20 paedophiles living on the estate.

Superintendent Bob Golding of Hampshire police confirmed that the four families moved off the estate had been wrongly targeted by the vigilante mob. "They are innocent victims of gossip and rumour. There is nothing to suggest they had anything to do with paedophiles."

webTitle: Milosevic uses arrests to bolster election chances

fields.headline: Milosevic uses arrests to bolster election chances
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The arrests of eight foreigners, including two Britons, on charges of espionage are designed to create a "sense of siege" and boost President Slobodan Milosevic's already strong chances in next month's elections, western officials fear.
fields.body:
The arrests of eight foreigners, including two Britons, on charges of espionage are designed to create a "sense of siege" and boost President Slobodan Milosevic's already strong chances in next month's elections, western officials fear.

"They are in effect hostages to his effort to present Yugoslavia as being under threat," a senior official said yesterday.

Ever since last year's war over Kosovo, western governments have pinned their hopes of removing Mr Milosevic on various scenarios, including an army coup and street demonstrations. When the Yugoslav strongman unexpectedly announced snap elections for next month, they banked on the central campaign issues being the future of the Serbian economy, Serbia's reintegration into the European fold, and how best to achieve political liberalisation.

But Mr Milosevic is casting the election as a loyalty test, with his challengers portrayed as traitors. "This is a battle for the survival of the nation and the state. Slobodan Milosevic is the symbol of Yugoslavia, of heroic resistance to the aggressor, and of restoration and development. Our opponents are not an opposition to our party, but to their own people and the state," Gorica Gajevic, the secretary general of the Socialist party of Serbia said last week.

Forced on to the back foot, the fractious Serbian opposition has accepted Mr Milosevic's gameplan and, in choosing Vojislav Kostunica as its standard-bearer in the elections, has appointed a nationalist rather than a liberaliser. As a result, western governments find themselves rooting for a man who strongly criticised Nato's Kosovo campaign and who refuses to meet officials from Nato countries.

Anti-western feeling is still high in Serbia and although many voters criticise Mr Milosevic they seem to accept his argument that Yugoslavia remains under siege.

Mr Milosevic's maverick ally, the ultra-nationalist Vojislav Seselj, yesterday pursued that line. He attacked Mr Kostunica as "Nato's candidate".

"Voice of America, Free Europe, Deutsche Welle and the BBC have all praised Kostunica over the past few days in Serbian language broadcasts," he said. Mr Kostunica had been more cunning than other opposition leaders at hiding his pro-Nato feelings but Serbs would never vote for "Nato candidates", he went on.

The charge is ironic since Mr Kostunica's nationalist credentials are clear. Before the Nato air strikes, he was photographed with Serbs in Kosovo brandishing a Kalashnikov rifle in resistance. He has described relations between foreigners and the Serbian state as "a game in which everything is given up in return for almost nothing, except symbolic concessions". He strongly opposes the Hague Tribunal and criticises the war crimes indictment issued against Mr Milosevic.

This line of "moderate nationalism" may explain why Mr Kostunica came out well in a recent poll by the Belgrade-based Institute of Social Sciences. It found him leading Mr Milosevic by 42% to 28%.

But the poll was taken before the Serbian Renewal Movement, a leading opposition party, decided to put up its own candidate in a move which will split the anti-Milosevic front.

fields.headline: 'It just doesn't seem real'
fields.standfirst:
Family: Grief for a father

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The family of a millionaire who killed himself while under investigation for allegedly indecently assaulting two 15-year-old boys yesterday spoke of their grief.
fields.body:
The family of a millionaire who killed himself while under investigation for allegedly indecently assaulting two 15-year-old boys yesterday spoke of their grief.

John Potter, 49, is believed to have been worth £2m after founding the largest Harley Davidson motorcycle dealership outside the US in Southampton. He was discovered on Sunday with a single bullet wound to the head at his £500,000 home in Herne Bay, Kent, where he lived with his wife Carol and sons Daniel and Russell. Daniel said yesterday: "We are still trying to come to terms with the fact he is no longer with us. My mother is devastated and we have visitors here who are trying to comfort her. At the moment it doesn't seem real."

Solicitors for the family last night issued a statement stressing that Mr Potter had not been facing charges when he died. The statement read: "Mr Potter was not the subject of any criminal charges at the time of his death and any suggestions of any wrongdoing on his part was and is adamantly denied."

Neighbours said that Mr Potter had been a family man and involved in the local neighbourhood watch scheme.

Neighbourhood watch organiser Faith Pauley, said: "I knew about the investigation but I will be amazed if you can find anyone who will say anything bad about John."

Detectives from Hampshire police were due to question him about the allegations on August 25. When they first went to see him at his Southampton office in May, Mr Potter is reported to have jumped from a first floor toilet window and suffered head injuries.
