webTitle: Bookham shocks market with new offering

fields.headline: Bookham shocks market with new offering
fields.trailText: Bookham Technologies, the fibre optics company that emerged from nowhere to claim a FTSE 100 berth just two months after floating, surprised the stock market again yesterday with the announcement that it planned to issue more shares.
fields.body:
Bookham Technologies, the fibre optics company that emerged from nowhere to claim a FTSE 100 berth just two months after floating, surprised the stock market again yesterday with the announcement that it planned to issue more shares.

The 12-year-old company based in Oxfordshire said it was looking at ways of increasing the liquidity in its shares. It is also keen to find an exit for venture capital firms that want to realise some of the profit on their investment.

The news knocked Bookham shares back 5% to £41.85p.

Chief executive and founder Dr Andrew Rickman, whose own stake in Bookham is worth £1.2bn, refused to rule out the possibility that he and some of his fellow directors might also sell some of their holdings, although he stressed that any change to the shareholder register would be minimal.

"No one is checking out," he said. "There will be no significant change in the position of investors in the company. There is nothing abnormal about venture capital companies looking to sell some of their investment. The management has no intention but to press forward 100%." Nevertheless analysts said the unexpected announcement was the principal reason behind early selling of Bookham shares yesterday.

This knocked almost 11% off the price at one stage. As the day progressed wider circulation of Dr Rickman's reassuring comments helped the shares recover a little but they still closed down on the day.

It was a time of heavy trading and speculation that the share price might be near its peak, especially if long-term investors are selling out.

Optical networking has become one of the hot investor areas in recent months. The technology uses light to transmit data, catering to the needs of the high-speed internet and telecoms networks, which are expected to play a key role in future internet communications.

That promise persuaded US firms JDS Uniphase and SDL to recently agree a $41bn (£27bn) merger.

The shares have risen from a flotation price of £21.12 to a high of £53.02p before slipping back.

The exact timing and size of any new share offer will depend upon market conditions. Finance director Stephen Cockrell said that the issue may also include some new cash to fund increased expenditure on new manufacturing and development facilities in order to meet higher than expected demand.

Bookham has already spent significant sums on expanding its manufacturing facility in Abingdon, and opening a new production facility at Swindon.

Mr Cockrell forecasts that capital expenditure is likely to rise from by £20m to £37m by the end of the year, and then touch £100m next year.

Analysts said that the higher than anticipated expenditure could put Bookham's expected breakeven date of the end of 2001 back by three to six months.

Mr Rickman said that by getting a higher volume of products into the marketplace Bookham would increase the likelihood of its technology being adopted on a global basis.

He was speaking after unveiling better than expected figures for the second quarter to July 2. Revenues jumped 84% from the previous period to £4.6m.

Nortel Networks accounted for around 59% of orders. This is a dependency level that analysts would like to see reduced.

Net losses widened from £4.02m to £11.3m. Staff numbers jumped 51% to 593 and by the end of July had passed 700.

Chief executive and founder Dr Andrew Rickman, whose own stake in Bookham is worth £1.2bn, refused to rule out the possibility that he and some of his fellow directors might also sell some of their holdings, although he stressed that any change to the shareholder register would be minimal. "No one is checking out," he said. "There will be no significant change in the position of investors in the company. There is nothing abnormal about venture capital companies looking to sell some of their investment. The management has no intention but to press forward 100%." Nevertheless analysts said the unexpected announcement was the principal reason behind early selling of Bookham shares yesterday. This knocked almost 11% off the price at one stage. As the day progressed wider circulation of Dr Rickman's reassuring comments helped the shares recover a little but they still closed down on the day. It was a time of heavy trading and speculation that the share price might be near its peak, especially if long-term investors are selling out. Optical networking has become one of the hot investor areas in recent months. The technology uses light to transmit data, catering to the needs of the high-speed internet and telecoms networks, which are expected to play a key role in future internet communications. That promise persuaded US firms JDS Uniphase and SDL to recently agree a $41bn (£27bn) merger. The shares have risen from a flotation price of £21.12 to a high of £53.02p before slipping back. The exact timing and size of any new share offer will depend upon market conditions. Finance director Stephen Cockrell said that the issue may also include some new cash to fund increased expenditure on new manufacturing and development facilities in order to meet higher than expected demand. Bookham has already spent significant sums on expanding its manufacturing facility in Abingdon, and opening a new production facility at Swindon. Mr Cockrell forecasts that capital expenditure is likely to rise from by £20m to £37m by the end of the year, and then touch £100m next year. Analysts said that the higher than anticipated expenditure could put Bookham's expected breakeven date of the end of 2001 back by three to six months. Mr Rickman said that by getting a higher volume of products into the marketplace Bookham would increase the likelihood of its technology being adopted on a global basis. He was speaking after unveiling better than expected figures for the second quarter to July 2. Revenues jumped 84% from the previous period to £4.6m. Nortel Networks accounted for around 59% of orders. This is a dependency level that analysts would like to see reduced. Net losses widened from £4.02m to £11.3m. Staff numbers jumped 51% to 593 and by the end of July had passed 700.

webTitle: Nomura's £557m offer for Hyder trumps WPD

fields.headline: Nomura's £557m offer for Hyder trumps WPD
fields.trailText: The long-running battle for Hyder, the Welsh multi-utility, yesterday entered its final phase when Nomura, the Japanese bank, upped its offer to £557m, trumping the agreed £526m bid from Western Power Distribution, the US group.
fields.body:
The long-running battle for Hyder, the Welsh multi-utility, yesterday entered its final phase when Nomura, the Japanese bank, upped its offer to £557m, trumping the agreed £526m bid from Western Power Distribution, the US group.

But WPD, under pressure from Welsh politicians to withdraw, said it was considering its position and would make a further announcement in due course, prompting market speculation it would increase its 340p-a-share bid and pushing Hyder shares up to 378p - notably more than the 360p offered by Nomura.

The two rival bidders have until tomorrow to make their final offers. But Mike Kinski, Nomura's transactions director, said: "We have made our own decision to increase the bid and it has not been driven by any timetable issues but the value in the business."

The Japanese bank has raised its offer for Hyder twice from its original 260p bid and its latest offer represents a 90% premium to Hyder's price of 189.25p on March 27, the day before it started the bidding war by saying it was in talks with others about its future.

Guy Hands, head of Nomura's principal finance group, said: "We strongly believe our increased offer is in the best interests of all Hyder shareholders and hope that the acquisition can be concluded swiftly."

Hyder, which owns Welsh Water and the Swalec electricity distribution business, has debts of £1.6bn which Nomura would assume, pushing the offer's overall value to more than £2bn - a signal that the market sees more value in British utilities than their previously depressed share prices indicated.

Mr Kinski, Hyder's designated chief executive, reaffirmed Nomura's commitment to keep the group intact and retain its 9,000 employees despite the higher offer.

He said that as a way of raising money the bank would consider exiting Hyder's stakes in some non-Welsh infrastructure projects such as the London Underground.

"We are very keen to get the business and feel we can justify the 360p offer and still continue to develop the business," he told BBC Radio Wales.

Both of the bidders have said that they plan no further redundancies on top of the 1,000 set in train by Hyder to meet price cuts imposed by utility regulators.

webTitle: Pumped up and primed for consolidation

fields.headline: Pumped up and primed for consolidation
fields.trailText: Conservative leader William Hague may have boasted this week about his "washboard stomach" and "high definition pecs" - but given his claims to drink beer by the gallon it is really Britain's fitness industry that is showing strength.
fields.body:
Conservative leader William Hague may have boasted this week about his "washboard stomach" and "high definition pecs" - but given his claims to drink beer by the gallon it is really Britain's fitness industry that is showing strength.

Companies are reporting record membership growth, profits and soaring share prices. About 5% of adults belong to a fitness club - still some way to go compared with the US's 12% - and already some areas, including Leeds and Crawley, are over-provided with gyms.

The popularity of fitness clubs fits the government's agenda too - it fits in with the campaigns promoting healthier lifestyles.

The promotional effort is good news for the 10 independent clubs quoted on the stock market, including Fitness First and Cannons. The six big chains in the business are Hilton, De Vere and David Lloyd Leisure, which is owned by Whitbread.

Such clubs do not need to spend much on advertising and instead are focused on expansion and providing quality service and affordable gym membership.

It is good news for shareholders, who have seen the stock price of mid-market operators Fitness First and LA Fitness rise rapidly. Fitness is seen as the one area of the leisure sector that offers real potential for earnings growth - unlike brewing, hotels and travel.

Research group, Online, estimates that there are about 770 health centres in Britain with the capacity for that number to double in the next five years before saturation occurs.

Some UK clubs are already protecting themselves against the prospect of saturation and cutthroat competition. Fitness First and Holmes Place are both building their brands across mainland Europe, and fashionable Fitness First bought into Asia last month.

The market's respect for Fitness First lies with chief executive Mike Balfour who expanded it from a club in Bournemouth 10 years ago to a chain of 66. The group recently reported that its pre-tax annual profit had doubled to £5m and that its like for like sales were up 8%.

Even the sector's bears find it hard to fault Fitness First's strategy as the share price has soared from 150p in January 1997 to over £13.50 yesterday.

Investors are favouring the mid-market operators like Fitness First that charge members £35 to £40 a month over larger players such as Cannons and Holmes Place which ask £50 to £60 a month.

Mid-market operators have smaller gyms, for which there are a greater number of sites available. It means they can expand faster and establish popular pricing structures.

The more expensive fitness clubs argue their prices are justified by membership loyalty and bigger and better fitness facilities and service.

But the expensive end of the market is suffering. Cannons, which reports its first-half results today, has seen its share price slip from over 200p last October to 130p. The company has been hit by analysts' downgrades earlier this year, and there is concern that management has failed to deliver the group's true potential.

While the market is still in its early growth phase, Nick Batram of Granville Baird argues the time is ripe for consolidation. "We are more likely to see consolidation between the middle and large club operators than at the affordable end of the market.

"This is largely down to valuations, greater cost savings and competition issues. It is unlikely that all three of Cannons, Esporta or Holmes Place will be quoted in their current state in two years' time."

fields.headline: Telekom postpones T-Mobile float
fields.trailText: Deutsche Telekom yesterday postponed plans to float its mobile telephone business, T-Mobile, which includes One2One in Britain.
fields.body:
Deutsche Telekom yesterday postponed plans to float its mobile telephone business, T-Mobile, which includes One2One in Britain.

The German telecoms group denied the move had been influenced by falling values among telecoms stocks, insisting that had been taken because of the complexities of including details of its $50bn (£33.3bn) acquisition, US mobile operator VoiceStream.

The flotation had been planned for this autumn, but now seems likely to be delayed until the new year.

"This is not about the share price. The timetable did not give us enough time to give all the details about the integration of VoiceStream," said a Deutsche Telekom spokesman.

Along with One2One, T-Mobile includes the T-Mobil business in Germany, Max.mobil in Austria and VoiceStream. The addition of VoiceStream made the preparation of the prospectus "considerably more complex," Telekom said.

It noted that: "Potential investors are also setting more stringent requirements regarding the presentation of the future orientation of Deutsche Telekom's mobile communications business."

The firm declined to comment on the date of the float. A spokesman said that no decision had been taken. The delay was greeted with relief by financial markets, braced for several heavyweight offerings and with the DJ Stoxx telecoms sector up 2.7%.

Norway's Telenor, Holland KPN, Spain's Telefonica Moviles and Orange are among those preparing to offer shares before the year's end.

The cost of acquiring third generation licences and then building networks is another factor weighing on the sector. Germany is in the middle of its auction of 3G mobile licences with the bidding topping DM30bn yesterday.

Deutsche Telekom stressed that the delay to the T-Mobile offering was not influenced by prices in the telecoms sector but its decision may reduce the pressure of other firms seeking to tap the markets.

webTitle: Head in the clouds artist was inspired by science

fields.headline: Head in the clouds artist was inspired by science
fields.standfirst:
Edinburgh exhibition explains how a book on meteorology helped John Constable make the sky 'the chief Organ of Sentiment' in his pictures
Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Edinburgh exhibition explains how a book on meteorology helped John Constable make the sky 'the chief Organ of Sentiment' in his pictures.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Instead of going on about brush strokes and paint textures, visitors to an exhibition opening today should admire the artist's exemplary handling of cumulonimbus, his mastery of stratocumulus, and his wayward but informed treatment of rainbows.

Constable's Clouds, at the National Gallery of Scotland in Edinburgh, is devoted to the great British obsession: the state of the weather. The artist himself said that the sky was "the chief Organ of Sentiment" in his pictures.

John Thornes, a meteorologist who has studied Constable's cloud paintings for 20 years and has written part of the exhibition catalogue, said yesterday that he believed this to have been no mere romantic conceit, but was based on the artist's knowledge of the meteorology of his time.

John Constable (1776-1837) was painting at a time when the science was in its infancy.

In 1803, Luke Howard, a London chemist, published a classification of cloud types that Dr Thornes, head of the climate and atmospheric research group at Birmingham University, said remained a definitive work.

Aristotle's Meteorologica had a far longer lasting influence, accepted for more than 2,000 years, but, said Dr Thornes, "his explanations of atmospheric phenomema were nearly all completely wrong."

Howard's work influenced the poets Goethe and Shelley, and also a young writer and amateur scientist called Thomas Forster, who wrote the first book on meteorology for general readers. Constable owned a second hand copy of the book that remains in the Constable family papers, heavily annotated by the artist.

"Constable wanted to perfect his skies, to capture a moment that also encapsulated the weather of that particular day," said Dr Thornes. "His skies are so realistic that they both summarise the weather of the previous few hours, and provide a forecast of the weather to come."

Dozens of Constable's sketches of the sky, mostly done very rapidly on Hampstead Heath in north London, are included in the show, which is part of the Edinburgh festival. On the back of each drawing he wrote notes, for example: "Hampstead, Sept 11, 1821, 10 to 11. Morning under the sun - Clouds silvery grey on warm ground. Sultry. Light wind to SW, fine all day - but rain in the night following."

Dr Thornes was less happy with Constable's rainbows. He grumbled that, although the painter had been perfectly capable of portraying rainbows that were scientifically correct, he would for artistic reasons place them in positions where they must cause anguish to any weatherman - as in the famous 1831 painting to be seen in the exhibition, Salisbury Cathedral from the Meadows.

"He was aware of the fact that a rainbow cannot be seen once the sun is higher in the sky than 42 degrees, which it is," Dr Thornes complained.

However, he forgave the artist for having gone "beyond meteorological truth" to express his desolation at the death of his wife, Maria, a desolation that the meteorologist believed might be read in the stormy skies of the later paintings.

Dr Thornes had no interest at all in art until a friend took him to a Turner exhibition where he was immediately struck by the huge cloudy skies.

He said yesterday that he has since moved on to an interest in LS Lowry, whose matchstick men are typically stooped under threatening grey heavens.

"His skies are very interesting - they solved a real artistic problem for him. By painting under very heavy skies, with very limited visibility, he didn't have to worry about shadows at all.

"And having hit that formula he just stuck to it - you never see a blue sky in a Lowry."

webTitle: Oxford Molecular sells up to US rival

fields.headline: Oxford Molecular sells up to US rival
fields.trailText: Oxford Molecular, which supplies software to the pharmaceuticals industry, is to go into liquidation after agreeing to sell its remaining operations for £18m to Pharmacopeia, a US rival.
fields.body:
Oxford Molecular, which supplies software to the pharmaceuticals industry, is to go into liquidation after agreeing to sell its remaining operations for £18m to Pharmacopeia, a US rival.

The deal puts an end to the company's 11-year history as an independent company - Oxford's software was once tipped to revolutionise the process of drug discovery.

Finance director Laurence Steingold said: "It is a sad day for the company but the deals we have done are in the best interests of our investors."

Oxford last month sold its discovery solutions division for £35m to Millennium Pharmaceuticals. It completed its break-up yesterday by agreeing to dispose of its software solutions business, which provides chemical analysis of potential drugs, to Pharmacopeia.

The company intends to change its name to OM2000 and return its remaining assets of about £40m to investors, through a cash payout of between 41p and 44p a share. It will then ask shareholders for permission to wind up.

Mr Steingold, who was appointed last year, said the company had failed because it had concentrated on innovation, rather than making money: "The company was not really sales led - it was led by engineers and academics."

Founded in 1989 by Oxford academic Tony Marchington, the company set out to make chemical analysis faster and more efficient. It made a succession of acquisitions in the mid-1990s to accumulate software to cover all stages of the drug discovery process.

Mr Steingold said it lacked the "operational expertise" to pull all these together.

Dr Marchington recently gave two years' notice of his intention to resign as chief executive of the company he has a 6% stake in. The shares, which hit 465p three years ago, edged up 3.5p to 34.5p.

webTitle: Drain of talent in schools, say heads

fields.headline: Drain of talent in schools, say heads
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Inadequate pay and an ever-increasing workload have led to a serious "talent drain" at the top of the teaching profession, headteachers warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Inadequate pay and an ever-increasing workload have led to a serious "talent drain" at the top of the teaching profession, headteachers warned yesterday.

They urged the government to give all headteachers an immediate salary rise of £3,000, and to take urgent steps to cut red tape in schools, in order to stop a waste of high class talent through the most experienced heads taking early retirement.

The warning came from the National Association of Head Teachers, which released figures showing that advertisements for headships were running at their highest level for several years, figures it will submit to the teachers' pay review body next month, ahead of the pay round.

There were 1,799 ads for heads' jobs published in the Times Educational Supplement between January and June - up 40% on the same time last year and 50% ahead of the 1998 figures. The only year when there were more, 2,261, was 1997, due to thousands of heads rushing to take early retirement when the previous government tightened the rules.

The association said that the statistics had "stark messages" for the government, given the combined difficulties of losing experienced heads and failing to attract high quality replacements. Most heads leaving were in the 50-59 age group, often simply taking early retirement rather than seeking alternative employment.

Despite the attention given to so-called "super-heads" who command salaries of more than £70,000, the association complained that, in general terms, heads' pay did not equate with the ever-growing demands of their jobs; it claimed they had three worries: pay, bureaucracy, and lack of control over budgets.

The general secretary, David Hart, said: "This country can ill afford a headteacher brain drain of this magnitude. Too much high class talent is being wasted and sacrificed on the altar of bureaucracy, red tape, inadequate funding and less than satisfactory pay levels.

"The government promised pressure and support for schools in equal measure. The pressure has been intense, the support has, so far, been conspicuous by its relative absence. Until the government's commitment has been translated into actual delivery, heads will continue to leave and senior staff will decide that the job of being a head is not worth the candle."

Average pay for a primary head was £35,000 but should be between £38,000 and £44,000, Mr Hart added. Similarly, secondary heads on an average of £51,000 should be on between £54,000 and £62,000. Such sums might change the minds of those thinking of leaving or unwilling to apply, he said.

Bob Carstairs, assistant general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said the national association's conclusions were in line with a survey of its own: "The shortage of heads is particularly serious in some parts of the country such as Essex and London".

A Department for Education and Employment spokesman claimed that at least half the 511 additional vacancies were the result of a new retirement scheme that the national assocation itself had lobbied for, allowing "burned out" heads to take on lighter duties or quit the profession.

Heads could also earn up to £76,000 in certain posts, he said, adding that, while there was more work associated with the government's literacy and numeracy strategies, moves were under way to cut paperwork in schools by half.

Average pay for a primary head was £35,000 but should be between £38,000 and £44,000, Mr Hart added. Similarly, secondary heads on an average of £51,000 should be on between £54,000 and £62,000. Such sums might change the minds of those thinking of leaving or unwilling to apply, he said. Bob Carstairs, assistant general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said the national association's conclusions were in line with a survey of its own: "The shortage of heads is particularly serious in some parts of the country such as Essex and London". A Department for Education and Employment spokesman claimed that at least half the 511 additional vacancies were the result of a new retirement scheme that the national assocation itself had lobbied for, allowing "burned out" heads to take on lighter duties or quit the profession. Heads could also earn up to £76,000 in certain posts, he said, adding that, while there was more work associated with the government's literacy and numeracy strategies, moves were under way to cut paperwork in schools by half.

fields.trailText:
Earthquake shakes Mexico
An earthquake measuring around 7.0 on the Richter scale shook western and central Mexico early yesterday, cracking walls and breaking windows.
fields.body:
Earthquake shakes Mexico
An earthquake measuring around 7.0 on the Richter scale shook western and central Mexico early yesterday, cracking walls and breaking windows.

The quake's centre was off Mexico's Pacific coast, and the city of Lazaro Cardenas was damaged, an official said. AP, Mexico City

ETA murders army officer
A Spanish army officer was shot dead yesterday in the northern city of Pamplona in the latest of a string of attacks this week blamed on the Basque separatist group ETA, police said.

The killing of the sub-lieutenant was the ninth linked to ETA since December. Reuters, Madrid

Wahid deputy takes charge
President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia yesterday bowed to fierce criticism of his rule by ordering Vice-President Megawati Sukarnoputri to handle the daily duties of government.

But Mr Wahid made it clear that he would remain in ultimate control. Reuters, Jakarta

Troops arrive in south Lebanon
Villagers threw rice yesterday to welcome Lebanese security forces into the former Israeli-occupied zone in southern Lebanon.

The 500 soldiers and 500 policemen moved into areas that had been controlled by guerrillas since Israeli troops withdrew on May 24. AP, Marjayoun

fields.headline: A fair day out
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Moy Hall Estate
fields.body:
Moy Hall Estate

While the correct title of the event on August 4-5, just south of Inverness, is the Highland Field Sports Fair, we like to think of it more as a country fair; although there are some British and Scotland-based organisations involved, there is still plenty of local input - especially in the craft tents, where people living in our own strath have exhibits. Unusually for a Highland gathering of this type there is no livestock, so the usual cattle, sheep and poultry are not present - although there are a few ponies for children's rides and many people take their dogs.

One local person had been in the Forestry Commission for many years but had taken early retirement and he now specialises in making frames from naturally shaped wood for mirrors of various sizes and shapes. Another local speciality is the Black Isle Brewery: the names on the bottles range from red kite to organic goldeneye and the stand seemed quite busy.

The farrier was also busy and it was good to see so much interest in his art. It looks as though, with an increasing number of ponies being used on the hill for deer extraction, and local riding schools being very well patronised, the future of the Highland ponies is assured.

It was good to see the children enjoying themselves so much, being shown the basics of archery, watching Bubbles the Clown or having their faces painted. There was of course the more serious side, with talk in the Deer Commission for Scotland tent on the question of there still being too many red deer. Roe and sika deer were also a problem over numbers.

Overall the fair offered a chance to view a cross section of the countryside, from stalking to fishing and basket making to local artists. However some stands have gone in recent years, such as the second-hand books stands and a couple that used to sell paintings. And what happened to the RSPB stand, and Scottish Natural Heritage?

As we left, the pipe band started up in the main arena; as we drove off after being there for three hours, the crowds were still pouring into the car parks.

webTitle: Japanese crime wave leaves police floundering

fields.headline: Japanese crime wave leaves police floundering
fields.trailText: Gangland shootouts, rising juvenile violence and a big increase in serious offences have raised fears that Japan - one of the safest countries in the world - is losing the battle against crime.
fields.body:
Gangland shootouts, rising juvenile violence and a big increase in serious offences have raised fears that Japan - one of the safest countries in the world - is losing the battle against crime.

Official statistics show that Japan is in the middle of its worst crime wave in two decades, and its police service, which has been plagued by scandal, seems unable to meet the challenge.

Just this week, two yakuza gangsters were killed and five injured in a sword and gun battle with members of a rightwing political group in Tokyo. Police have detained six members of a gang affiliated to the Sumiyoshi-kai, one of the three biggest crime syndicates in Japan, but other suspects are still at large.

Although Britain and America remain far more dangerous, the crime wave has prompted calls for action by politicians and generated anxious editorials in the media.

While the number of offences has increased, the arrest rate has declined. In the first six months of this year, the national police agency (NPA) investigated 1.1m crimes, an increase of 12% on the same period of 1999, and the first time that the half-year figure has exceeded 1m.

During this period, the number of arrests fell by more than 20% to 281,000, prompting police officials to acknowledge that investigators can no longer keep up. The admission - from a police service at a low point in terms of morale and public respect - is seen as a plea both for sympathy and extra resources.

Since late last year, the NPA has been embroiled in a series of scandals, culminating in the resignation of the country's top police officer after revelations of a high-level cover-up of drug abuse by a senior officer.

Police methods have also come under fire, particularly after the discovery of a 19-year-old woman who had been held captive for more than nine years in the home of a child abuser. Detectives had ignored tip-offs that might have led to the teenager's release on several occasions.

The arrest rate for murder, burglary and arson may have dropped by 12% from January to June, but for many Japanese, the most alarming crimes have been those which the police have been powerless to stop: random acts of violence by youngsters offending for the first time.

The number of murders by teenagers almost doubled - from 27 to 53 - in the first six months of the year. The cases include a 17-year-old boy who clubbed a schoolmate and his mother to death after being bullied.The number of minors arrested for using stimulants has jumped by 45%.

Experts are divided on the causes of this crime wave. Some say it is a reflection of the hardships of a country still struggling to emerge from its worst recession in 50 years, but many psychologists blame a lack of morality in an affluent generation over-exposed to violence in video games, television and comics.

The prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, has pledged to introduce moral education in the country's schools and the government has established a panel of experts to consider ways to tackle youth crime, including stiffer penalties for juveniles.

Nationalist political leaders, however, have blamed the immigrant population. Tokyo governor Shintaro Ishihara has warned that some areas of the capital are no longer safe after dark because of foreign gangsters.

fields.headline: Swine fever dooms farm's 3,500 pigs
fields.standfirst:
Ministry tries to contain first outbreak in 14 years
Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: All 3,500 pigs on a Suffolk farm were being destroyed yesterday to combat the first outbreak of swine fever in Britain for 14 years.
fields.body:
All 3,500 pigs on a Suffolk farm were being destroyed yesterday to combat the first outbreak of swine fever in Britain for 14 years.

More than 100 animals died from the disease before it was diagnosed. The Ministry of Agriculture thought it had been eradicated from the UK.

To try to stop the infection spreading to more than half a million pigs in the country, a three-kilometre exclusion zone has been introduced around the farm, near Woodbridge, and farmers will not be allowed to move pigs in the area.

All visitors' footwear and vehicles going to farms in the area will have to go through a powerful disinfectant "dip".

A team of agriculture ministry inspectors will call on other farms, but a spokesman stressed that the swine fever poses no threat to human health.

The batch of pigs that died had come from a farm in Norfolk, and urgent checks were being made to see if another batch of piglets from the same source also had the disease.

Like BSE, swine fever can be spread by feeding infected meat products to pigs. In the 1960s it was such a menace that all pig feed had to be heat treated, and over a three-year period it was thought to have been eradicated.

Yesterday the ministry said it was at a loss to know how it had suddenly reappeared in Suffolk.

The last outbreak, in 1986, had been a single one, and it was hoped that this one could also be confined.

The disease, also known as hog cholera, is a carried by a highly infectious virus and can be transmitted in dead meat. Farmers fear that the growing trend of raising pigs outdoors could lead to the rapid spread of swine fever.

Ministry officials are still considering how to get rid of the carcasses of the infected herd - either by burying them on the farm or putting them in sealed containers to be taken for rendering, so that all the virus would be destroyed by heat.

James Black, vice chairman of the National Pig Association, who also farms in Suffolk, said: "We are all extremely concerned about the implications.

"This is a very serious disease that is easily spread from pig to pig and can even be carried by staff and vehicles. Restrictions will have to be in place for weeks, but my fear is that it may already have spread."

Farmers will be compensated for animals that are slaughtered, but Mr Black said: "The other costs - of staffing and overheads and cleaning, and the fact that the farm will be empty for weeks - could be the last straw for some producers, who are only just emerging from the last price crisis."

webTitle: Financial reality hits free web hope

fields.headline: Financial reality hits free web hope
fields.standfirst:
Service providers struggling to create 'internet for the people'
Net news
fields.trailText: The prime minister Tony Blair's vision of an "internet for the people" is turning out to be a mirage.
fields.body:
The prime minister Tony Blair's vision of an "internet for the people" is turning out to be a mirage.

In March this year Mr Blair hailed plans by the US internet firm AltaVista to offer unlimited online access for a one-off payment of around £30 and a small annual fee.

"Our goal must be to see prices comparable with anywhere in the world," Mr Blair said, fearing the UK's "new economy" would lag behind unless call charges were cut to allow affordable web access.

But since then a series of unmetered services have been launched and have sunk, their founders realising that their plans were not economic. As a result, the government's aspirations of extending internet access beyond wealthy and educated sectors of society remain a long way off.

Richard Branson's Virgin Net recently announced a delay in its flat fee, unlimited access service, while this week CallNet 0800 - the first UK company to offer unmetered access - announced that it was scrapping the service on September 5 and replacing it with standard pay per minute charges for surfing the net.

Even AltaVista - which received a blizzard of publicity for its plans, including front page news in the Sun and the Daily Mail - appears to have struggled to make its unmetered service work.

Tim Richardson, internet editor of The Register, a specialist information technology website, said the ambitious plans of internet service providers such as AltaVista had not benefited ordinary users.

"AltaVista has yet to provide any evidence that it is providing unmetered internet access for the 120,000 users it claims to have," Mr Richardson said.

The company originally said it had received more than 1m inquiries from potential customers since its announcement, and planned to add 90,000 new users each month.

But yesterday an AltaVista spokesman said the company was "not prepared to say" how many active users it had.

The firm may make a statement next week, but fears in the industry are that AltaVista is running into technological and access worries that have plagued other internet service providers.

CallNet this week told its customers that it blamed "substantial changes in the telecommunications industry", which it said had "altered the fundamental economics" of its unmetered service. Another operator, Breathe, was recently forced to bar 500 customers for using its unmetered service too much.

But many in the sector blame BT for dragging its feet on reducing call charges for internet service providers. "Many of them had higher hopes for wholesale access from BT," said one analyst.

"It's very hard to build a business plan for unmetered access when you are paying per minute to BT."

Negotiations are still going on between BT and other telecommunications companies over wholesale packages that would inject new life into flat-fee internet access for home users. But it may be several months before a deal is signed.

Earlier this year BT came under fire from the chancellor, Gordon Brown, when he demanded that the company open up its local network to cheaper, faster suppliers.

fields.headline: A bomb in Moscow
fields.standfirst:
Mr Putin may turn it to his advantage

Audio: Ian Traynor in Moscow (1min 25)
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Almost as troubling as the bomb which ripped through a pedestrian subway under Pushkin Square in Moscow during Tuesday's rush hour is the question of how President Vladimir Putin may respond.
fields.body:
Almost as troubling as the bomb which ripped through a pedestrian subway under Pushkin Square in Moscow during Tuesday's rush hour is the question of how President Vladimir Putin may respond. The atrocity, all the more appalling for the absence of any warning, was immediately, perhaps too immediately, blamed on the Chechens.

Almost exactly a year ago, a similar outrage in Red Square marked the beginning of a series of bomb attacks, mostly on apartment buildings, in which hundreds died. Mr Putin, only recently appointed prime minister by the then president Boris Yeltsin, used the ensuing revulsion to justify his launching of an all-out war of conquest in Chechnya. After uncounted deaths and immeasurable misery, Mr Putin declared victory and rode his conqueror's chariot to the Kremlin on the back of a presidential election landslide.

But as forensic teams pick their way through the Pushkin Square débris, two points should be kept in mind. Despite strenuous efforts by Mr Putin's FSB security apparatus, Chechen responsibility for last year's terror campaign was never conclusively proved and, then as now, the Chechen leadership denied all involvement. And the Chechen "victory" that Mr Putin so skilfully exploited for electoral advantage was never entirely real. That conflict continues to this day. If the Chechens were behind Tuesday's blast, and especially if, as is feared, it marks the opening shot in a new urban terror campaign, the lie of Mr Putin's invincibility is exposed before the Russian people. If somebody else was responsible, he may feel even more threatened.

Mr Putin has made a lot of enemies since taking office one year ago this week, any one of whom might wish to ruin his anniversary. They include, for example, nationalist elements within the federation (as in Tatarstan) and those in mainly Muslim former Soviet republics opposed to Mr Putin's central Asia "Ostpolitik". As Mr Putin warned yesterday against jumping to conclusions about who planted the bomb, some in Moscow predicted he could plunge into another, broad, swingeing law-and-order crackdown which could serve a wide multitude of purposes. Such a move would ostensibly be justified by a need to avenge the victims of Pushkin Square. But even if it fails to net the culprits, as was the case last year, Mr Putin will doubtless use it to ensure that his own position is further strengthened.

fields.headline: Sin tax shakedown in Japan
fields.standfirst: News Analysis Yokohama tries new revenue-raising exercise
fields.trailText: The pimps and prostitutes of Yokohama City are used to being hassled by police officers and yakuza gangsters, but they may soon be shaken down by an altogether new face: the tax man.
fields.body:
The pimps and prostitutes of Yokohama City are used to being hassled by police officers and yakuza gangsters, but they may soon be shaken down by an altogether new face: the tax man.

With local government revenues shrinking amid the worst recession in 50 years, the mayor of Yokohama, Hidenobu Takahide, has proposed the introduction of Japan's first sin tax, taking a cut from sex and gambling.

Numerous obstacles - including red tape, opposition from organised crime syndicates and accusations of unfairness - need to be overcome, but the Yokohama plan is being closely watched by other Japanese municipalities, many of which are close to bankruptcy.

Walk around Akebono-cho red light district, and it soon becomes clear why the sex industry is an obvious target in this port city.

The main drag is lined with garishly coloured, neon-lit buildings with names like Princess Peach, The Pink House, and St Gospel School's Costume Play - all of which seem to be doing a better trade than conventional local firms.

Many of these places are so-called fashion health establishments, which circumvent the prohibition on prostitution in Clinton style by offering only oral sex.

It is a lucrative business. Signboards outside every door list prices ranging from about 7,000 to 15,000 yen (about £44 to £95) for 40 minutes, depending on the time of day, the age of the women and extras, such as dressing up as schoolgirls. Most places start at 10am and, according to local residents, have a steady stream of customers until the early hours of the morning. These businesses are supposed to pay about 43% of their profit in corporate tax - the same as any other private firm. Officials in the mayor's office say, however, that brothels and fashion health establishments usually doctor their accounts to ensure they pay next to nothing.

All this will change if Mr Takahide has his way. The mayor has set up a panel to investigate ways to levy a new local tax on sex shops, betting offices and pachinko, or gambling machine, parlours. It is expected to announce its conclusions by the end of this year.

"Most local governments are in dire financial straits as welfare expenditures have increased while revenues have decreased," the mayor explained in a recent interview. "To narrow the gap we need to increase revenues."

Yokohama's tax income has fallen steadily over the past four years as local companies and residents have been hit by the recession. Last year, Japan's second most populous city received ¥667bn, or £4.2bn in tax, down from ¥728bn in 1996.

Meanwhile, it has had to pay more for health and social services to care for the growing number of elderly residents. It is a pattern that has been repeated across the country, leaving many municipalities in a worse state than Yokohama.

As of April, local governments owed a staggering ¥179 trillion - just over £1 trillion - in debt, more than Britain's entire annual output.

The figure has almost tripled in the past 10 years. Seven prefectures, including Tokyo and Osaka, have declared financial crises. In good times, the main source of revenue for local governments is corporate tax, but two-thirds of Japan's companies are now losing money so they do not pay a single yen.

Many municipalities rely on central government grants to stay solvent, but these could soon dry up. On Tuesday, a government panel recommended cutting subsidies to encourage local authorities to be more independent.

Desperate for new income flows, Tokyo and Osaka - the country's two biggest and most indebted municipalities - have recently introduced new taxes on banks. This has been made possible by the implementation this year of a new local law which gives regional authorities more power over their finances.

Despite criticism that the bank taxes unfairly punish a specific industry, they have strong public support because banks are widely blamed for Japan's economic problems. Yokohama's new sin tax seeks to tap into a similar sense of public indignation. "Local people have requested action against the sex industry and a tax may be one way of reducing its presence in the city," said a senior official at the municipal tax office. "Gambling joints and brothels also make a great deal of money so, under a progressive tax system, it is reasonable to charge them more."

This will be easier said than done. Municipal officials are not sure how many sex establishments are doing business in the city, let alone their income. It is also hard to imagine that bureaucrats will push too hard to probe the finances of the yakuza crime syndicates that run such places.

"We cannot accept the new tax because it discriminates against us," said the crew-cut owner of the Yellow Cab health fashion business. "Yokohama has screwed up its finances and now they're picking on us to cover their tab. Why should we co-operate?" Even opponents of the sex industry have their doubts. "This is just grandstanding aimed at gathering votes," said Hideo Akimoto, deputy chairman of the Akebono-cho residents association.

"They've no intention of cracking down on the sex trade. Political pressure will kill this plan because the police and the government are in the pockets of the mob. That's how this business was able to grow here in the first place."

Economists' views are mixed. Critics say that a revision of the corporate tax system would be a more equitable and effective way of stabilising public finances than piecemeal levies on certain industries. Others, however, see the Yokohama moves as a possible test case.

"This shows how local governments are trying to find new ways to raise revenues," said Junzoh Wuemura of the Japan Centre for Economic Research. "But putting this plan into action will be tough."

fields.headline: Clouding the issue
fields.standfirst:
No sin to be meteorologically incorrect

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Many celebrated painters knew little or nothing about how to paint skies, according to a meteorologist at the Edinburgh Festival.
fields.body:
Many celebrated painters knew little or nothing about how to paint skies, according to a meteorologist at the Edinburgh Festival. Dr John Thornes, director of the climate and atmospheric research group at Birmingham university, singled out for particular blame Gainsborough's 1750 portrait of Mr and Mrs Andrews which hangs in the National Gallery, London. "To a meteorologist," he said, "it looks wrong." Rubens did not come too well out of this exercise either.

Most people who look at Mr and Mrs Andrews savour the way it breathes the 18th century, while more timelessly evoking a prosperous couple basking in their prosperity. It is not hard to imagine the Andrews's counterparts now, with their jobs in the City and his 'n' hers Porsches. But Dr Thornes's trained eye sees things differently. The landscape may be exquisite, he says, but the clouds are poorly depicted: "It would appear that there is a large bonfire on the horizon and that black smoke is rising out of it."

Could that perhaps have been Gainsborough's point? These were turbulent years. The Jacobite wars had only just ended: the seven years war was not far away. Perhaps a beacon was burning just out of the picture, bringing news which would shortly shatter the Andrews's serenity ... But in any case, there are limits to the standards of scientific accuracy we ought to expect from painters.

Should this kind of criticism catch on, the peace of great galleries will be shattered by the complaints of limnologists challenging lakes, fluviologists disparaging rivers, and structural engineers moaning that the buildings which artists depict could never stand up. How painters must envy Wordsworth, who could write of wandering lonely as a cloud without a chorus of critics demanding to know what kind of cloud he meant. Not to know if the poet imagined himself as cumulus, stratus or nimbus does not mar our pleasure in what he created. Nor should the imperfections of Gainsborough's clouds.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Rowers set new Channel record
fields.body:
Rowers set new Channel record

A team of six rowers completed a world record crossing of the English Channel yesterday while preparing for an assault on the transatlantic record. The crew made the 91-mile trip from Jersey to Poole, Dorset, in less than 15 hours, aided by strong winds and a following tide.

Magnetism 'flattens crops'

Some crop circles are caused by shifts in the earth's magnetic field, a leading scientist claimed yesterday. Colin Andrews believes crops can be electrocuted by the earth's electric current, flattening them into distinctive circular patterns. But the scientist says this explains only a fifth of circles, the remainder of which are made by hoaxers.

Son for movie stars

The Welsh actress Catherine Zeta Jones gave birth to a son in a Los Angeles hospital on Tuesday evening. The baby, Dylan Michael Douglas, is a first child for Jones, 30, and her fiance, the actor Michael Douglas, 55.

Bid to end 'leaves' delays

Train operators yesterday announced a £4m investment in an attempt to end the annual delays caused by leaves on the line. Railtrack, Connex and South West Trains plan to fit more than 200 trains with equipment that will allow drivers to drop sand on slippery railway lines.

Quiet family funeral for actor

The actor Sir Alec Guinness will be buried in a private family funeral tomorrow, it has been announced. A spokesman for his family said that there would be no memorial service at the request of the actor, who died in hospital in Midhurst, West Sussex, on Saturday, aged 86.

webTitle: Lady Young takes over environment watchdog

fields.headline: Lady Young takes over environment watchdog
fields.trailText: Barbara Young, the Blairite life peer and deputy governor of the BBC, is to leave her job as chairwoman of English Nature to become chief executive of the environment agency.
fields.body:
Barbara Young, the Blairite life peer and deputy governor of the BBC, is to leave her job as chairwoman of English Nature to become chief executive of the environment agency.

The appointment will be welcomed by environmental groups which have seen Lady Young of Old Scone revitalise English Nature in her two years as chairman. They hope she will now breathe new life into the agency.

The announcement, which sees her swap a two day a week job with a salary of £47,000 for a hands-on role as a chief executive earning in excess of £125,000, comes as a surprise, since she has a number of part-time posts which she will have to give up.

The agency is responsible for the wider environment, pollution from industry, water quality, and sea defences. It has struggled to keep up with the expectations of the public.

Lord de Ramsey, a friend of John Major, who was chairman at the time of the general election, left his post early after widespread criticism of his lack of leadership. The new chairman, Sir John Harman, a former leader of Kirklees council, has also so far failed to make a serious impression.

Yesterday Lady Young said: "My time at English Nature has been thoroughly exhilarating. There is still much to do, but I leave English Nature an organisation which is flourishing. I very much look forward to working closely with it in my new role at the environment agency."

fields.headline: Zimbabwe's snub to UN
fields.trailText: I fully accept that land rights in Zimbabwe are in need of fundamental reform. But it is disappointing to read that the heads of member states of the Southern Africa Development Community have endorsed Robert Mugabe's policies for land reform (Regional leaders rally behind Mugabe, August 8).
fields.body:
I fully accept that land rights in Zimbabwe are in need of fundamental reform. But it is disappointing to read that the heads of member states of the Southern Africa Development Community have endorsed Robert Mugabe's policies for land reform (Regional leaders rally behind Mugabe, August 8).

Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, proposed some while ago that the UN development programme should be responsible for channelling funds available from external donors to compensate commercial farmers whose land was earmarked for redistribution.

The UNDP could play a key role in determining who should inherit smallholdings and could help to diversify the crops grown so as to alleviate the loss to the Zimbabwean economy of the tobacco currently grown on large estates.

Leaders in southern Africa will run a great risk of social disorder if they condone high-handedness in Zimbabwe. How much better if they had publicly supported a role for the UNDP in delivering justice to landless farmers on the basis of need.

Malcolm Harper
United Nations Association

 The disturbing excess of zeal by the British embassy in Khartoum in deterring potential asylum seekers is nothing new (Diplomats told to drop unauthorised screening of visa requests, August 9). More than four years ago our embassy asserted - falsely - that all the Sudanese regime's torture centres had been closed. Who told them so? Why, the Sudanese government's torturer-in-chief. The Home Office was quick to use this as grounds for refusing asylum. British interest in Sudan's newly extracted oil seems to have overridden concern for the truth.

Peter Verney
Sudan Update

fields.headline: Tories have rights too
fields.trailText: It is odd that the Conservative party seems to oppose the development of the distinctively British human rights culture which will follow from the Human Rights Act (Leader, August 9).
fields.body:
It is odd that the Conservative party seems to oppose the development of the distinctively British human rights culture which will follow from the Human Rights Act (Leader, August 9). For the first time, British courts will have to take account of human rights law. It follows logically that a body of British human rights jurisprudence will be created.

There are bound to be times when different rights are contested. But what is new - and welcome - is that this will happen in our courts and in parliament rather than just at Strasbourg. Far more of us will be able to contribute to a dialogue about rights, and play a part in shaping the type of human rights culture that we want to see in the UK. As the main opposition party, the Conservatives have an important role in this debate.

Jenny Watson
Human Rights Act research unit, King's College

 Julia Langdon is entitled to criticise me for views which I do hold but not for those which I do not (They just can't stand a successful working mum, August 9). It is wrong for her to say that I am arguing against working women. I passionately believe in increasing employment opportunities for women. My own mother has worked for over 40 years.

No one is suggesting that Cherie Blair should not work. But she should not publicly pontificate on the controversial human rights legislation from which she stands to gain financially.

John Bercow MP

fields.headline: Germaine's a patriot
fields.trailText: I wrote the story of Germaine Greer's emotional outburst at the Australian writers' festival at the South Bank last month which was published in the Canberra Times and appears to have placed her top of the Australian media hit list of "whingeing Aussies" described by John Sutherland in his column (G2, August 7).
fields.body:
I wrote the story of Germaine Greer's emotional outburst at the Australian writers' festival at the South Bank last month which was published in the Canberra Times and appears to have placed her top of the Australian media hit list of "whingeing Aussies" described by John Sutherland in his column (G2, August 7). It is true that Ms Greer described herself as "an honorary aborigine" and stated: "I don't want to die in this country but I can't go home - ever - until this is fixed."

However, she was not expressing anti-Australian views but rather refusing to perpetuate the postcolonial myth that it was the English who did all these dreadful things to the aborigines and that everything is hunky dory now. Such a view makes Ms Greer an Australian patriot, not the opposite.

Peter Thompson
London

fields.headline: Derek Hill
fields.standfirst: Contradictions in the life of a society portrait painter better known in his adopted Irish home as a master of landscape
fields.trailText: Derek Hill, who has died aged 83, won respect as a painter in oils in the early 1950s. It is only in the last decade, however, that respect has broadened into appreciation of his significance.
fields.body:
Derek Hill, who has died aged 83, won respect as a painter in oils in the early 1950s. It is only in the last decade, however, that respect has broadened into appreciation of his significance. Best known in Britain as a portrait painter, chronicler of that fading Anthony Powell world where high society meets the power nexus as well as haute bohème, Hill came to be seen in his adopted home of Ireland as the master of that country's wild western coastline and broken Atlantic light. To the British, Hill is an interesting anomaly; the "last of the gentlemen painters" is a phrase much used. In Ireland he is a national figure.

Such contradictions, successfully reconciled in his work, fall off the page when you remember Derek or consider his life and character. He was an intensely social being who thought of himself as a loner. "All I want is peace," he would say to his friends. Woe betide any who granted this wish by failing to include him in their invitations. This seldom happened. He was excellent company and had good tales to tell. His life as a traveller, a stage designer, an art collector, a painter of famous people, an expert in Islamic architecture, a promoter of talents other than his own, a gardener, and chocoholic equipped him as a raconteur. He was also empathetic and could share the ups and downs of the personal and emotional life of his friends - emotions he had himself to some degree evaded. When I was writing an appreciation of him, published in 1997, he told me that he had never experienced a satisfying physical relationship. Teasing was the best antidote to the legendary Hill attribute of social touchiness. As a friend, you needed to underline the difficulties caused by his occupying a space-time dimension which simultaneously included an evening with the Guermantes circle, as it were, and painting by himself on Tory, an island off (and frequently cut off from) the Donegal coast. Most people who sat for Hill as a portraitist agreed that his ability to paint and converse at the same time was both relaxing and enchanting. His cast of characters include: Freddie Mills; Artur Rubenstein; Bernard Berenson; Lords Hailsham; Mountbatten, Dufferin, Drogheda, Zuckerman and Longford; Isaiah Berlin; Anthony Eden; John Betjeman; Frederick Ashton; Noël Coward; LP Hartley; Kenneth Clarke; Steven Runciman; Osbert Lancaster; Wilfred Thesiger; Tony O'Reilly; Erskine Childers; George Christie and the Duke of Buccleuch. His last major portrait was of Alec Guinness - "so delightful, but so difficult because his genius depends on the anonymity of his face" - whom Derek pre-deceased by a few days. There are two portraits of the Prince of Wales, to whom Derek was devoted. The friendship was reciprocated, as Prince Charles was rightly confident that it was exclusive of his position. But as well as the droppable names, the best portraits include friends and neighbours in Rome, Donegal or on Tory.

Hill's landscapes, by contrast, are lonely and seldom peopled. The Irish writer Monk Gibbon put it well. "What is strange," he wrote in 1963, "is that someone like Derek Hill, a humanist with a keen love of social contacts, should have discovered in one of the bleakest and most remote corners of western Europe the seascapes and landscapes themes which many people consider has led him to complete artistic fulfilment."

The larger paintings of rocks and sea on Tory rank among the very best pure landscapes painted anywhere since 1945. The "tiny postcard masterpieces", as Derek's Donegal neighbour the American art collector Henry P McIlhenny called Hill's less sculptured landscapes, have the fleeting intensity of a light that changes each minute. They are poetic indeed, but grounded in Hill's knowledge of abstract proportions and his experience as a young designer in a Munich influenced by the Bauhaus before the war.

Derek's father was AJL Hill, a cricket captain of Hampshire. The family lived at Romsey and were friends of the Mountbattens. Derek painted Earl Mountbatten, and there is a fine view of Ben Bulben and the stretch of water where Mountbatten was eventually murdered, painted from a lavatory window at Cassiebawn, the Mountbatten's Irish home. AJL Hill was a shrewd businessman and Derek never wanted for money. (He tended to purchase his own paintings when they appeared on the market. As he complained that he was insufficiently appreciated, I had to explain that taste is formed, like it or not, by the market, and that even the best painters need dealers or agents to promote them.)

His parents were tolerant of his leaving Marlborough School at 16 to devote himself to the arts: he was for a time a pupil of Kurt Schwitters. While not unsuccessful as a stage designer (he was influenced by a sojourn in Moscow and was knowledgeable about ballet as well as opera), it was the Paris-based English couturier, Edward Molyneaux, who persuaded him to concentrate on painting alone. Molyneaux's great art collection of French Impressionist and post Impressionist paintings (sold to Mrs Mellon and now the bedrock of the National Gallery at Washington collection) taught him light. The best Hills, however, are architectural in the way of Corot, Courbet and Cézanne.

One of Hill's most endearing qualities, both as an artist and as a man, was his generosity to those younger than himself and his encouragement of young artists. As a director of the British School in Rome in the 1950s, he nourished such talent as Michael Andrews, John Bratby and Anthony Fry. His own art collection was very fine with great examples of the misty Thames landscape and early abstract paintings of his friend Victor Pasmore.

Hill settled in Donegal in 1954. Hitherto his closest thing to a home had been I Tatti, Bernard Berenson's Florentine villa now owned by Harvard. He purchased an old rectory and 20 lakeside acres for £1,000. Here he created a house and a garden which has been featured in many books as masterpieces of interior and garden design. An older brother, John, was a distinguished decorator and he and Derek discovered, and bought, rolls of original Morris wallpapers, which were being used as drawer-lining paper in an Edinburgh hotel. Islamic objects, colours, textiles and designs were also important; Derek published collaborative studies of Islamic architecture in the 1960s and 1970s. My own family lived 15 miles away and as a teenager I would ride over unsurfaced roads to stay in the magical house and eat wonderful food. Elizabeth David, a frequent guest, said that Derek's cook-housekeeper, Gracie, was the best natural cook she had ever encountered. I would return with a loaned Moore maquette in my knapsack or a Sutherland gouache and the beginnings of an educated eye. After making over Glebe House to the Irish nation in the early 1980s, Derek shared a minute cottage with Gracie, who was about 10 years older. They bickered contentedly, like a long-married couple, and I once had to rescue the marriage by cooking for them both.

Hill was made CBE in 1997. For his own paintings, for his generosity, for his work as the impressario-creator of the Tory school of naive marine painters, Derek Hill was made an honorary Irish citizen in 1999 by the President of the Republic, Mrs McAleese. fields.bodyText: Derek Hill, who has died aged 83, won respect as a painter in oils in the early 1950s. It is only in the last decade, however, that respect has broadened into appreciation of his significance. Best known in Britain as a portrait painter, chronicler of that fading Anthony Powell world where high society meets the power nexus as well as haute bohème, Hill came to be seen in his adopted home of Ireland as the master of that country's wild western coastline and broken Atlantic light. To the British, Hill is an interesting anomaly; the "last of the gentlemen painters" is a phrase much used. In Ireland he is a national figure. Such contradictions, successfully reconciled in his work, fall off the page when you remember Derek or consider his life and character. He was an intensely social being who thought of himself as a loner. "All I want is peace," he would say to his friends. Woe betide any who granted this wish by failing to include him in their invitations. This seldom happened. He was excellent company and had good tales to tell. His life as a traveller, a stage designer, an art collector, a painter of famous people, an expert in Islamic architecture, a promoter of talents other than his own, a gardener, and chocoholic equipped him as a raconteur. He was also empathetic and could share the ups and downs of the personal and emotional life of his friends - emotions he had himself to some degree evaded. When I was writing an appreciation of him, published in 1997, he told me that he had never experienced a satisfying physical relationship. Teasing was the best antidote to the legendary Hill attribute of social touchiness. As a friend, you needed to underline the difficulties caused by his occupying a space-time dimension which simultaneously included an evening with the Guermantes circle, as it were, and painting by himself on Tory, an island off (and frequently cut off from) the Donegal coast. Most people who sat for Hill as a portraitist agreed that his ability to paint and converse at the same time was both relaxing and enchanting. His cast of characters include: Freddie Mills; Artur Rubenstein; Bernard Berenson; Lords Hailsham; Mountbatten, Dufferin, Drogheda, Zuckerman and Longford; Isaiah Berlin; Anthony Eden; John Betjeman; Frederick Ashton; Noël Coward; LP Hartley; Kenneth Clarke; Steven Runciman; Osbert Lancaster; Wilfred Thesiger; Tony O'Reilly; Erskine Childers; George Christie and the Duke of Buccleuch. His last major portrait was of Alec Guinness - "so delightful, but so difficult because his genius depends on the anonymity of his face" - whom Derek pre-deceased by a few days. There are two portraits of the Prince of Wales, to whom Derek was devoted. The friendship was reciprocated, as Prince Charles was rightly confident that it was exclusive of his position. But as well as the droppable names, the best portraits include friends and neighbours in Rome, Donegal or on Tory. Hill's landscapes, by contrast, are lonely and seldom peopled. The Irish writer Monk Gibbon put it well. "What is strange," he wrote in 1963, "is that someone like Derek Hill, a humanist with a keen love of social contacts, should have discovered in one of the bleakest and most remote corners of western Europe the seascapes and landscapes themes which many people consider has led him to complete artistic fulfilment." The larger paintings of rocks and sea on Tory rank among the very best pure landscapes painted anywhere since 1945. The "tiny postcard masterpieces", as Derek's Donegal neighbour the American art collector Henry P McIlhenny called Hill's less sculptured landscapes, have the fleeting intensity of a light that changes each minute. They are poetic indeed, but grounded in Hill's knowledge of abstract proportions and his experience as a young designer in a Munich influenced by the Bauhaus before the war. Derek's father was AJL Hill, a cricket captain of Hampshire. The family lived at Romsey and were friends of the Mountbattens. Derek painted Earl Mountbatten, and there is a fine view of Ben Bulben and the stretch of water where Mountbatten was eventually murdered, painted from a lavatory window at Cassiebawn, the Mountbatten's Irish home. AJL Hill was a shrewd businessman and Derek never wanted for money. (He tended to purchase his own paintings when they appeared on the market. As he complained that he was insufficiently appreciated, I had to explain that taste is formed, like it or not, by the market, and that even the best painters need dealers or agents to promote them.) His parents were tolerant of his leaving Marlborough School at 16 to devote himself to the arts: he was for a time a pupil of Kurt Schwitters. While not unsuccessful as a stage designer (he was influenced by a sojourn in Moscow and was knowledgeable about ballet as well as opera), it was the Paris-based English couturier, Edward Molyneaux, who persuaded him to concentrate on painting alone. Molyneaux's great art collection of French Impressionist and post Impressionist paintings (sold to Mrs Mellon and now the bedrock of the National Gallery at Washington collection) taught him light. The best Hills, however, are architectural in the way of Corot, Courbet and Cézanne. One of Hill's most endearing qualities, both as an artist and as a man, was his generosity to those younger than himself and his encouragement of young artists. As a director of the British School in Rome in the 1950s, he nourished such talent as Michael Andrews, John Bratby and Anthony Fry. His own art collection was very fine with great examples of the misty Thames landscape and early abstract paintings of his friend Victor Pasmore. Hill settled in Donegal in 1954. Hitherto his closest thing to a home had been I Tatti, Bernard Berenson's Florentine villa now owned by Harvard. He purchased an old rectory and 20 lakeside acres for £1,000. Here he created a house and a garden which has been featured in many books as masterpieces of interior and garden design. An older brother, John, was a distinguished decorator and he and Derek discovered, and bought, rolls of original Morris wallpapers, which were being used as drawer-lining paper in an Edinburgh hotel. Islamic objects, colours, textiles and designs were also important; Derek published collaborative studies of Islamic architecture in the 1960s and 1970s. My own family lived 15 miles away and as a teenager I would ride over unsurfaced roads to stay in the magical house and eat wonderful food. Elizabeth David, a frequent guest, said that Derek's cook-housekeeper, Gracie, was the best natural cook she had ever encountered. I would return with a loaned Moore maquette in my knapsack or a Sutherland gouache and the beginnings of an educated eye. After making over Glebe House to the Irish nation in the early 1980s, Derek shared a minute cottage with Gracie, who was about 10 years older. fields.headline: Matching personal data 'risk to privacy'
fields.trailText: Plans to step up data matching - the comparison of sets of personal information held by different government agencies - could fall foul of the Human Rights Act, according to an official report published today.
fields.body:
Plans to step up data matching - the comparison of sets of personal information held by different government agencies - could fall foul of the Human Rights Act, according to an official report published today.

The report, a consultation paper prepared by the public audit forum, said data matching could be useful to fight fraud and ensure that citizens received all benefits they were entitled to. But it admitted that the practice could threaten the right to privacy enshrined in article eight of the European convention on human rights.

The convention is written into the Human Rights Act which comes into force on October 2.

The report cited, as an example of data matching on a large scale, the audit commission's national fraud initiative to combat housing benefit fraud. The commission had identified about £42m of fraud, "showing that joined-up government works in this area".

In her latest annual report, Elizabeth France, data protection registrar, said proposals for increased data matching "may well contravene" the Human Rights Act "because of lack of safeguards for individuals".

The threat posed by data matching was highlighted by the judge Sir Nicholas Browne-Wilkinson before he was appointed a law lord: "If the information obtained by the police, the inland revenue, the social security services, the health service and other agencies were to be gathered together in one file, the freedom of the individual would be gravely at risk... The dossier of private information is the badge of the totalitarian state."

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In the state of New York, Hillary Clinton is running for a US Senate seat, not for mayor of the city of New York, as stated on page 5 of G2 on August 8 in an article headed Cherie, the women's champ.
fields.body:
In the state of New York, Hillary Clinton is running for a US Senate seat, not for mayor of the city of New York, as stated on page 5 of G2 on August 8 in an article headed Cherie, the women's champ.

A story yesterday on page 7 named Britain's consul general in Sudan, Lawrence Pickup, as the official who devised a controversial visa form (since withdrawn) designed to prevent asylum seekers reaching Britain. The Foreign Office says Mr Pickup was not the man responsible. It is not quite sure who was.

Errors were made in the names of books cited yesterday, G2, page 16, in a piece headed In search of the killer title. Catch 22 is Catch-22 and William Goldman's book is Adventures in the Screen Trade, not My Adventures ... (A reader feels it was stretching things a bit to use this as evidence of Goldman's titling skills, given its derivation from Dylan Thomas's Adventures in the Skin Trade.)

Homophone corner (and a repeat offender, with its partner defuse), from an ITV listing for Holiday Hotel, G2, page 24, August 8: "Travel rep Claire tries to diffuse the situation between two young tourists and a policeman."

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: John Bunyan
fields.standfirst: Dentist who sought the perfect bite
fields.trailText: John Bunyan, who has died of cancer aged 65, was a brilliantly unorthodox dentist. He gave his patients a "perfect bite" via his occlusion analysis technique. He aimed to get the jaw's workings back to what they should have been without such accidents as missing teeth and poor fillings. Bunyan had developed the technique via the technology of Dr Peter K Thomas, a Los Angeles-based teacher and lecturer of restorative dentistry in the 1960s.
fields.body:
John Bunyan, who has died of cancer aged 65, was a brilliantly unorthodox dentist. He gave his patients a "perfect bite" via his occlusion analysis technique. He aimed to get the jaw's workings back to what they should have been without such accidents as missing teeth and poor fillings. Bunyan had developed the technique via the technology of Dr Peter K Thomas, a Los Angeles-based teacher and lecturer of restorative dentistry in the 1960s.

Bunyan was warm as well as humorous in his Harley Street consulting room. He linked his dentistry to concern for his patients' general health and had so gentle a touch that often neither his drill nor his needle were felt. His family and friends have benefited from his enthusiasms. With our painstakingly remodelled bites, we spend years, sometimes decades, without requiring any dental treatment.

Bunyan, a descendant of the author of The Pilgrim's Progress, was born in London, and after Westminster School qualified in dentistry in 1959 at Guy's Hospital. He worked in his father's Harley Street practice before opening his own. His techniques required an unusually high standard of laboratory work and he was happy when his eldest son became his technician and eventually his business partner.

Bunyan had only the minimum qualification, licentiate of dental studies. He had a low opinion of British post-graduate teaching, which never took up the techniques that he had developed, and he made no efforts to get a doctorate or a Royal College fellowship. At his practice Bunyan numbered politicians, corporate directors and Arab princes among his patients - but he also treated a large number of friends and relatives gratis or at cost - using them, in his earlier years, as grateful guinea pigs.

He was at his happiest in recent years at his beloved Thakeham in West Sussex, with his house and garden full of energy, life and children. His adventurous spirit and manual dexterity converged in his hobbies. These included pedigree cars and model aeroplanes, which he built and flew - more successfully as builder than pilot, since his planes often crashed. He was a skilled maker and mender of clocks, with a large collection.

In 1958 he married Lavinia, daughter of the industrialist Sir Peter Seligman. His four children each gave him grandchildren.

 John Bunyan, dentist, born July 18 1935; died July 29 2000
